Let $\omega$ be its order.
Let $\tau$ be its exponent of convergence.
Then $\tau \le \omega$.

238fbd1f-dd90-4e04-b9ac-5e85dc08591d.text:
The length of one arch of the sine function:
:$y = \sin x$
is given by:
:$L = 2 \sqrt 2 \map E {\dfrac {\sqrt 2} 2}$
where $E$ denotes the incomplete elliptic integral of the second kind.

c4380a3c-a803-44b2-bbab-476b008a35c9.text:
Let $x \in \R_{>1}$ be a (strictly) positive real number greater than $1$.
The characteristic of its common logarithm $\log_{10} x$ is equal to one less than the number of digits to the left of the decimal point of $x$.

73e03774-dd84-47c0-ade2-fbf21e67e033.text:
:$\map \csc {\dfrac \pi 2 - \theta} = \sec \theta$ for $\theta \ne \paren {2 n + 1} \dfrac \pi 2$
where $\csc$ and $\sec$ are cosecant and secant respectively.
That is, the secant of an angle is the cosecant of its complement.
This relation is defined wherever $\cos \theta \ne 0$.

15fab647-3ab9-4675-ab1a-d2877edd2f74.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $a, b \in S$.
The following are dual statements:
:$b \in a^\prec$, the strict lower closure of $a$
:$b \in a^\succ$, the strict upper closure of $a$

a406d7a4-2420-4f78-a5a3-9efb5ecd501d.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=109|body=If, from a medial area a rational area be subtracted, there arise two other irrational straight lines, either a first apotome of a medial straight line or a straight line which produces with a rational area a medial whole.}}

82fdc9fe-756f-4cf3-8753-2a430c98bb68.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma, \mu}$ be a measure space. 
Let $f : X \to \R$ be a $\Sigma$-measurable function.
For each $n \mathop \in \N$, let $f_n : X \to \R$ be a $\Sigma$-measurable function.
Then:
:if $\sequence {f_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ converges in mean to $f$, it converges in measure to $f$.

abb47e60-7bea-46ca-bb8d-f9d5f2022808.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=29|body=To find two rational straight lines commensurable in square only and such that the square on the greater is greater than the square on the less by the square on a straight line commensurable in length with the greater.}}

66fcedce-5737-48a3-9d1a-4d12a2bc3f28.text:
Let $\Z_m$ be the set of integers modulo $m$.
Let $+_m$ be the operation of addition modulo $m$.
Let $\struct {\Z_m, +_m}$ denote the additive group of integers modulo $m$.
Then $\struct {\Z_m, +_m}$ is a cyclic group of order $m$, generated by the element $\eqclass 1 m \in \Z_m$.

8c2829b9-c7ac-4f80-b6f4-67199ed72f7d.text:
:$\ds \paren {\sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n a_i c_i} \paren {\sum_{j \mathop = 1}^n b_j d_j} = \paren {\sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n a_i d_i} \paren {\sum_{j \mathop = 1}^n b_j c_j} + \sum_{1 \mathop \le i \mathop < j \mathop \le n} \paren {a_i b_j - a_j b_i} \paren {c_i d_j - c_j d_i}$
where all of the $a, b, c, d$ are elements of a commutative ring.
Thus the identity holds for $\Z, \Q, \R, \C$.

6df17264-2159-408c-a1a2-1ad6445a3595.text:
Let $f$ be an odd real function with an inverse $f^{-1}$.
Then $f^{-1}$ is also odd.

5c958f02-0bd1-4163-82df-5509cb5e0f40.text:
Let $n, n + 1, n + 2, n + 3$ be four consecutive positive integers.
At least one of these is not square-free.

6d535d85-30a0-4495-860a-f37dc852e528.text:
Let $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n$ be a real or complex series that is absolutely convergent.
If $\pi: \N \to \N$ is a permutation of $N$, then:
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n = \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_{\map \pi n}$

6dc5cf25-cc47-400a-82a4-1975f9b75f14.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=115|body=From a medial straight line there arise irrational straight lines infinite in number, and none of them is the same as any of the preceding.}}

cfd8d887-7e45-42e3-af8f-e13b847f9935.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space which is compact.
Then $M$ is totally bounded.

d0a16c8b-09a6-4e12-8982-046883b6ff45.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A, d_2}$ be metric spaces on the same underlying set $A$.
Let $d_1$ and $d_2$ be Lipschitz equivalent.
Then $d_1$ and $d_2$ are topologically equivalent.

222600b8-0f17-4c9b-a7ff-ef765f17b4ca.text:
Let $\struct {S, \oplus}$ be a magma.
Let $a \in S$.
Let $n \in \N_{>0}$.
Let $\tuple {a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n}$ be the ordered $n$-tuple defined by $a_k = a$ for each $k \in \N_n$.
Then:
:$\ds \bigoplus_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_k = \oplus^n a$
where:
:$\ds \bigoplus_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_k$ is the composite of $\tuple {a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_n}$ for $\oplus$
:$\oplus^n a$ is the $n$th power of $a$ under $\oplus$.

a42fcc1e-34e3-491f-8bc2-beebd72137ba.text:
:$\sin^4 x - \cos^4 x = \sin^2 x - \cos^2 x$
where $\sin$ and $\cos$ denote sine and cosine respectively.

b13435ee-5605-4e67-9c50-1a076070e013.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a division ring.
Then $\struct {R^*, \circ}$ is a group.

9689c487-7dbf-4481-8291-bf043b41df38.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the Arens-Fort space.
Then $T$ is totally separated.

f6a5dfc7-d108-4518-b1aa-bc174f41d3e5.text:
Let $S_1, S_2, \ldots, S_n$ all be tosets.
Let $T_n$ be the ordered sum of $S_1, S_2, \ldots, S_n$:
:$\forall n \in \N_{>0}: T_n = \begin{cases}
S_1 & : n = 1 \\
T_{n - 1} + S_n & : n > 1
\end{cases}$
Then $T_n$ is a toset.

66b4677a-5f65-43b7-a039-da61ab4e3ac1.text:
Let $A, T$ be sets such that $A \subseteq T$.
Let $S = \powerset T$ denote the power set of $T$.
Let $\alpha$ denote the relation defined on $S$ by:
:$\forall X, Y \in S: X \mathrel \alpha Y \iff X \cap A = Y \cap A$
Then $\alpha$ is an equivalence relation.

b0a419b4-7402-4f6b-a437-478d189ef428.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, \preceq_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \preceq_2}$ be ordered sets.
Let $\struct {S_1 \times S_2, \precsim}$ be the simple order product of $\struct {S_1, \preceq_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \preceq_2}$.
Let $X_1$ be a non-empty subset of $S_1$, $X_2$ be a non-empty subset of $S_2$ such that
:$X_1$ and $X_2$ admit suprema.
Then:
:$X_1 \times X_2$ admits a supremum
and:
:$\map \sup {X_1 \times X_2} = \tuple {\sup X_1, \sup X_2}$

95b1d85f-a40d-4a76-ba90-36aea881da7f.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a finite complement topology on an infinite set $S$.
Let $T \times D$ be the double pointed topology on $T$.
Then $T \times D$ is not a $T_0$ space, $T_1$ space, $T_2$ space, $T_3$ space, $T_4$ space or $T_5$ space.

18ae89d5-c24f-4648-8f98-27405d803c04.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is defined on a real interval $I$.
{{TFAE|def = Strictly Convex Real Function}}

ffd89c63-b23e-475a-9076-113b0d9efadf.text:
Let $n \ge 0$ be a integer. 
Then: 
:$\map \zeta {-n} = \paren {-1}^n \dfrac {B_{n + 1} } {n + 1}$ 
where:
:$B_n$ is the $n$th Bernoulli number
:$\zeta$ is the Riemann Zeta function

cb36e581-b92f-4a18-8b42-4ee78935fedc.text:
Let $a \in \R_{\ne 0}$.
Then:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x \paren {a x^2 + b x + c} } = \frac 1 {2 c} \ln \size {\frac {x^2} {a x^2 + b x + c} } - \frac b {2 c} \int \frac {\d x} {a x^2 + b x + c}$

2fdaf51a-6437-4d19-bf69-3c2736950515.text:
Let $D$ be the unit disk centred at $0$.
Let $f : D \to \C$ be a holomorphic function.
If:
:$\cmod {\map f \omega} = \cmod \omega$ for some $\omega \in D \setminus \set 0$
or:
:$\cmod {\map {f'} 0} = 1$
then $\map f z = a z$ for all $z \in D$ for some $a \in \C$ with $\cmod a = 1$.

0ceeebdc-8cdd-461c-8533-2f0bf1c3885c.text:
Let $\ds \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^\infty a_k$ be a convergent series in $\R$.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to 1^-} \paren {\sum_{k \mathop = 0}^\infty a_k x^k} = \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^\infty a_k$
where $\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to 1^-}$ denotes the limit from the left.
Abel's Theorem first appears in {{AuthorRef|Niels Henrik Abel|Abel}}'s paper {{ArticleLink|authorNolink = Niels Henrik Abel|title = Mémoire sur une Propriété Générale d'une Classe Très-Étendue de Fonctions Transcendantes}}.
{{AuthorRef|Carl Gustav Jacob Jacobi}} remarked that it was the greatest discovery in integral calculus in the $19$th century.
{{explain|From the way it is described in {{BookLink|Calculus Gems|George F. Simmons}}, I wonder whether this actually is that same result: "the discovery about integrals of algebraic functions now known as Abel's theorem". There are several such "Abel's Theorems", it's far from clear which citation refers to what.}}

1b2193fa-436b-45a7-afea-d889ca633bbd.text:
Let $\alpha$ be a cut.
Let $p \in \alpha$.
Let $q \in \Q$ such that $q \notin \alpha$.
Then $q > p$.

6e9e100a-df03-4e2a-bd62-a8edb94cd106.text:
Let $f$ be a separated morphism of schemes.
Then $f$ is quasi-separated.

fb6f7df7-0b18-4ec3-9b06-7afc482e322a.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=65|body=The square on the side of the sum of two medial areas applied to a rational straight line produces as breadth the sixth binomial.}}

50e7c3a3-c745-408e-8990-c12b60c2287a.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $J$ be an ideal of $R$.
Let $\struct {R / J, +, \circ}$ be the quotient ring defined by $J$.
Then $\struct {R / J, +, \circ}$ is a ring with unity, and its unity is $1_R + J$.

cb199c02-9179-47dc-b28f-423d93ca48ef.text:
Let $\map {\R^3} {x, y, z}$ denote the real Cartesian space of $3$ dimensions.
Let $\mathbf V$ be a vector field on $\R^3$.
Then:
:$\curl \curl \mathbf V = \grad \operatorname {div} \mathbf V - \nabla^2 \mathbf V$
where:
:$\curl$ denotes the curl operator
:$\operatorname {div}$ denotes the divergence operator
:$\grad$ denotes the gradient operator
:$\nabla^2 \mathbf V$ denotes the Laplacian.

b7c20230-6c5d-4575-ab3c-7c31e8e91a4b.text:
Let $G$ and $H$ both be finite cyclic groups with orders $n = \order G$ and $m = \order H$ respectively.
Then their group direct product $G \times H$ is cyclic {{iff}} $g$ and $h$ are coprime, that is, $g \perp h$.

8355ed66-81a6-43f3-bbe7-130f3fc864f6.text:
Let $x, y \in \R$.
Then the following are equivalent:
:$(1): \quad x < y$
:$(2): \quad y - x > 0$

03d98fae-8c94-4b7a-be64-54e84b7fe308.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be a sequence in $T$.
Let $q \in S$ be an accumulation point of $\sequence {a_n}$.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $q$ is also a limit point of $\sequence {a_n}$.

118f6780-d3c7-4afc-b350-6122492fea58.text:
Let $S$ be a set and let $\PP$ be a partition on $S$ which is not the (trivial) partition of singletons.
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the partition space whose basis is $\PP$.
Then $T$ is not a $T_{2 \frac 1 2}$ (completely Hausdorff) space.

2900aedb-c5d7-4c8f-87c6-2108ff0f8d1c.text:
Let $\struct {X, d}$ and $\struct {Y, d'}$ be metric spaces. 
Let $\map {\mathcal C} {X, Y}$ be the set of continuous functions $X \to Y$.
Let $\mathcal F = \set {f_1, f_2, \ldots, f_n}$ be a finite subset of $\map {\mathcal C} {X, Y}$.
Then $\mathcal F$ is pointwise equicontinuous.

63295fd1-c73d-4d87-9cc1-e982eb88cd89.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \preceq, \tau}$ be a linearly ordered space.
Let $A$ and $B$ be separated sets of $T$.
Let $A^*$ and $B^*$ be defined as:
:$A^* := \ds \bigcup \set {\closedint a b: a, b \in A, \closedint a b \cap B^- = \O}$
:$B^* := \ds \bigcup \set {\closedint a b: a, b \in B, \closedint a b \cap A^- = \O}$
where $A^-$ and $B^-$ denote the closure of $A$ and $B$ in $T$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad A \subseteq A^*$
:$(2): \quad B \subseteq B^*$
:$(3): \quad A^* \cap B^* = \O$

55be07ff-1c5b-44c3-bbea-8fe065d46128.text:
Let $u$ be a differentiable real function of $x$.
Then:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\sec u} = \sec u \tan u \dfrac {\d u} {\d x}$
where $\sec$ is the secant function and $\tan$ is the tangent function.

068c04c8-26bf-4dd6-a2cc-7a889ae9d5e7.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a topological space.
Let $x \in S$.
Then the singleton set $\left\{{x}\right\}$ is not dense-in-itself.

42be3a1f-3949-48d9-aa73-5e6c6d8ad043.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \circ_2}$ be algebraic structures with identities $e_1, e_2$ respectively.
The canonical injections:
:$\inj_1: \struct {S_1, \circ_1} \to \struct {S_1, \circ_1} \times \struct {S_2, \circ_2}: \forall x \in S_1: \map {\inj_1} x = \tuple {x, e_2}$
:$\inj_2: \struct {S_2, \circ_2} \to \struct {S_1, \circ_1} \times \struct {S_2, \circ_2}: \forall x \in S_2: \map {\inj_2} x = \tuple {e_1, x}$
are injections.

de9ff0dd-259e-473e-9943-d7b82094e1c8.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^2 \paren {\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} }^3} = \frac {-\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } {a^4 x} + \frac x {a^4 \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } + C$

4d43c9ac-426f-43e1-aa6c-a27b31b785ad.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is defined on $I \subseteq \R$.
Let $f$ be strictly monotone on $I$.
Let the image of $f$ be $J$. 
Then $f$ always has an inverse function $f^{-1}$ and:
:if $f$ is strictly increasing then so is $f^{-1}$
:if $f$ is strictly decreasing then so is $f^{-1}$.

80a59c69-784b-46aa-897c-937f8dc8240b.text:
Let $S$ be an uncountable set.
Let $H \subseteq S$ be a countable subset of $S$.
Let $T = \struct {H, \tau}$ be a topological space on the underlying set $H$.
Then despite the fact that $H$ is countable, the set of limit points of $T$ may be uncountable.

f584fbb6-ae27-4a4f-ad9e-0cc3e7d75ad1.text:
Let $\struct {S, \RR}$ be a relational structure.
Let $\RR$ be a strictly well-founded relation.
Then there exists no infinite sequence $\sequence {a_n}$ of elements of $S$ such that:
:$\forall n \in \N: a_{n + 1} \mathrel \RR a_n$

dc78a14b-edc5-4dda-96b3-baffcfc65ef9.text:
Let $\map f z$ be a mapping with isolated poles.
{{explain|Explain the context in which this theorem is placed. For example, what is the domain and range of $f$? One supposes $\C$ but it needs to be made clear.}}
Let $f$ go to zero faster than $\dfrac 1 {\size z}$ as $\size z \to \infty$.
{{explain|"faster"}}
Let $C$ be a contour that is deformed such that all poles of $\map f z$ are contained in $C$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum \limits_{n \mathop = -\infty}^\infty \paren {-1}^n \map f n = \frac 1 {2 i} \oint_C \frac {\map f z} {\sin \pi z} \rd z$

8cc27c12-f929-4fd5-9ac5-20d01e755c0d.text:
Let $\struct {F, +, \circ, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a valued field.
Let $\struct {F^\N, +, \circ}$ be the commutative ring of sequences over $F$ with unity $\tuple {1, 1, 1, \dotsc}$.
Let $\CC \subset F^\N$ be the set of Cauchy sequences on $F$.
Then:
:$\struct {\CC, +, \circ}$ is a commutative subring of $F^\N$ with unity $\tuple {1, 1, 1, \dotsc}$.

27665c94-88b9-49ca-8cd3-fe0a1913db50.text:
Let $\family {\struct {X_i, \tau_i} }_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of topological spaces where $I$ is an arbitrary index set.
Let $X$ be the cartesian product of $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$:
:$\ds X := \prod_{i \mathop \in I} X_i$
Then the natural basis on $X$ is the set $\BB$ of cartesian products of the form $\ds \prod_{i \mathop \in I} U_i$ where:
:for all $i \in I : U_i \in \tau_i$
:for all but finitely many indices $i : U_i = X_i$

1c24ae35-9448-4c34-af7f-97a56c42cc74.text: :$\ds \int \frac {x \rd x} {\sin^n a x} = \frac {-x \cos a x} {a \paren {n - 1} \sin^{n - 1} a x} - \frac 1 {a^2 \paren {n - 1} \paren {n - 2} \sin^{n - 2} a x} + \frac {n - 2} {n - 1} \int \frac {x \rd x} {\sin^{n - 2} a x}$

e43e14cb-6a3a-4933-ba78-8492f3128c78.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $
orm {\,\cdot\,}^\Q_p$ be the p-adic norm on the rationals $\Q$.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, 
orm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Then $\struct {\Q_p, 
orm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ is a completion of $\struct {\Q, 
orm {\,\cdot\,}^\Q_p}$

77efeb87-ef56-4c97-9434-c19410b6e22b.text:
Let $\nu: \O \to T$ be an empty mapping.
Then $\nu$ is an injection.

f82e04c3-dfea-4ba4-8a90-40c298cd0bdc.text:
Let $\left({R,+,*}\right)$ be a ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let the characteristic of $R$ be $m$.
Let $\left({\Z_m, +_m, \times_m}\right)$ be the ring of integers modulo $m$.
Let $\circ$ be the mapping from $\Z_m \times R$ to $R$ defined as:
:$\forall \left[\!\left[a\right]\!\right]_m \in \Z_m: \forall x \in R: \left[\!\left[a\right]\!\right]_m \circ x = a \cdot x$
where $\left[\!\left[a\right]\!\right]_m$ is the residue class of $a$ modulo $m$ and $a \cdot x$ is the $a$th power of $x$.
Then $\left({R, +, \circ}\right)_{\Z_m}$ is a unitary $\Z_m$-module.

424643f6-76d1-40bf-af57-f627b44f1d45.text:
Set difference is right distributive over union.
Let $R, S, T$ be sets.
Then:
:$\paren {R \cup S} \setminus T = \paren {R \setminus T} \cup \paren {S \setminus T}$
where:
:$R \setminus S$ denotes set difference
:$R \cup T$ denotes set union.

6e6dd427-facb-4a27-b517-fea8a4e9da31.text:
Let $a, b \in \Z_{>0}$ be (strictly) positive integers.
Let $a \divides b$.
Then:
:$a \le b$

4a861429-c6ad-45da-9145-72d18e38af29.text:
Let $a, b \in \R$ and $m \in \Z$.
Let $a$ be congruent to $b$ modulo $m$, that is:
:$a \equiv b \pmod m$
Then:
:$\forall n \in \Z_{\ge 0}: a^n \equiv b^n \pmod m$

cb3d1520-3f31-4da6-a6de-02720ce997e3.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $*: G \times S \to S$ be a group action.
Let $\RR_G$ be the relation induced by $G$, that is:
:$x \mathrel {\RR_G} y \iff y \in \Orb x$
where:
:$\Orb x$ denotes the orbit of $x \in X$.
Then:
:$\RR_G$ is an equivalence relation.
:The equivalence class of an element is its orbit.

f153e047-b5a3-4bc5-a56e-000adf9d7b13.text:
Let $\C$ denote the complex numbers.
Let $f$ and $g$ be complex functions defined on an open subset $S \subseteq \C$, except possibly at the point $c \in S$.
Let $f$ and $g$ tend to the following limits:
:$\ds \lim_{z \mathop \to c} \map f z = l$
:$\ds \lim_{z \mathop \to c} \map g z = m$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{z \mathop \to c} \paren {\map f z + \map g z} = l + m$

e32774c9-795e-42ce-a260-8730d261ffd2.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $I \subset \R$ be the closed real interval $\closedint a b$.
Let $\gamma: I \to S$ be a path.
Then:
:$\map \gamma I$ is a path-connected set of $T$.

152cede8-24c4-4e83-ad13-1ab30e577476.text:
Let $A, B \subseteq S$.
Then:
:$\chi_{A \symdif B} = \chi_A + \chi_B - 2 \chi_{A \cap B}$ 
where:
:$\chi$ denotes characteristic function
:$\symdif$ denotes symmetric difference.

302c0aca-12df-4ff3-84cb-43b771e7327c.text:
Let $a, b, z \in \R$.
Let $a$ be congruent to $b$ modulo $z$:
: $a \equiv b \pmod z$
Then:
:$\forall c \in \R: a + c \equiv b + c \pmod z$

8342259e-55b6-48b7-9c0d-e32e8ce4f047.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a characteristic subgroup of $G$.
Let $K$ be a characteristic subgroup of $H$.
Then $K$ is a characteristic subgroup of $G$.

feb84f1e-475c-4aec-ad4f-34914fd25eb8.text: The smallest Fermat pseudoprime to bases $2$, $3$ and $5$ is $1729$.

cd60cb20-d162-48dc-992e-11e343899ebe.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ such that $n = a^2 + b^2$ where $a, b \in \Z$.
Then $n$ is not congruent modulo $4$ to $3$.

a58e3910-0d86-4dce-a057-f6ccb75c87d3.text: Every equivalence relation is a congruence for the left operation.

42f8f7df-675f-40f8-b761-8cc695ec78f8.text:
Let $\alpha$ denote the relation defined on the natural numbers $\N$ by:
:$\forall x, y \in \N: x \mathrel \alpha y \iff \exists n \in \Z: x = 2^n y$
We have that $\alpha$ is an equivalence relation.
Let $\eqclass n \alpha$ be the $\alpha$-equivalence class of a natural number $n$.
Then $\eqclass n \alpha$ contains exactly $1$ odd number.

b997b684-f885-4ee3-bb95-633b46536a2f.text:
Let $z \in \C$ be a complex number.
Let $\overline z$ denote the complex conjugate of $z$.
Let $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$ be a positive integer.
Then:
:$\overline {z^n} = \left({\overline z}\right)^n$

f374957b-4a4d-43e0-b6a2-013df32f4f44.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty \map \cos {a x^2} \rd x = \frac 1 2 \sqrt {\frac \pi {2 a} }$
where $a$ is a positive real number.

a45cce2c-4680-48df-8892-616d26235bdb.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\paren {1 + \sin a x}^2} = \frac {-1} {2 a} \map \tan {\frac \pi 4 - \frac {a x} 2} - \frac 1 {6 a} \map {\tan^3} {\frac \pi 4 - \frac {a x} 2} + C$

f06a82d2-f5be-40bf-a0a5-f856cddc3a43.text:
Let $S$ denote the open real interval:
:$S := \openint {-1} 1$
Let $x \in S$.
Let $\tanh^{-1} x$ be the inverse hyperbolic tangent of $x$.
Then:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\tanh^{-1} x} = \dfrac 1 {1 - x^2}$

fd4be417-eb07-47d0-b1e7-916516166b06.text:
Let $\EE$ be an experiment with a probability space $\struct {\Omega, \Sigma, \Pr}$.
The event space $\Sigma$ of $\EE$ has the property that:
:$A, B \in \Sigma \implies A \setminus B \in \Sigma$
That is, the difference of two events is also an event in the event space.

30498d50-c445-4c41-986a-3b6dd872c4f6.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Then $p$ is the smallest prime number which divides $\paren {p - 1}! + 1$.

bb0224c9-e698-48b4-92b5-f7f0f696a595.text:
Let $\Gamma$ denote the Gamma function.
Then:
:$\map \Gamma {\dfrac 1 2} = \sqrt \pi$
Its decimal expansion starts:
:$\map \Gamma {\dfrac 1 2} = 1 \cdotp 77245 \, 38509 \, 05516 \, 02729 \, 81674 \, 83341 \, 14518 \, 27975 \ldots$
{{OEIS|A002161}}

bf600e9e-9099-4ac8-b130-8270b95f9086.text:
Let $T_1 = \struct {S_1, \tau_1}$ and $T_2 = \struct {S_2, \tau_2}$ be topological spaces.
Let $T = \struct {T_1 \times T_2, \tau}$ be the product space of $T_1$ and $T_2$, where $\tau$ is the product topology on $S$.
Let $H \subseteq T_1$ and $K \subseteq T_2$.
Then:
:$\map \partial {H \times K} = \paren {\map \partial H \times \map \cl K} \cup \paren {\map \cl H \times \map \partial K}$
where:
:$\map \cl H$, for example, denotes the closure of $H$.
:$\map \partial H$, for example, denotes the boundary of $H$.

7135dc6a-b933-4b03-9f2a-9a74a2623c46.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $\mathbb T \subseteq \powerset S$, where $\powerset S$ is the power set of $S$.
Suppose all $T \in \mathbb T$ admit a supremum $\sup T$ in $S$.
Then:
:$\sup \bigcup \mathbb T = \sup {\set {\sup T: T \in \mathbb T} }$
if one of these two quantities exists (in $S$).

957bacb5-2ef0-42b3-a6db-6b1dc6614f89.text:
For $n \in \N$, let $\R^n$ be an Euclidean space.
Let $p \in \R_{\ge 1}$.
Let $d_p$ be the $p$-product metric on $\R^n$.
Let $d_0$ be the standard discrete metric on $\R^n$.
Then $d_p$ and $d_0$ are not topologically equivalent.

6edce4c9-0b6a-4ebd-a7e7-46445aad8a18.text:
Let $a, b \in \Z$ such that $a$ and $b$ are not both zero.
Let $\gcd \set {a, b}$ be the greatest common divisor of $a$ and $b$.
Then:
:$\exists x, y \in \Z: a x + b y = \gcd \set {a, b}$
That is, $\gcd \set {a, b}$ is an integer combination (or linear combination) of $a$ and $b$.
Furthermore, $\gcd \set {a, b}$ is the smallest positive integer combination of $a$ and $b$.
Let $\struct {D, +, \times}$ be a Euclidean domain whose zero is $0$ and whose unity is $1$.
Let $\nu: D \setminus \set 0 \to \N$ be the Euclidean valuation on $D$.
Let $a, b \in D$ such that $a$ and $b$ are not both equal to $0$.
Let $\gcd \set {a, b}$ be the greatest common divisor of $a$ and $b$.
Then:
:$\exists x, y \in D: a \times x + b \times y = \gcd \set {a, b}$
such that $\gcd \set {a, b}$ is the element of $D$ such that:
:$\forall c = a \times x + b \times y \in D: \map \nu {\gcd \set {a, b} } \le \map \nu c$
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be a principal ideal domain.
Let $S = \set {a_1, a_2, \dotsc, a_n}$ be a set of non-zero elements of $D$.
Let $y$ be a greatest common divisor of $S$.
Then $y$ is expressible in the form:
:$y = d_1 a_1 + d_2 a_2 + \dotsb + d_n a_n$
where $d_1, d_2, \dotsc, d_n \in D$.
There are sources which suggest that Bézout's Lemma was first noticed by {{AuthorRef|Claude Gaspard Bachet de Méziriac}}.
{{AuthorRef|Étienne Bézout}}'s contribution was to prove a more general result, for polynomials.
{{TheoremWanted|This result can also be expanded to include more general objects, as far up as bézout domains. Specifically the page Bézout's Lemma/Bézout Domain is needed.}}

ee28f840-b354-4180-8ef3-8ee436bd86b4.text:
Let $\mathbb D$ be a subset of $\N$.
Let $\sequence {a_n}: \mathbb D \to \R$ be a real sequence.
Let $\mathbb X$ be a real interval such that $\mathbb D \subseteq \mathbb X$.
Let $f: \mathbb X \to \R, x \mapsto \map f x$ be a differentiable real function.
Suppose that for every $n \in \mathbb D$:
:$\map f n = a_n$
Then:
:If $\forall x \in \mathbb X: D_x \map f x \ge 0$, $\sequence {a_n}$ is increasing
:If $\forall x \in \mathbb X: D_x \map f x >  0$, $\sequence {a_n}$ is strictly increasing
:If $\forall x \in \mathbb X: D_x \map f x \le 0$, $\sequence {a_n}$ is decreasing
:If $\forall x \in \mathbb X: D_x \map f x < 0$, $\sequence {a_n}$ is strictly decreasing
where $D_x$ denotes differentiation {{WRT|Differentiation}} $x$.

ba407608-f531-44fb-9715-308f5e6f8d01.text:
Let $\CC$ be the Cantor set.
Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the real number space $\R$ under the Euclidean topology $\tau_d$.
Then $\CC$ is a compact subset of $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$.

813ac737-b86f-42bb-927c-f29c23883375.text:
Let $C$ be a contour in $\C$.
Let $f, g: \Img C \to \C$ be continuous complex functions, where $\Img C$ denotes the image of $C$.
Let $\lambda, \mu \in \C$ be complex constants.
Then:
:$\displaystyle \int_C \paren {\lambda \map f z + \mu \map g z} \rd z = \lambda \int_C \map f z \rd z + \mu \int_C \map g z \rd z$

f357b9cb-ce98-4aae-9b2d-951a82c6ac03.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \preceq}\right)$ be a bounded below join semilattice.
Let $P = \left({K\left({L}\right), \precsim}\right)$ be an ordered subset of $L$,
where $K\left({L}\right)$ denotes the compact subset of $L$.
Then $P$ is a bounded below join semilattice.

4be9825c-0db7-4a21-b697-46965156f4e5.text: Every group has exactly one idempotent element: the identity.

393095fa-b868-4e54-b259-db85c8d8fa65.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring
Let $\mathbb L$ be a non-empty set of ideals of $R$.
Then the intersection $\bigcap \mathbb L$ of the members of $\mathbb L$ is itself an ideal of $R$.

8cb638d3-325b-4574-b298-ff0ebc5f984a.text:
Let $S = \set {1, 2, 3, 4, \ldots, n}$ be a set of integers from $1$ through $n$.
Let $2^t$ be the greatest power of $2$ in $S$.
Then $2^t$ does not divide any other integer in $S$.
That is, no other member of $S$ is a multiple of $2^t$.

283953f9-606a-44de-b204-3dd3bf13b819.text:
Let $z \in \C$ be a complex number.
Let $z$ be interpreted as a vector in the complex plane.
Let $w \in \C$ be the complex number defined as $z$ multiplied by the imaginary unit $i$:
:$w = i z$
Then $w$ can be interpreted as the vector $z$ after being rotated through a right angle in an anticlockwise direction.

770ed8ee-cb9a-4021-82be-77c420029003.text:
Let $\struct {R, 
orm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\struct {S_1, 
orm {\, \cdot \,}_1 }$ and $\struct {S_2, 
orm {\, \cdot \,}_2 }$ be normed division ring completions of $\struct {R, 
orm {\, \cdot \,} }$
Then there exists an isometric isomorphism $\psi: \struct {S_1, 
orm {\, \cdot \,}_1 } 	o \struct {S_2, 
orm {\, \cdot \,}_2 }$

88bd6997-9215-40f9-b5a3-7b3bf10e7995.text:
:$\map \sec {2 \pi - \theta} = \sec \theta$
where $\sec$ denotes secant.
That is, the secant of an angle equals its conjugate.

8a9597e7-71f4-4fd7-b87d-ee59b22b9dc0.text: The set of real numbers $\R$ forms an ordered integral domain under addition and multiplication: $\struct {\R, +, \times, \le}$.

eab55029-0194-4eac-9632-02e6f74de1f1.text:
Let $\size x > a$.
Then:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {a^2 - x^2} = \dfrac 1 {2 a} \map \ln {\dfrac {x + a} {x - a} } + C$

d47a267e-6c09-46ca-a2de-78b1ff0ae63c.text:
For $n \in \N_{>0}$, let $\map \Lambda n$ be the von Mangoldt function.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{N \mathop \to \infty} \frac 1 N \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^N \map \Lambda n = 1$
is logically equivalent to the Prime Number Theorem.

a14a6ddc-a4f6-4a6c-927e-54b286070739.text:
Let $X$ be the set of real functions $f: \R \to \R$ which possess continuous derivatives.
Let $\RR \subseteq X \times X$ be the equivalence relation on $X$ defined as:
:$\RR = \set {\tuple {f, g} \in X \times X: D f = D g}$
where $D f$ denotes the first derivative of $f$.
Then the equivalence classes of $\RR$ are defined as:
:$\map {\eqclass f \RR} x = \set {g \in X: \exists c \in \R: \forall x \in \R: \map g x = \map f x + c}$
That is, it consists of the set of all real functions $f \in X$ which differ by a real constant.

622a638b-e608-483b-b359-3c8fdac092b2.text:
Let $F$ be a mapping satisfying the following properties:
{{explain|What is $G$?}}
: The domain of $F$ is $\On$, the ordinal class
: For all ordinals $x$, $\map F x = \map G {F \restriction x}$.
: For all ordinals $x$, if $A \setminus \Img x \ne \O$, then $\map G {F \restriction x} \in A \setminus \Img x$ where $\Img x$ is the image of the subset $x$ under $F$.
: $A$ is a set.
Then there exists an ordinal $y$ satisfying the following properties:
: $\forall x \in y: A \setminus \Img x \ne \O$
: $\Img y = A$
: $F \restriction y$ is an injective mapping.
Note that the first third and fourth properties of $F$ are the most important.  For any mapping $G$, a mapping $F$ can be constructed satisfying the first two properties using transfinite recursion.

7161e5b1-6417-4205-ac2a-f03d94e79788.text:
Let $f: \C \to \C$ be a complex function.
Let $U \subseteq \C$ be an open set such that $f$ has no zeros in $U$.
Suppose further that $f$ is holomorphic in $U$.
Then the complex function
:$\dfrac 1 {f_{\restriction U} } : U \to \C$
is holomorphic.

4f85edc8-5014-4674-85f7-6b002c88a77b.text:
Let $S = \set s$ be a singleton.
Let $\RR$ be a reflexive relation on $S$.
Then $\RR$ is a well-ordering on $S$.

13ce0e0f-4363-4a64-b59a-9dde759f0c5a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \neg}$ be a Boolean algebra.
Then $\neg \top = \bot$.

7a326c22-b68f-4777-a646-3d60253a2310.text:
Let $f$ be a real function defined on an interval $I$.
Let $a$ be a point in $I$ where $f$ is right-hand differentiable.
Then $f$ is right-continuous at $a$.

bba66a58-426b-4460-bf73-c061fd33fbdd.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau_S}$ be a topological space.
Let $D$ be a doubleton endowed with the indiscrete topology.
Let $\struct {S \times D, \tau}$ be the double pointed topology on $S$.
Let $X \subseteq S \times D$ be a subset of $S \times D$.
Then the closure of $X$ in $\tau$ is:
:$\map \cl X = \map \cl {\map {\pr_1} X} \times D$
where $\pr_1$ denotes the first projection on $S \times D$.

54037956-ccd5-4235-a6e5-6448ee267b5a.text:
Let $\struct {\mathbb K, \norm{\,\cdot\,}}$ be a valued field.
Let $\sequence {1 + a_n}$ be a sequence of nonzero elements of $\mathbb K$.
Let the infinite product $\ds \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \left({1 + a_n}\right)$ converge absolutely to $a \in \mathbb K \setminus \set 0$.
Then $\ds \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \frac 1 {1 + a_n}$  converges absolutely to $1 / a$.

7b770fea-baec-4731-93fc-4c49839aaff6.text:
Let $\struct {K, +, \times}$ be a field.
Let $L / K$ be a field extension over $K$.
Let $\struct {L, +, \times}_K$ be the a vector space of $L$ over $K$.
Then $\struct {L, +, \times}_K$ is a vector space.

50ed3472-2592-48de-8956-f428f9413825.text:
Let $\RR$ be a relation on a set $S$.
Then $\RR^=$, the reflexive closure of $\RR$, is reflexive.

41681160-5cf8-46ee-a55e-43870543f322.text:
Let $\Q_{>0}$ denote the set of strictly positive rational numbers:
:$\Q_{>0} := \set {x \in \Q: x > 0}$
where $\Q$ denotes the set of rational numbers.
The algebraic structure $\struct {\Q_{>0}, +}$ is closed in the sense that:
:$\forall a, b \in \Q_{>0}: a + b \in \Q_{>0}$
where $+$ denotes rational addition.

a238cf53-d7b2-480e-b53b-5c7f7139fd85.text:
Let $\mathbf a, \mathbf b$ be vector quantities.
Then:
:$\mathbf a + \mathbf b = \mathbf b + \mathbf a$

9afa1678-8c78-4daa-b289-14aad940fcff.text: :$\ds \int \cos^4 a x \rd x = \frac {3 x} 8 + \frac {\sin 2 a x} {4 a} + \frac {\sin 4 a x} {32 a} + C$

a97d12e7-0cff-482e-8a5b-d5d97e8218a7.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the either-or space.
Then $T$ is a Lindelöf space.

a206f0a2-6728-4814-9a6b-dfa220a91d5c.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be a principal ideal domain.
Let $S = \set {a_1, a_2, \dotsc, a_n}$ be a set of non-zero elements of $D$.
Let $y_1$ and $y_2$ be greatest common divisors of $S$.
Then $y_1$ and $y_2$ are associates.

821386b8-1aca-470f-acce-575bdc2ff351.text:
:$\ds \int \frac {x^3 \rd x} {a^2 - x^2} = -\frac {x^2} 2 - \frac {a^2} 2 \map \ln {a^2 - x^2} + C$
for $x^2 < a^2$.

02d42354-f20f-4a0c-b1a0-5342d172cdab.text:
Let $\struct {S, \vee_1, \wedge_1, \preceq_1}$ and $\struct {T, \vee_2, \wedge_2, \preceq_2}$ be complete lattices.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping such that
:for all directed sets $\struct {D, \precsim}$ and Moore-Smith sequences $N:D \to S$ in $S$: $\map f {\liminf N} \preceq_2 \map \liminf {f \circ N}$
Then $f$ preserves directed suprema.

c51518f3-194c-40c1-bd10-e189c2d9a67d.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq_1}$ and $\struct {T, \preceq_2}$ be ordered sets.
Let $S'$ be the image of a mapping $\phi: \struct {S, \preceq_1} \to \struct {T, \preceq_2}$.
Then:
:$\phi$ is an order embedding from $\struct {S, \preceq_1}$ into $\struct {T, \preceq_2}$
{{iff}}:
:$\phi$ is an order isomorphism from $\struct {S, \preceq_1}$ into $\struct {S', \preceq_2 \restriction_{S'} }$.

d6337193-ae14-40c0-b7d8-a1321b0b399c.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer such that $n \ge 118$.
Then between $n$ and $\dfrac {4 n} 3$ there exists at least one prime number of each of the forms:
:$4 m - 1, 4 m + 1, 6 m - 1, 6 m + 1$

9b524974-46fb-4c3c-87ae-92b76cbd3112.text: Congruence modulo $m$ is a congruence relation on $\struct {\Z, +}$.

ac1e29c3-1d25-4ea4-82e7-58bf9ff79927.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose identity is $e$ and whose order is $n$.
Then:
:$\forall g \in G: g^n = e$

f4820bc9-f1af-46ef-8bc5-0fefc6302edf.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets, such that:
:$\exists f: S \to T$ such that $f$ is an injection
:$\exists g: T \to S$ such that $g$ is an injection.
Then there exists a bijection from $S$ to $T$.

bd62b37b-5cd5-48f5-b33e-45c14f31312a.text:
Let $\left({P, s, 0}\right)$ be a Peano structure.
Let $P'$ be the set $s \left[{P}\right]$, that is:
:$P' = \left\{{s \left({n}\right): n \in P}\right\}$
Let $s'$ be the restriction of $s$ to $P'$.
Then $\left({P', s', s \left({0}\right)}\right)$ is also a Peano structure.

b88f5511-0119-4158-9876-bd7e1f29ac68.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let $x \in G$.
Let:
: $H x$ be the right coset of $x$ modulo $H$.
Then:
: $x \in H x$

bbe9c09f-9b15-423c-8fbd-02fe27c9c963.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ and $\struct {H, *}$ be groups.
Let $f: G \to H$ and $g: G \to H$ be group homomorphisms.
Then the set:
:$S = \set {x \in G: \map f x = \map g x}$
is a subgroup of $G$.

1bc6c255-8e6f-44a4-a4e0-7457aab7ca77.text:
Let $x, y, z \in \Z$ such that $z > 0$.
Then:
:$x < y \iff z x < z y$
:$x \le y \iff z x \le z y$

4ff105d1-772d-48b1-a330-4a5ad57bedde.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ, \preceq}$ be a naturally ordered semigroup.
Let $0$ be the zero of $S$.
Let $1$ be the one of $S$.
Then:
:$0 \prec 1$

b4e0058c-8c67-46c1-8a86-9016e00c0afc.text:
Let $G$ and $H$ be groups.
Let $Z$ and $W$ be central subgroups of $G$ and $H$ respectively.
Then $Z \times W$ is a central subgroup of $G \times H$.

253ed36e-833c-4089-859d-70b9cbe9fdaf.text:
Let $A$ be an inductive class under a mapping $g$.
Let $A$ be a set.
Then there exists some subset $S$ of $A$ such that $S$ is minimally inductive under $g$.

3e1197e9-2af5-4942-ba79-41fd64c34c66.text:
Let $S \ne \O$ be a non-empty set.
Consider a pseudometric space $\struct {S, d}$ where $d: S \times S \to \R_{\ge 0}$ is a pseudometric.
Then $\struct {S, d}$ gives rise to a topological space $\struct {S, \tau_d}$ whose topology $\tau_d$ is '''defined''' (or '''induced''') by $d$.

86df47d0-152a-4f9a-8b58-34f69fba4349.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=72|body=If two medial areas incommensurable with one another be added together, the remaining two irrational straight lines arise, namely either a second bimedial or a side of the sum of two medial areas.}}

08f3f011-90dc-423b-8e45-315079efcb1c.text:
Let $G$ be a finite group.
Let $H$ be a normal subgroup of $G$ which has a finite index in $G$.
Let:
:$p^k \divides \index G H$
where:
:$p$ is a prime number
:$k \in \Z_{>0}$ is a (strictly) positive integer
:$\divides$ denotes divisibility.
Then $G$ contains a subgroup $K$ such that:
:$\index K H = p^k$

9a1b7eec-b3e3-4473-bcb4-a52b738618fd.text:
Let $\phi$ be the Euler $\phi$ function.
For any $\epsilon > 0$ and sufficiently large $n$:
:$n^{1 - \epsilon} < \map \phi n < n$

7883b3d1-218d-45ac-b45b-4625289ec7a4.text:
Let $\family {a_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an $I$-indexed family of positive real numbers.
That is, let $a_i \in \R_{\ge 0}$ for all $i \in I$.
Suppose that $\ds \sum \set {a_i: i \in I}$ converges.
Then the set $I_{>0} := \set {i \in I: a_i > 0}$ is countable.

0625dd06-b2d8-4d87-8cf0-5645120b2246.text:
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ and $\sequence {y_n}$ be sequences in $\R$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ and $\sequence {y_n}$ be convergent to the following limits:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = l$
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} y_n = m$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \frac {x_n} {y_n} = \frac l m$
provided that $m \ne 0$.
Some treatments of this subject specifically exclude all sequences where the denominators are zero at '''any''' point in their domain.
Thus, for example, this is how it is presented in {{BookReference|Complex Numbers|1960|Walter Ledermann}}:
:''If $z_n \to c$ and $w_m \to d$, then
::''... $\text{(iv)} \ z_n / w_n \to c / d$, where ... $w_n \ne 0$ for all $n$ and $d \ne 0$.''
However, it is demonstrated within the proof that past a certain $N \in \R$, which is bound to exist, $w_n$ is ''guaranteed'' to be non-zero.
The behaviour of the sequence $S = \sequence {\dfrac {z_n} {w_n} }$ in the limit is not dependent upon the existence or otherwise of its terms for $n < N$.
Thus it is not necessary to state that $w_n \ne 0$ for all $n$, and in fact such a statement would unnecessarily restrict the applicability of the theorem to exclude otherwise well-behaved cases where it is desirable that the theorem ''does'' apply.
Hence this restriction is not supported on {{ProofWiki}}.

da764af1-cb95-4355-b7db-aaec47495316.text:
The left operation is anticommutative:
:$\forall x, y: x \leftarrow y = y \leftarrow x \iff x = y$

8721d483-d7c2-4ba0-ac71-108aa80d55e3.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau_{_S} }$ be a topological space.
Let $\struct {R, +, *, \tau_{_R} }$ be a topological division ring.
Let $g: \struct {S, \tau_{_S} } \to \struct {R, \tau_{_R} }$ be a continuous mapping.
Let $U = S \setminus \set {x : \map g x = 0}$
Let $g^{-1}: U \to R$ be the mapping defined by:
:$\forall x \in U : \map {g^{-1} } x = \map g x^{-1}$
Let $\tau_{_U}$ be the subspace topology on $U$.
Then:
:$g^{-1}: \struct {U, \tau_{_U} } \to \struct {R, \tau_{_R} }$ is continuous.

66100c2f-2d8f-4f3b-a283-19d1c9732d9c.text: The integers $11$ and $26$ cannot be represented by the sum of less than $6$ hexagonal numbers.

554f7a2b-5095-4f59-97e3-8765eeb48e25.text:
Let $\mathbf A = \sqbrk a_n$ be a square matrix of order $n$.
Let $D = \map \det {\mathbf A}$ be the determinant of $\mathbf A$:
:$\ds \map \det {\mathbf A} := \sum_{\lambda} \paren {\map \sgn \lambda \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_{k \map \lambda k} } = \sum_\lambda \map \sgn \lambda a_{1 \map \lambda 1} a_{2 \map \lambda 2} \cdots a_{n \map \lambda n}$
where:
:the summation $\ds \sum_\lambda$ goes over all the $n!$ permutations of $\set {1, 2, \ldots, n}$
:$\map \sgn \lambda$ is the sign of the permutation $\lambda$.
Let $a_{p q}$ be an element of $\mathbf A$.
Let $A_{p q}$ be the cofactor of $a_{p q}$ in $D$.
Then:
:$(1): \quad \ds \forall r \in \closedint 1 n: D = \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_{r k} A_{r k}$
:$(2): \quad \ds \forall r \in \closedint 1 n: D = \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_{k r} A_{k r}$
Thus the value of a determinant can be found either by:
:multiplying all the elements in a row by their cofactors and adding up the products
or:
:multiplying all the elements in a column by their cofactors and adding up the products.
The identity:
:$\ds D = \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_{r k} A_{r k}$
is known as the '''expansion of $D$ in terms of row $r$''', while:
:$\ds D = \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_{k r} A_{k r}$
is known as the '''expansion of $D$ in terms of column $r$'''.
Let $\delta_{rs}$ be the Kronecker delta.
Then:
:$(1): \quad \ds \forall r \in \closedint 1 n: \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_{r k} A_{s k} = \delta_{r s} D$
:$(2): \quad \ds \forall r \in \closedint 1 n: \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_{k r} A_{k s} = \delta_{r s} D$
That is, if you multiply each element of a row or column by the cofactor of ''another'' row or column, the sum of those products is zero.

2ecc0c74-8522-4820-b442-a7aaf8aefec2.text:
Let $x$ be a real number.
Then:
:$\cosh x \ge 1$
where $\cosh$ denotes the hyperbolic cosine function.

d0ae4ee3-409e-46a5-ab1d-81751a635611.text:
Let $X^n$ be an $n$-dimensional manifold.
Let $U$ be a neighborhood of a point $p \in X^n$.
Then there exist local coordinates on $U$.

af604417-e4ab-4e36-a503-ac59800f4378.text:
Let $a \in \R_{\ne 0}$.
Then:
:$\ds \int \frac {\sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} } x \rd x = \sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} + \frac b 2 \int \frac {\d x} {\sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} } + c \int \frac {\d x} {x \sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} }$

55fd61ef-d46c-44f3-9ac5-bd339dfa93e2.text:
Let $\mathbf x = a \mathbf 1 + b \mathbf i + c \mathbf j + d \mathbf k$ be a quaternion.
Let $\size {\mathbf x}$ be the modulus of $\mathbf x$.
Let $\overline {\mathbf x}$ be the conjugate of $\mathbf x$.
Then:
:$\size {\mathbf x}^2 \mathbf 1 = \mathbf x \overline {\mathbf x}$

340953a0-559c-4661-8ade-30bc814c529e.text:
:$\forall n \in \Z: \ceiling x + n = \ceiling {x + n}$
where $\ceiling x$ denotes the ceiling of $x$.

c862737f-a093-4065-a147-3d0c6b21142e.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $e$ be the identity of $G$.
Then $e$ is in the center of $G$:
:$e \in \map Z G$

b6d8e1db-1c7b-4947-b36f-dfaa9abe1f73.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Let $x \in R$ be a proper zero divisor of $R$.
Then:
:$\paren {x \divides 0_R} \land \paren {x \circ y = 0_R} \land \paren {y \ne 0_R} \implies y \divides 0_R$
That is, if $x$ is a proper zero divisor, then whatever non-zero element you form the product with it by to get zero must itself be a zero divisor.

43c9c273-2725-446e-96d5-80d89a08b967.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a closed algebraic structure.
Let $\FF$ be a family of relations on $S$.
Let each element of $\FF$ be compatible with $\circ$.
Let $\QQ = \bigcup \FF$.
Then $Q$ is a relation compatible with $\circ$.

1d48e066-0309-4601-a88a-47d4c7729d76.text:
Let $\struct {\R, \tau}$ be the real number line considered asa  topological space with the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Then:
:$\Q$ is an $F_\sigma$ set in $\struct {\R, \tau}$.

a5b0a711-829c-4b69-869d-45e30d56fcbc.text:
$10$ is the only triangular number which is the sum of two consecutive odd squares:
:$10 = 1^2 + 3^2$

1616e378-5869-41c6-b37a-4463256a0c1e.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is:
:continuous on the closed interval $\closedint a b$
and:
:differentiable on the open interval $\openint a b$.
Let $\map f a = \map f b$.
Then:
:$\exists \xi \in \openint a b: \map {f'} \xi = 0$

aa0383a0-abb1-42e1-89b1-7df50c4f8a63.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be an abelian group.
Let the operation $*$ be defined on $G$ such that:
:$\forall x, y \in G: x * y = x \circ y^{-1}$
Then $\struct {G, *}$ is an entropic structure.

8753f012-ac4d-46d3-a3bf-b8603170f88d.text:
The complex exponential function is its own derivative.
That is:
:$\map {D_z} {\exp z} = \exp z$

b40eb4fe-a6af-4dee-91a0-aff0ba39487d.text:
Let $F_n$ denote the $n$th Fibonacci number.
Let $m$ be a non-negative integer.
Then:
:$F_{m n + 1} \equiv \paren {\begin{cases} F_1 & : m \bmod 4 = 0 \\
F_{n - 1} & : m \bmod 4 = 1 \\
\paren {-1}^n F_1 & : m \bmod 4 = 2 \\
\paren {-1}^n F_{n - 1} & : m \bmod 4 = 3 \end{cases} } \pmod {F_n}$

50ce9d40-2e3e-4524-8b10-2212573a6d41.text: A loop-digraph is the same thing as a relational structure.

cdfbb256-0014-4d7f-9904-a3dd3abb8eca.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ and $K$ be subgroups of $G$.
Let $K$ act on the left coset space $G / H^l$ by:
:$\forall \tuple {k, g H} \in K \times G / H^l: k * g H := \paren {k g} H$
The stabilizer of $g H$ is $K \cap H^g$, where $H^g$ denotes the $G$-conjugate of $H$ by $g$.

5a7bbedb-dcca-47e0-a9b2-6c82946c9546.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be an additive function.
Then:
:$\forall r \in \Q, x \in \R: \map f {x r} = r \map f x$

2550eba4-426b-404d-817d-7825c6f3b744.text:
Let $\mathbf u$ and $\mathbf v$ be vectors.
Consider a parallelogram, two of whose adjacent sides represent $\mathbf y$ and $\mathbf v$ (in magnitude and direction).
:400px
Then the diagonal of the parallelogram connecting the terminal points of $\mathbf u$ and $\mathbf v$ represents the magnitude and direction of $\mathbf u - \mathbf v$, the difference of $\mathbf u$ and $\mathbf v$.

d98f5b2f-b4f7-4516-aa94-9a8a97dd6893.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $\mathfrak A$ be an algebra of sets on $X$.
Then the following hold:
:$(1): \quad$ The intersection of two sets in $\mathfrak A$ is in $\mathfrak A$.
:$(2): \quad$ The difference of two sets in $\mathfrak A$ is in $\mathfrak A$.
:$(3): \quad$ $X \in \mathfrak A$.
:$(4): \quad$ The empty set $\O$ is in $\mathfrak A$.

8c6b55b2-c135-4041-b9bd-2c9a26ad1e1f.text:
Let:
: $\phi: \left({S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n}\right) \to \left({T, *_1, *_2, \ldots, *_n}\right)$
be a mapping from one algebraic structure:
: $\left({S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n}\right)$
to another:
: $\left({T, *_1, *_2, \ldots, *_n}\right)$
Let $\circ_k$ have the morphism property under $\phi$ for some operation $\circ_k$ in $\left({S, \circ_1, \circ_2, \ldots, \circ_n}\right)$.
Then if an element $a \in S$ is either left cancellable or right cancellable under $\circ_k$, then $\phi \left({a}\right)$ is correspondingly left cancellable or right cancellable under $*_k$.
Thus, the morphism property is seen to preserve cancellability.

600bd531-1d67-45d8-939f-852a143cbdbe.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $g: T \to S$ be a right inverse of $f$.
Then $g$ is an injection.

cd7b73ee-41a1-4951-bf80-6f932d5d36a8.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=38|body=If two medial straight lines commensurable in square only and containing a medial rectangle be added together, the whole is irrational; and let it be called a '''''second bimedial''''' straight line.}}

d1dda72b-2a79-4231-9856-4f8bbed85ed3.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $x \in S$.
Then $x$ is an isolated point of the singleton set $\set x$, but not necessarily an isolated point of $T$.

8f8c10f9-cb79-4cb8-adf4-b8136850690d.text:
A composite of surjections is a surjection.
That is:
:If $g$ and $f$ are surjections, then so is $g \circ f$.

9a9a347f-4efd-4530-ad54-80bf4a93daff.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $S$ be a singleton.
Then $f$ is an injection.

c02a1fb0-734e-4ecc-ab31-421e9f5419ae.text:
Let $A$ be a preadditive category.
Let $a_1, a_2$ be objects of $A$.
Let $(a_1 \times a_2, p_1, p_2)$ be their binary product, assuming it exists.
Let $i_1 : a_1 \to a_1 \times a_2$ be the unique morphism with:
:$p_1 \circ i_1 = 1 : a_1 \to a_1$
:$p_2 \circ i_1 = 0 : a_1 \to a_2$
Let $i_2 : a_1 \to a_1 \times a_2$ be the unique morphism with:
:$p_1 \circ i_2 = 0 : a_2 \to a_1$
:$p_2 \circ i_2 = 1 : a_2 \to a_2$
where $1$ is the identity morphism and $0$ is the zero morphism.
Then $(a_1 \times a_2, i_1, i_2, p_1, p_2)$ is the binary biproduct of $a_1$ and $a_2$.

a25f0469-fd3f-48e8-85cb-4123d126d6c2.text: The Cayley table for any finite group is a Latin square.

a3f78392-2bab-461a-9931-e8e30d7f6f8f.text:
Let $z \ne 0$ be a complex number with modulus $r$ and argument $\theta$.
Let $\sequence {z_n}$ be a sequence of nonzero complex numbers.
Let $r_n$ be the modulus of $z_n$ and $\theta_n$ be an argument of $z_n$.
Then $z_n$ converges to $z$ {{iff}} the following hold:
:$(1): \quad r_n$ converges to $r$
:$(2): \quad$ There exists a sequence $\sequence {k_n}$ of integers such that $\theta_n + 2 k_n \pi$ converges to $\theta$.

f54870c7-6afd-4ffa-873d-e9105ebe8745.text:
Let $a, q$ be coprime integers.
Let $\PP_{a, q}$ be the set of primes $p$ such that $p \equiv a \pmod q$.
Define:
:$\eta_{a, q} : n \mapsto \begin{cases}
1 & : n \equiv a \pmod q\\
0 & : \text{otherwise}
\end{cases}$
Let $G = \paren {\Z / q \Z}^\times$.
Let $G^*$ be the dual group of Dirichlet characters on $G$.
{{explain|Explain the notation $\paren {\Z / q \Z}^\times$}}
Then for all $n \in \N$:
:$\ds \map {\eta_{a, q} } n = \sum_{\chi \mathop \in G^*} \frac {\map {\overline \chi} a} {\map \phi q} \, \map \chi n$

cdc13941-b25c-434f-9b3b-5a17d44ba5ef.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $\struct {S', \preceq'}$ be an ordered subset of $L$.
Then $\struct {S', \preceq'}$ is an ordered set.

f085f1dc-8c2a-4f1f-843d-9bf3d528e2dc.text:
$\struct {\On, +, \le}$ forms an ordered semigroup, where:
:$\On$ denotes the ordinal class
:$+$ denotes ordinal addition.

25a96118-2ab3-4109-8c02-4f590117d1ff.text: :$\displaystyle \int \paren {\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} }^3 \rd x = \frac {x \paren {\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} }^3} 4 + \frac {3 a^2 x \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } 8 + \frac {3 a^4} 8 \arcsin \frac x a + C$

b8ada2b2-4cd0-4ff8-8b80-a4325cc8b9ee.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \times}$ be a ring.
Let $J \subseteq R$ be a left ideal of $R$.
Let $\circ : R \times J \to J$ be the restriction of $\times$ to $R \times J$.
Then $\struct {J, +, \circ}$ is a left module over $\struct {R, +, \times}$.

38d18fbe-23d2-4693-ac0d-925442c28508.text:
Let $\sequence {a_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ be a sequence in $\C$.
Suppose that there exists $B > 0$ such that for all $n, m \in \N$:
:$\ds \size {\sum_{k \mathop = m}^n a_n} \le B$
Then the Dirichlet series:
:$\ds \map f s = \sum_{n \mathop \ge 1} a_n n^{-s}$
converges locally uniformly to an analytic function on $\map \Re s > 0$.

49c89ca7-6bce-4ee3-92bd-b7690316f6ee.text:
Let $F$ be a field.
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $\struct {\map {\MM_F} n, +, \times}$ denote the ring of square matrices of order $n$ over $F$.
Then $\struct {\map {\MM_F} n, +, \times}$ is a ring with unity, but is not a commutative ring.

09a99868-8f22-4625-ac9c-d4ff1dd06f5b.text:
Let $(L, \wedge, \vee, \preceq)$ be a pseudocomplemented lattice.
Then $(L, \wedge, \vee, \preceq)$ is a bounded lattice.

1e4b9247-37f3-444a-8d34-8ce95b7ba49c.text:
Let $V$ be a vector space of dimension $n$.
Let $\BB = \set {\mathbf x_1, \mathbf x_2, \ldots, \mathbf x_n}$ be a basis for $V$.
Let $\mathbf x \in V$ be any vector of $V$.
Then $\mathbf x$ can be expressed as a unique linear combination of elements of $\BB$.
{{explain|The definition we have of linear combination doesn't really work for this. We probably need to expand that definition.}}

4730ef9e-101a-4467-9da6-3239932b2da8.text:
Let $A$ be a class.
Let $\mathrm U$ denote the universal class.
Let $f: A \to \mathrm U$ be a class mapping.
Let $S$ be a subset of $A$.
{{explain|Note that further work is needed on the Subset page to clarify that a "subset" of a "proper class" is indeed a "set". Some words are already on that page, but this needs to be formalised and separated out into its own transcluded "class theoretic" page.}}
Then the image $f \sqbrk S$ is also a set.
If $A$ is a set, then this result is known as the Axiom of Replacement in Zermelo-Fraenkel set theory.

dee73d8a-b862-444b-9427-360fe28fac44.text: There exists at least one example of a compact space for which none of the Tychonoff separation axioms are satisfied.

990a3da0-8746-47c5-b6d4-8a1ccefaa84a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_{\bar p} }$ be an excluded point space.
Then $T$ is a scattered space.

b6a799fe-315a-4504-a3d2-f58ec402b27e.text:
:$\ln 2 \ge \dfrac 1 2$
where $\ln$ denotes the natural logarithm function.

b46b9afd-9195-4b86-9264-2dd898ff515e.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a preordered set.
Let $A$ be a set of subsets of $S$ such that
:$\forall X \in A: X$ is filtered
and
:$\forall X, Y \in A: \exists Z \in A: X \cup Y \subseteq Z$
Then:
:$\bigcup A$ is also filtered.

f6e87005-7853-42fe-b9cb-02779edf7d6c.text:
Let $R$ be a division ring.
Let $\norm {\, \cdot \,}_1: R \to \R_{\ge 0}$ be a norm on $R$.
Let $\norm {\, \cdot \,}_1$ satisfy:
:$\forall x \in R, x \ne 0_R:\norm x_1 \ge 1$ 
Then:
:$\norm {\, \cdot \,}_1$ is the trivial norm.

d68f074d-2fde-43e1-b5df-33d12220249f.text:
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times T$ be a relation on a cartesian product $S \times T$.
Let:
:$I_S$ be the identity mapping on $S$
:$I_T$ be the identity mapping on $T$.
Let $\RR^{-1}$ be the inverse relation of $\RR$.
Let $\RR$ be such that:
:$\RR^{-1} \circ \RR = I_S$ and
:$\RR \circ \RR^{-1} = I_T$
where $\circ$ denotes composition of relations.
Then $\RR$ is a bijection.

badb2119-a14b-4e81-beac-53f3bee9ab66.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p$ be the p-adic norm on the rationals $\Q$.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
That is, $\Q_p$ is the quotient ring $\CC \, \big / \NN$ where:
:$\CC$ denotes the commutative ring of Cauchy sequences over $\struct {\Q, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$
:$\NN$ denotes the set of null sequences in $\struct {\Q, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$.
Then the field operations on $\Q_p$ are defined by:
:$+ : \quad \forall \sequence {x_n} + \NN, \sequence {y_n} + \NN \in \CC \, \big / \NN$:
:::$\quad \paren {\sequence {x_n} + \NN} + \paren {\sequence {y_n} + \NN} = \sequence {x_n + y_n} + \NN$
:$\circ : \quad \forall \sequence {x_n} + \NN, \sequence {y_n} + \NN \in \CC \, \big / \NN$: 
:::$\quad \paren {\sequence {x_n} + \NN} \paren {\sequence {y_n} + \NN} = \sequence {x_n y_n} + \NN$

3e0cf71f-9fe3-4ab7-b6ca-8f11cff8cc78.text:
Let $\AA$ be the set of all arithmetic functions.
Let $*$ denote Dirichlet convolution, and $+$ the pointwise sum of functions.
The ring of arithmetic functions $\struct {\AA, +, *}$ is a commutative ring with unity.

533d9da9-d2c8-4a33-b149-2cffb984d0ac.text:
:$\map s {0, n} = \delta_{0 n}$
where:
:$\map s {0, n}$ denotes a signed Stirling number of the first kind
:$\delta_{0 n}$ denotes the Kronecker delta.

29cf3e7e-0ac2-4235-809f-80c14168dcfb.text:
Let $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$ be a commutative ring.
Let $\struct{G, +_G, \circ}$ be a left module over $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$.
Let $\circ' : G \times R \to G$ be the binary operation defined by:
:$\forall \lambda \in R: \forall x \in G: x \circ' \lambda = \lambda \circ x$
Then $\struct{G, +_G, \circ, \circ'}$ is a bimodule over $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$.

0bf1738d-48a0-4788-b23c-eb04dc41acc2.text:
Let $\chi_0$ be the trivial Dirichlet character modulo $q$.
{{explain|Trivial character we got, Dirichlet character we got, we still need a page for trivial Dirichlet character. There exists on another page a link to Dirichlet Character/Trivial Character which ought to be straightforward to construct.}}
Let $\zeta$ be the Riemann zeta function.
Then:
:$\ds \map L {s, \chi_0} = \map \zeta s \cdot \prod_{p \mathop \divides q} \paren {1 - p^{-s} }$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.

83ffd338-3c1d-40c0-935d-608da0379f3d.text:
Let $n, k \in \Z_{\ge 0}$.
Let $k > n$.
Let $\ds {n \brace k}$ denote a Stirling number of the second kind.
Then:
:$\ds {n \brace k} = 0$

dc2f3a9e-5ed2-4c6a-b969-09d690386508.text:
Let $\mathbf P$ be a order category, and denote its ordering by $\preceq$.
Let $p \in \mathbf P_0$ be an object of $\mathbf P$.
Then:
:$\mathbf P \mathbin / p \cong p^\preceq$
where:
:$\mathbf P \mathbin / p$ is the slice of $\mathbf P$ over $p$
:$p^\preceq$ is the order category defined by the weak lower closure of $p$.

4bd2107e-2ad4-4d13-8adc-468e16b049d9.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times S$ be an antireflexive relation on $S$.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$.
Let $\RR {\restriction_T} \subseteq T \times T$ be the restriction of $\RR$ to $T$.
Then $\RR {\restriction_T}$ is an antireflexive relation on $T$.

0f15c75f-7ae0-473f-bf87-cdc2b2a27e15.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be an integral domain.
Let $K, L$ be field of quotients of $\struct {D, +, \circ}$.
Then there is one and only one (field) isomorphism $\phi: K \to L$ satisfying:
:$\forall x \in D: \map \phi x = x$

417f2d37-7af5-4d74-8662-7024f2f00fa1.text:
Let $x, y, z \in \R_{\ge 0}$ be positive real numbers.
Let $t \in \R, t > 0$ be a (strictly) positive real number.
Then:
:$x^t \paren {x - y} \paren {x - z} + y^t \paren {y - z} \paren {y - x} + z^t \paren {z - x} \paren {z - y} \ge 0$
The equality holds {{iff}} either:
: $x = y = z$
: Two of them are equal and the other is zero.
When $t$ is a positive even integer, the inequality holds for ''all'' real numbers $x, y, z$.

9d9c5811-5ed1-4cc6-b34b-12d8441f50d7.text:
Let $T_1$ be a compact space.
Let $T_2$ be a Hausdorff space.
Let $f: T_1 \to T_2$ be a continuous bijection.
Then $f$ is a homeomorphism.

4183cddc-9c74-43f5-ac1d-21b61f7f55f0.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $\Aut G$ denote the automorphism group of $G$.
Let $\phi: G \to \Aut G$ be the homomorphism defined as:
:$\forall g \in G: \map \phi g = \kappa_{g^{-1} }$
where $\kappa_{g^{-1} }$ denotes the inner automorphism of $G$ by $g^{-1}$.
Then $\phi$ can be decomposed into the form:
:$\phi = \alpha \beta \gamma$
in the following way:
:$\alpha: \Inn G \to \Aut G$ is defined as:
::$\forall \kappa \in \Inn G: \map \alpha \kappa = \kappa$
:where $\Inn G$ denotes the inner automorphism group of $G$
:$\beta: G / \map Z G \to \Inn G$ is defined as:
::$\forall g \in G / \map Z G: \map \phi g = \kappa_{g^{-1} }$
:where $G / \map Z G$ denotes the quotient group of $G$ by the center of $G$
:$\gamma: G \to G / \map Z G$ is defined as:
::$\forall g \in G: \map \gamma g = \map {q_{\map Z G} } g = g \, \map Z G$
:where $q_{\map Z G}$ is the quotient epimorphism from $G$ to $G / \map Z G$.

9c4a38be-03b4-45cd-8587-a9c4557c3f45.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $G$ be a group.
Let:
:$p^n \divides \order G$
where:
:$\order G$ denotes the order of $G$
:$n$ is a positive integer.
Then $G$ has at least one subgroup of order $p$.

f6dc202e-4bf9-418a-8374-17bc8a1ca12e.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer such that $n > 33$.
Then $n$ can be expressed as the sum of $5$ non-zero squares.

ed1beb6a-d900-4dc4-a631-aa793167e5ad.text: The magic constant of the order $3$ magic square is $15$.

11deaee5-0c48-47ec-9e18-1a0b6f5eb424.text:
Let $\ds \map f x := \sum_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty a_n \paren {x - \xi}^n$ be a power series about a point $\xi$.
Let $R$ be the radius of convergence of $S$.
Then:
:$\ds \int_a^b \map f x \rd x = \sum_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty \int_a^b a_n x^n \rd x = \sum_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty a_n \frac {x^{n + 1} } {n + 1}$

ff7b152e-5e5f-4d9a-a7a6-265fbc175a30.text:
Let $x, y \in \R$ be real numbers.
Let $\exp x$ be the exponential of $x$.
Then:
:$\map \exp {x y} = \paren {\exp y}^x$

d42ed208-9a4d-4e88-b289-927111bb22b0.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq_S}$ and $\struct {T, \preceq_T}$ be well-ordered sets.
Then precisely one of the following hold:
:$\struct {S, \preceq_S}$ is order isomorphic to $\struct {T, \preceq_T}$
or:
:$\struct {S, \preceq_S}$ is order isomorphic to an initial segment in $\struct {T, \preceq_T}$
or:
:$\struct {T, \preceq_T}$ is order isomorphic to an initial segment in $\struct {S, \preceq_S}$

21e7f823-511d-4c92-a857-03c4ae210f29.text:
A recurrence relation for the square numbers is:
:$S_n = S_{n - 1} + 2 n - 1$

d1af328e-9c67-4731-9db1-9b84ebdf6c4c.text:
Let $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$ be a ring.
Let $\struct {G, +, \circ}_R$ be the cartesian product of a sequence $\sequence {\struct {G_n, +_n, \circ_n}_R}$ of $R$-modules.
Then for each $j \in \closedint 1 n$, the canonical injection $\inj_j$ from $\struct {G_j, +_j, \circ_j}_R$ into $\struct {G, +, \circ}_R$ is a monomorphism.

b7e6040d-15ca-4a93-8f14-e0fca73e0dbe.text:
Let $P = \left({X, \subseteq}\right)$ be an inclusion ordered set.
Let $A, B \in X$ such that
:$A \cup B \in X$
Then $A \vee B = A \cup B$

fad0175e-ddec-4f46-b244-08358c63025e.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=42|body=A binomial straight line is divided into its terms at one point only.}}

ace1cc02-2d3e-4f27-8457-a2ee3f54ce27.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ be ordered sets.
Let $\preccurlyeq_l$ be the lexicographic order on $S_1 \times S_2$''':
:$\tuple {x_1, x_2} \preccurlyeq_l \tuple {y_1, y_2} \iff \paren {x_1 \prec_1 y_1} \lor \paren {x_1 = y_1 \land x_2 \preccurlyeq_2 y_2}$
Then $\preccurlyeq_l$ is an ordering on $S_1 \times S_2$.

b90d9143-2ba2-4148-b2dc-e4ec5402e7c8.text:
Let $T_A = \struct {S_A, \tau_A}$ and $T_B = \struct {S_B, \tau_B}$ be topological spaces.
Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a continuous surjection.
If $T_A$ has one of the following properties, then $T_B$ has the same property:
:Compact Space
:$\sigma$-Compact Space
:Countable Compact Space
:Sequential Compact Space
:Lindelöf Space

0a635f7d-4726-4bfe-bf47-2190662be844.text:
Let $n$ be a finite ordinal.
Let $x$ be a transfinite ordinal.
Then:
: $n + x = x$

ed3b3b57-0a3a-4653-be89-ef4d9c08a0b1.text:
Let $T_\R = \struct {\R, \tau_\R}$ be the (uncountable) discrete space on the set of real numbers.
Let $T_D = \struct {D, \tau_D}$ be the indiscrete topology on the doubleton $D = \set {a, b}$.
Let $T = T_\R \times T_D$ be the double pointed (uncountable) discrete space which is the product space of $T_\R$ and $T_D$.
Then $T$ is weakly countably compact.

8e0daf99-0a83-4fa1-ac75-0ea49f24af2e.text:
Let $a \in \R_{>0}$ be a strictly positive real constant.
Let $\size x > a$.
Then:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {a^2 - x^2} = \dfrac 1 {2 a} \map \ln {\dfrac {x + a} {x - a} } + C$

e205b873-32d6-46d9-a321-9b9a1d1510a4.text: :$R \setminus S = R \setminus T \iff R \cap S = R \cap T$

be2b373e-0743-4388-bafa-3e29400c1475.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\epsilon \in \R_{>0}$ be a Lebesgue number for $M$.
Let $\epsilon' \in \R_{>0}: \epsilon' < \epsilon$.
Then $\epsilon'$ is also a Lebesgue number for $M$.

699761ee-071a-4295-bc0d-3a5c49fe383a.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a complete lattice.
Let $f: S \to S$ be an increasing mapping.
Let $P = \struct {M, \precsim}$ be an ordered subset of $L$ such that
:$M = \set {x \in S: x = \map f x}$
Then $P$ is complete lattice.

455787a7-38e3-4046-87d5-73a216456547.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Let $A, B$ be subsets of $T$.
Let $A$ and $B$ are separated.
Then:
:$\map \partial {A \cup B} = \partial A \cup \partial B$
where:
:$\partial A$ denotes the boundary of $A$
:$A \cup B$ denotes the union of $A$ and $B$.

6ff87eed-53ab-499d-a621-b45e6debae3f.text:
Let $\RR$ be an ordering on a set $S$.
Let $\RR^\ne$ be the reflexive reduction of $\RR$.
Then $\RR^\ne$ is a strict ordering on $S$.

2629439f-44d8-4255-aa87-0c036d08bbac.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a well-ordered set.
Let $\max \set {x, y}$ denote the max operation on $x, y \in S$.
Then $\struct {S, \max}$ is a monoid.
Its identity element is the smallest element of $S$.

8275e572-d0b4-4109-9176-e81e18f62385.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be an idempotent ring.
Denote with $0_R$ the zero of $R$.
Then $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ is a commutative ring.

cf76c892-484e-4dfb-b066-6a9848519acd.text:
Let $F_k$ be the $k$'th Fibonacci number.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{j \mathop = 1}^{2 n - 1} F_j F_{j + 1} = {F_{2 n} }^2$

620979d9-dd40-48e8-b41a-99fecfda3b1d.text:
Let $\struct {G, \oplus}$ be an abelian group.
Let $\mathbb G$ be the set of all group endomorphisms of $\struct {G, \oplus}$.
Let $\struct {\mathbb G, \oplus, *}$ denote the '''ring of endomorphisms''' on $\struct {G, \oplus}$.
Then $\struct {\mathbb G, \oplus, *}$ is not necessarily a commutative ring with unity.

649145be-7c82-4a2f-b6c2-304d2d06cfa5.text:
Let $z = \polar {r, \theta}$ be a complex number expressed in polar form.
Let $z$ be represented on the complex plane $\C$ in vector form.
The effect of multiplying $z$ by $e^{i \alpha}$ is to rotate it about the origin of $\C$ by $\alpha$ in the positive direction

f353dbbe-440f-4cf6-af56-10d633776aef.text:
Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Let $W$ be a non-empty subset of $\R$.
Then $R_W$ is Lindelöf
where $R_W$ denotes the topological subspace of $R$ on $W$.

795cde36-a72c-4f32-ac30-0a52c05eff7d.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let $*: G \times G / H \to G / H$ be the action on the (left) coset space:
:$\forall g \in G, \forall g' H \in G / H: g * \paren {g' H} := \paren {g g'} H$
Then $G$ is a transitive group action.

28078e3c-180d-4f19-b130-9e4dc9db1f6a.text:
If $S$ is a finite subset of a group $G$, then:
:$\card {a \circ S} = \card S = \left|{S \circ a}\right|$
That is, $a \circ S$, $S$ and $S \circ a$ are equivalent: $a \circ S \sim S \sim S \circ a$.

26c7f870-02d2-4955-ac16-7f700d3e88d8.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $\family {T_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of subsets of $T$.
Then:
:$\ds S \setminus \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} T_i = \bigcap_{i \mathop \in I} \paren {S \setminus T_i}$
where:
:$\ds \bigcap_{i \mathop \in I} T_i := \set {x: \forall i \in I: x \in T_i}$
that is, the intersection of $\family {T_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$.

af6329f6-0b26-4fea-b5b7-e74bb8919251.text:
Let $\struct {S, \vee, \wedge, 
eg}$ be a Boolean algebra.
Then for all $a, b \in S$:
:$
eg \paren {a \vee b} = 
eg a \wedge 
eg b$
:$
eg \paren {a \wedge b} = 
eg a \vee 
eg b$

d81c24e1-e265-41a6-8110-b850def64c41.text:
Let $\ds \struct {S, \circ} = \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n S_k$ be the external direct product of the algebraic structures $\struct {S_1, \circ_1}, \struct {S_2, \circ_2}, \ldots, \struct {S_n, \circ_n}$.
If $\circ_1, \ldots, \circ_n$ are all associative, then so is $\circ$.

4e138428-b3d3-4347-b325-fa727985b10f.text:
Let $
orm {\,\cdot\,}_p$ be the $p$-adic norm on the rationals $\Q$ for some prime $p$.
The induced valuation ideal on $\struct {\Q,
orm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ is the set:
:$\PP = p \Z_{\ideal p} = \set {\dfrac a b \in \Q : p 
mid b, p \divides a}$
where $\Z_{\ideal p}$ is the induced valuation ring on $\struct {\Q,
orm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$

317b4508-9937-4365-9ee2-738d8a4ca014.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\sin^2 a x} = \frac {-\cot a x} a + C$

11103f78-a87f-4319-92de-3482cc60d9a7.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $f, g: S \to S$ be idempotent mappings from $S$ to $S$.
Let:
:$f \circ g = g \circ f$
where $\circ$ denotes composition.
Then $f \circ g$ is idempotent.

d0ac7127-6a38-4c00-8f0c-00bdcbf12970.text:
Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers.
Let $i$ be the imaginary unit.
Then:
:$\tan \paren {a + b i} = \dfrac {\tan a - \tan a \tanh ^2 b} {1 + \tan ^2 a \tanh ^2 b} + \dfrac {\tanh b + \tan ^2 a \tanh b} {1 + \tan ^2 a \tanh ^2 b} i$
where:
:$\tan$ denotes the tangent function (real and complex)
:$\tanh$ denotes the hyperbolic tangent function.

a273df3f-2b24-497f-a29f-644e9eaaca73.text: The smallest pair of quasiamicable numbers is $48$ and $75$.

21516459-8139-441e-9cf4-13a715f3d8a5.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $f: S \to S$ be a mapping on $S$.
Then $f$ is an involution {{iff}} $f$ is both a bijection and a symmetric relation.

653b3f1c-8ec2-491e-9d63-f83edf9b8c5d.text:
Let $\left({S, \preccurlyeq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$.
Let $\preccurlyeq \restriction_T$ be the restricted ordering on $T$.
Then for all $t \in T$:
:$t^{\preccurlyeq T} = T \cap t^{\preccurlyeq S}$
where:
:$t^{\preccurlyeq T}$ is the weak lower closure of $t$ in $\left({T, \preccurlyeq \restriction_T}\right)$
:$t^{\preccurlyeq S}$ is the weak lower closure of $t$ in $\left({S, \preccurlyeq}\right)$.

9709081a-a3db-4d8d-ac0a-0cc2e6348fde.text:
Let $I \subseteq \R$ be a real interval.
Let $f, g : I \to \R$ be absolutely continuous functions.
Then $f + g$ is absolutely continuous.

7383bd75-43c3-46bb-b86b-d71207842355.text:
Let Schanuel's Conjecture be true.
Then $\pi \times e$ is transcendental.

3e2ff139-57b0-4edc-8464-71b850324efd.text:
Let $f: S \to \C$ be a complex function.
Let $z_0$ be a limit point of $S$.
Suppose that $\ds \lim_{z \mathop \to z_0} \map f z = L$.
Then that limit $L$ is unique.

e260fb16-7498-4f97-8a96-4d7c83fa1883.text:
Let $N$ be a class which is closed under a progressing mapping $g$.
Let $b$ be an element of $N$ such that $N$ is minimally closed under $g$ with respect to $b$.
For all $x, y \in N$:
:either $\map g x \subseteq y$ or $y \subseteq x$
and $N$ forms a nest:
:$\forall x, y \in N: x \subseteq y$ or $y \subseteq x$

50ea793e-3818-46ac-9f9a-b2ba30a151f1.text:
Let $\struct {\C_{\ne 0}, \times}$ be the group of non-zero complex numbers under multiplication.
Let $\struct {\R_{> 0}, \times}$ be the group of positive real numbers under multiplication.
Let $\struct {K, \times}$ be the circle group.
Then:
:$\struct {\C_{\ne 0}, \times} \cong \struct {\R_{> 0}, \times} \times \struct {K, \times}$
{{explain|It is apparent that the second $\times$ is Cartesian product, but this is not obvious.}}

4459ed2d-c9c7-47c9-9505-5b82fac0523f.text:
Let $\mathbf C$ be a morphisms-only metacategory.
Then $\mathbf C$ induces a metacategory $\mathbf C'$, as follows (phrased to fit with Characterization of Metacategory via Equations):
:Define $\mathbf C'_1$ to be the collection $\mathbf C_1$ of morphisms of $\mathbf C$.
:Define $\mathbf C'_0$ to be the image of the operation $\operatorname{dom}$ on $\mathbf C_1$.
:Define $\operatorname{id}$ to be the identity on $\mathbf C'_0$, and take $\operatorname{dom}$ and $\operatorname{cod}$ as in $\mathbf C$.
:Define $\circ$ to be as in $\mathbf C$; i.e., $g \circ f$ is the unique element of $\mathbf C_1$ with $R_\circ \left({g, f, g \circ f}\right)$.

e5894317-4433-4ed6-92b9-5f426a5dd141.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Then the topology $\tau$ induced by the metric $d$ is a topology on $M$.

5836c71d-2165-4154-aef1-7f1a6d8e5513.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Then:
:$S \times T = T \times S \iff S = T \lor S = \O \lor T = \O$
where $S \times T$ denotes the cartesian product of $S$ and $T$.

437a765a-9757-4120-9724-aa1db00bb551.text:
Let $\map \BB {S, \tau}$ be a Borel $\sigma$-algebra generated by the set of open sets in $S$.
Then $\map \BB {S, \tau}$ is equivalently generated by the set of closed sets in $S$.

f1c96dbe-6c94-40f4-9600-9ce93e4f70ac.text:
Let $H$ be a Hilbert space.
Let $K$ be a closed linear subspace of $H$.
Let $P_K$ denote the orthogonal projection on $K$.
Then $P_K$ has: 
:$P_K \circ P_K = P_K$

83b5f574-a36e-4bc4-b05c-554d9e6ce282.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Let $T_*$ be the set of all lower bounds of $T$ in $S$.
Then $T_* \cap T \ne \O$ {{iff}}:
:$T$ has a smallest element $m$
and
:$T_* \cap T$ is a singleton such that $T_* \cap T = \set m$

32bcc05b-01cb-4412-b2df-ef9a2e3f5a55.text:
:$\dfrac {\d \mathrm S} {\d x} = \sqrt {\dfrac 2 \pi} \sin x^2$
where $\mathrm S$ denotes the Fresnel sine integral function.

fd0a2632-d993-4e9f-b8c3-bfa67d822f6a.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \preceq}$ be an up-complete ordered set.
Let $x \in S$.
Then $x^\preceq$ is closed under directed suprema,
where $x^\preceq$ denotes the lower closure of $x$.

20df1353-93b8-4355-bbe6-15d302c5915b.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=11|body=If four magnitudes be proportional, and the first be commensurable with the second, the third will also be commensurable with the fourth; and, if the first be incommensurable with the second, the third will also be incommensurable with the fourth.}}

6a02ad01-8981-41cd-af79-525d4fb55ef5.text:
Let $a, b \in \R$ such that $\forall \epsilon \in \R_{>0}: a - \epsilon < b < a + \epsilon$.
Then $a = b$.

6e7bb2ed-29f0-4179-8aa5-be08a1cca243.text:
Let $u$ be a differentiable real function of $x$.
Then:
:$\map {\dfrac \d {\d x} } {\artanh u} = \dfrac 1 {1 - u^2} \dfrac {\d u} {\d x}$ 
where $\size u < 1$
where $\tanh^{-1}$ is the real area hyperbolic tangent.

6523d72d-2b76-45d7-ab4e-6cca48c75abb.text:
:$\map {\laptrans {e^{b t} \sin a t} } s = \dfrac a {\paren {s - b}^2 + a^2}$
where:
:$a$ and $b$ are real numbers
:$s$ is a complex number with $\map \Re s > a + b$
:$\laptrans f$ denotes the Laplace transform of $f$ evaluated at $s$.

27ed9f43-440e-481d-a76c-53dbe79e1a6e.text:
Let $\RR$ be a binary relation on a non-empty set $S$.
For each $a \in S$, let $C_a = \set {b \in S: a \mathrel \RR b }$
Suppose that:
:For all $a \in S$, $C_a$ is a non-empty finite set.
Let $s \in S$.
Then there exists a sequence $\sequence {x_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ in $S$ such that:
:$x_0 = s$
:$\forall n \in \N: x_n \mathrel \RR x_{n+1}$

2a51fb12-430d-4fad-b517-332b852c46b9.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \preceq}\right)$ be a join semilattice.
Let $x \in S$ such that
:$x^{\mathrm{compact} }$ is a non-empty set,
where $x^{\mathrm{compact} }$ denotes the compact closure of $x$.
Then :$x^{\mathrm{compact} }$ is directed.

8e01977c-de37-40f8-91ea-67c8a301ce74.text:
Let $\struct {\R, \tau}$ denote the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Define an equivalence relation $\sim$ by letting $x \sim y$ {{iff}} either:
:$x = y$
or:
:$x, y \in \Q$
Let $\struct {\R / {\sim}, \tau_\sim}$ be the quotient space of $\R$ by $\sim$.
Then $\struct {\R / {\sim}, \tau_\sim}$ is a Kolmogorov space but not a Fréchet space.

4e8f20e8-36bc-4c3e-91a6-5b8d0a23f24e.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping to an arbitrary set $T$.
Let $\RR$ be a relation on $T$ defined such that:
:$\RR: = \set {\tuple {\map f x, \map f y}: x \preccurlyeq y}$
That is, $a$ is related to $b$ in $T$ {{iff}} they have preimages $x$ and $y$ under $f$ such that $x$ precedes $y$.
Then $\RR$ is transitive.

2b5af6c0-78f3-4ef4-ba1c-a8288433872c.text:
:$\map \Gamma 0$ is not defined.
where $\Gamma$ denotes the Gamma function.

0b7637d8-1f04-4957-a24e-02ad37f386c9.text:
Let $\mathbf{Set}$ be the category of sets.
Then the empty set $\O$ is an initial object of $\mathbf{Set}$.

4cde9d52-46d9-4049-b7b9-d2b6a8a6a75a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space which is second-countable.
Let $T_H = \struct {H, \tau_H}$, where $\O \subset H \subseteq S$, be a subspace of $T$.
Then $T_H$ is second-countable.

6bbb669d-d99b-4518-badc-f37f19f33eb3.text:
Let $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$ be a ring.
Let $\struct{G, +_G, \circ}$ be a right module over $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$.
Let $\circ' : R \times G \to G$ be the binary operation defined by:
:$\forall \lambda \in R: \forall x \in G: \lambda \circ' x = x \circ \lambda$
Then $\struct{G, +_G, \circ'}$ is not necessarily a left module over $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$

72d4e9be-8b03-483a-918f-b7bfb0b84114.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\PP$ be a partition of $S$.
Let $\tau$ be the set of subsets of $S$ defined as:
:$a \in \tau \iff a$ is the union of sets of $\PP$
Then $\tau$ is a topology on $S$.

f2185062-5357-4b97-92cc-44916589775f.text:
Let $\gen g = G$ be a cyclic group.
Let $a \in G$
Then it is not necessarily the case that $a$ is also a generator of $G$.

d91c6d7e-47a8-464a-983f-3d4472fe13e4.text:
Let $f$ be a holomorphic function on a simply connected domain $V \subseteq \mathbb C$.
Let $\gamma$ be a contour in $V$ starting at $z_1$ and ending at $z_2$.
Let $U$ be a connected domain.
Let $\phi: U \to V$ be a holomorphic function with $\phi^{-1} \sqbrk {\set {z_1, z_2} } \ne \O$.
Let $\omega$ be a contour in $U$ starting at $u_1$ and ending at $u_2$, such that $\map \phi {u_1} = z_1$ and $\map \phi {u_2} = z_2$.
Then the contour integral of $f$ over $\gamma$ satisfies the following substitution:
:$\displaystyle \int_\gamma \map f z \rd z = \int_\omega \map f {\map \phi u} \, \map {\phi'} u \rd u$

6e404083-d26b-404a-be4b-13850489cd72.text:
Let $C$ be a directed smooth curve in $\C$.
Let $C$ be parameterized by the smooth path $\gamma: \left[{a \,.\,.\, b}\right] \to \C$.
Define $\psi: \left[{a \,.\,.\, b}\right] \to \left[{a \,.\,.\, b}\right]$ by $\psi \left({t}\right) = a + b - t$.
Define $\rho: \left[{a \,.\,.\, b}\right] \to \C$ by $\rho = \gamma \circ \psi$.
Then $\rho$ is a smooth path which parameterizes a directed smooth curve $-C$.
The directed smooth curve $-C$ is independent of the parameterization $\gamma$.

469450ad-9f58-4e25-a1f6-9a8da49e7ecc.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=61|body=The square on the first bimedial straight line applied to a rational straight line produces as breadth the second binomial.}}

c7eb013a-569d-455d-b94e-d91509d71ff8.text:
Let $k$ be a field.
Let $n\geq1$ be a natural number.
Let $A = k \left[{X_1, \ldots, X_n}\right]$ be the ring of polynomial functions in $n$ variables over $k$.
Let $T \subseteq A$ be a subset, and $V \left({T}\right)$ the zero locus of $T$.
Let $J = \left({T}\right)$ be the ideal generated by $T$.
Then:
: $V \left({T}\right) = V \left({J}\right)$

cbcc6bc3-669e-45e5-b846-9a25b9cb1ba2.text:
Let $\R^3$ be the real Euclidean $3$-space considered as a metric space under the usual metric.
Let $x = \tuple {x_1, x_2, x_3} \in \R^3$ be a point in $\R^3$.
Let $\map {B_\epsilon} x$ be the open $\epsilon$-ball at $x$.
Then $\map {B_\epsilon} x$ is the interior of the sphere whose center is $x$ and whose radius is $\epsilon$.

1c438790-450b-4b26-afcf-91f80d1f0413.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \preceq, \tau}\right)$ be a transitive relational structure with lower topology.
Let $A \subseteq S$ such that
:$A$ is closed.
Then $A$ is upper.

7735db3a-5e7b-435b-a083-6245e092bce4.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $\sequence {X_i: i \in \N}$ be an exhausting sequence of sets on $X$.
For each $i \in \N$, let $g_i: X_i \to Y$ be a mapping such that:
:$g_{i + 1} \restriction X_i = g_i$
where $g_{i + 1} \restriction X_i$ denotes the restriction of $g_{i + 1}$ to $g_i$.
Then:
:$\ds \bigcup \set {g_i: i \in \N}$
is a mapping from $X$ to $Y$.
For each $i \in \N$, let $g_i : X_i \to Y$ be invertible.
Then $\ds \bigcup \set {g_i: i \in \N}$ is invertible and:
:$\ds \paren {\bigcup \set {g_i: i \in \N} }^{-1} = \bigcup \set {g_i^{-1}: i \in \N}$

5f9ebf03-858d-4483-8c65-5daca60f9e39.text:
Let $\cos: \C \to \C$ be the complex cosine function. 
Then $\cos$ is entire.

21a93951-3153-4def-8f16-b5282901982f.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $M$ be a free $R$-module with basis $B$.
Let $S$ be a generating set for $M$.
Then:
:$\size B \le \size S$.
That is, there exists an injection from $B$ to $S$.

389d1ce6-0b0a-4510-bbc3-ead34f06b6fd.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be finite sets.
Let $\card S = m, \card T = n$.
Let $C$ be the number of surjections from $S$ to $T$.
Then:
:$C = n! \ds {m \brace n}$
where $\ds {m \brace n}$ denotes a Stirling number of the second kind.

c179b693-3bc3-4152-8ba8-d099e2702ad4.text:
Let $S, T \ne \O$.
Then:
:$S \times T = T \times S \implies S = T$

85837154-d055-47a4-8018-9c03524cc616.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_{a, b} }$ be a modified Fort space.
Then $T$ is a compact space.

f4136bd5-2d60-4db4-83ea-af88d744f6ae.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $A \subseteq S$ be a subset of $T$.
By successive applications of the operations of complement relative to $S$ and the closure, there can be no more than $14$ distinct subsets of $S$ (including $A$ itself).

cabb6de1-405a-4162-a45a-0ad4b4e94e5c.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Then its center $\map Z G$ is characteristic in $G$.

ad04938a-c293-45f9-ad83-6798d9d2c9b1.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a complete lattice.
Let $X, Y$ be subsets of $S$ such that
:$X$ is finer than $Y$.
Then $\sup X \preceq \sup Y$
where $\sup X$ denotes the supremum of $X$.

0ec1f785-5ce2-4499-a258-9f4daa13ed5e.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a monoid.
Let $x \in S$ be invertible, and let its inverse be $x^{-1}$.
Then $x^{-1}$ is also invertible, and:
:$\paren {x^{-1} }^{-1} = x$

18257f59-ab15-4cab-81ad-34056a050e48.text:
Let $x, y, z$ be ordinals.
Then:
: $(1): x \le y \implies \left({z + x}\right) \le \left({z + y}\right)$
: $(2): x \le y \implies \left({x + z}\right) \le \left({y + z}\right)$

81fa8397-8168-44a2-bb4c-3b56280a6b61.text:
Let $C$ be a curve defined by a real function which is twice differentiable.
Let the curvature of $C$ be non-constant.
Let $P$ be a point on $C$.
Let $Q$ be the center of curvature of $C$ at $P$.
The normal to $C$ at $P$ is tangent to the evolute $E$ of $C$ at $Q$.

1075741a-fddb-46c3-9dfd-8c5370994685.text:
