Let $\HH$ be a Hilbert space over $\Bbb F \in \set {\R, \C}$.
Let $A \in \map B \HH$ be a normal operator.
Let $\lambda \in \Bbb F$.
Then $\map \ker {A - \lambda}$ is a reducing subspace for $A$.
Here $\ker$ denotes kernel.

73c1a60a-8b81-4aa8-ab11-de759424b70f.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Then there exists at least one positive integer $n$ greater than $1$ such that:
:$n^{p - 1} \equiv 1 \pmod {p^2}$

9a3008f2-124e-41d4-87d5-3e524948799d.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=VIII|prop=5|body=Plane numbers have to one another the ratio compounded of the ratios of their sides.}}

6d2776a6-4014-48c7-9ddc-f60d943f151f.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the Arens-Fort space.
Then $T$ is a scattered space.

8a3651f8-b558-44b4-98ec-f16e4b51d973.text:
Let $n \in \N_{> 0}$ be a natural number greater than $0$.
Let $S$ be a set of cardinality $n$.
Let $S_n$ denote the symmetric group on $S$ of order $n$.
Let $R_e$ and $R_o$ denote the subsets of $S_n$ consisting of even permutations and odd permutations respectively.
Then the cardinality of both $R_e$ and $R_o$ is $\dfrac {n!} 2$.

1b7d1aaa-1f84-41e5-b33c-7c7874cc89f9.text:
Let $\struct {\Z, +}$ be the additive group of integers.
Let $\struct {\R, +}$ be the additive group of real numbers.
Then $\struct {\Z, +}$ is a normal subgroup of $\struct {\R, +}$.

5bf0d2a0-bfb9-4253-a3b2-9f3620773a3d.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Let $\mathbb L$ be a non-empty set of subrings of $R$.
Then the intersection $\ds \bigcap \mathbb L$ of the members of $\mathbb L$ is itself a subring of $R$.

27e6ccf6-bcab-4eb5-a9ed-f69d9a531315.text:
:$\ds \sum_k \paren {-1}^k \dbinom n k \dbinom {r - k t} n \dfrac r {r - k t} = \delta_{n 0}$
where $\delta_{n 0}$ is the Kronecker delta.

3d1697b5-c71d-49fd-9e26-073af8ed49b5.text:
Let $\left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a complete lattice.
Let $\left({T, \vee_2, \wedge_2, \precsim}\right)$ be a continuous complete lattice.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping such that
:$\forall x \in S: f\left({x}\right) = \sup \left\{ {f\left({w}\right): w \in S \land w \ll x}\right\}$
Let $x \in S, y \in T$.
Then
:$y \ll f\left({x}\right) \iff \exists w \in S: w \ll x \land y \ll f\left({w}\right)$

33fd9065-7daf-4d36-b4e8-77b120485a3a.text:
Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Let $\struct {\Q, \tau_d}$ be the rational number space under the same topology.
Then:
:$\Q^- = \R$
where $\Q^-$ denotes the closure of $\Q$.

25000786-8f72-4fa5-8332-5ded97fb92a3.text:
:$\cosh^2 x = \dfrac {\cosh 2 x + 1} 2$
where $\cosh$ denotes hyperbolic cosine.

4e7f607b-6a59-46c8-873e-3db476ee27b7.text:
Let $\left({S,\preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $x_0, x_1, \dots, x_n \in S$.
Suppose that for $k = 0, 1, \dots, n - 1: x_k \preceq x_{k+1}$.
Suppose also that $x_n \preceq x_0$.
Then $x_0 = x_1 = \dots = x_n$.

5760a8a1-96e8-4d0b-aad2-b7ff66e6a2fd.text:
Let $x \in \R_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive real number.
Let $r \in \R$ be a real number.
Then:
:$x^r > 0$
where $x^r$ denotes the $x$ to the power of $r$.

253f4957-6388-4e4e-ac79-a379a57268b7.text:
:$\sin \alpha \cos \beta = \dfrac {\map \sin {\alpha + \beta} + \map \sin {\alpha - \beta} } 2$
where $\sin$ denotes sine and $\cos$ denotes cosine.

68df31af-4675-43c6-a19c-9f2cdab3cbb6.text: :$\ds \int e^{a x} \cos^{n - 1} b x \sin b x \rd x = \frac {e^{a x} \cos^{n - 1} b x \paren {a \sin b x - b \cos b x} } {a^2 + n b^2} - \frac {\paren {n - 1} a b} {a^2 + n b^2} \paren {\int e^{a x} \cos^n b x \rd x - \int e^{a x} \cos^{n - 2} b x \rd x} + C$

2d458dac-c628-42e9-ad15-eddf99005a20.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $g: S \to \Img f$ be the restriction of $f$ to $S \times \Img f$.
Then $g$ is a surjective restriction of $f$.

08c18808-3078-453c-827d-bf62956445b9.text:
Let $\struct {\Z_{16}, +}$ denote the additive group of integers modulo $16$.
Let $\struct {\Z'_{17}, \times}$ denote the multiplicative group of reduced residues modulo $17$.
Let $\phi: \struct {\Z_{16}, +} \to \struct {\Z'_{17}, \times}$ be the mapping defined as:
:$\forall \eqclass k {16} \in \struct {\Z_{16}, +}: \map \phi {\eqclass k {16} } = \eqclass {3^k} {17}$
Then $\phi$ is a group isomorphism.

5e3e1cce-da5a-44d9-a6f9-2fc4b88b69f7.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space which is topologically complete.
Let $H \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$.
Let $\struct {H, \tau_H}$ be the topological subspace of $T$ induced by $H$.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $\struct {H, \tau_H}$ is also topologically complete.
That is, topological completeness is not hereditary.

c830882c-952d-433f-88cd-ac48e2bbee81.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer.
Then:
:$n \divides n$
That is, $n$ divides itself.

deabdf63-42f7-435c-bcde-dff1cb8cf339.text:
Let $\mathbf A = \sqbrk a_n$ be a square matrix of order $n$.
Let $D = \map \det {\mathbf A}$ be the determinant of $\mathbf A$.
Let $a_{p q}$ be an element of $\mathbf A$.
Let $A_{p q}$ be the cofactor of $a_{p q}$ in $D$.
Let $\delta_{rs}$ be the Kronecker delta.
Then:
:$(1): \quad \ds \forall r \in \closedint 1 n: \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_{r k} A_{s k} = \delta_{r s} D$
:$(2): \quad \ds \forall r \in \closedint 1 n: \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n a_{k r} A_{k s} = \delta_{r s} D$
That is, if you multiply each element of a row or column by the cofactor of ''another'' row or column, the sum of those products is zero.

6ba3997d-6792-4c7a-bb01-92b503a10c01.text:
The roots of the equation:
:$z^6 + 1 = \sqrt 3 i$
are:
:$\set {\sqrt [6] 2 \cis 20 \degrees, \sqrt [6] 2 \cis 80 \degrees, \sqrt [6] 2 \cis 140 \degrees, \sqrt [6] 2 \cis 200 \degrees, \sqrt [6] 2 \cis 260 \degrees, \sqrt [6] 2 \cis 320 \degrees}$

f76c04e8-0958-49ae-93ad-8eb7702a11e7.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $U$ and $V$ be convex sets in $S$.
Let $U \cap V \ne \O$.
Then $U \cup V$ is also convex.

86c4d808-8e97-4111-8b9b-f211c7a50dce.text:
Let $x$ be a real number.
Then the ceiling function of $x$ is an integer:
:$\ceiling x \in \Z$

aea483aa-d47f-4b3c-af13-73d09c25f130.text:
Let $\struct {F, +, \times}$ be a field whose zero is $0$.
Let $\struct {K, +, \times}$ be a subfield of $\struct {F, +, \times}$.
The zero of $\struct {K, +, \times}$ is also $0$.

a38d67a9-5ab4-4252-bdc7-e57ef0a2d680.text:
Let $\EE$ be an experiment with a probability space $\struct {\Omega, \Sigma, \Pr}$.
Let $\Omega$ be a finite set.
Then the event space $\Sigma$ consists of an even number of subsets of $\Omega$.

97e73fb0-293d-4418-89f8-1419dc32acdf.text:
Let $G \left({z}\right)$ be the generating function for the sequence $\left\langle{a_n}\right\rangle$.
Let $c$ be a constant.
Then $G \left({c z}\right)$ be the generating function for the sequence $\left\langle{b_n}\right\rangle$ where:
:$\forall n \in \Z_{\ge 0}: b_n = c^n a_n$

0e20e117-ca5e-4a42-9c8f-72b4d78f73de.text:
Let $x$ and $y$ be real numbers.
Let $x \bmod y$ denote the modulo operation.
Then $\ds \lim_{y \mathop \to 0} x \bmod y = 0$.

864fc3d0-af97-495a-b224-c92475948d5e.text: The set of quaternions $\H$, with the operations of addition and multiplication, forms a vector space.

3d224545-6158-4f1b-81cf-18632bf0dd28.text:
Let $\Gamma$ be a limit ordinal.
Let $\hointr 0 \Gamma$ denote the open ordinal space on $\Gamma$.
Consider the compact subspace $\hointr 0 \Gamma$.
Then $\hointr 0 \Gamma$ is not compact in $\closedint 0 \Gamma$.

7770ab97-3438-4d7f-9e8e-bbada5f90a44.text:
Let $\family {\struct {X_i, \tau_i} }_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of topological spaces where $I$ is an arbitrary index set.
Let $\ds \struct {X, \tau} = \prod_{i \mathop \in I} \struct {X_i, \tau_i}$ be the product space of $\family {\struct {X_i, \tau_i} }_{i \mathop \in I}$.
For all $k \in I$, let $\pr_k$ denote the projection from $X$ to $X_k$.
Let $z \in X$.
Let $i, k \in I$. 
Let $Y_i = \set {x \in X: \forall j \in I \setminus \set i: x_j = z_j}$.
Let $p_i = \pr_i {\restriction_{Y_i} }$ be the restriction of $\pr_i$ to $Y_i$.
Let $V_k \in \tau_k$.
Let $\map {\pr_k^\gets } {V_k} \cap Y_i \ne \O$.
Then:
:$\map {p_i^\to} {\map {\pr_k^\gets} {V_k} \cap Y_i}$ is open in $\struct{X_i, \tau_i}$

529830d9-6015-4f47-9712-238c2e22ff52.text:
:$\ds \int \cosh^2 x \rd x = \frac {\sinh x \cosh x + x} 2 + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

3fcfab47-ebc5-441f-a530-f5ef48f62571.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $C$ be a chain in $S$.
Let $m$ be a minimal element of $C$.
Then $m$ is the smallest element of $C$.

7c4a44c0-113c-4199-8cbd-8e9046d84d33.text:
Let $\struct {E, +_E, \times_E}$ and $\struct {F, +_F, \times_F}$ be fields.
Let $\phi: E \to F$ be a (field) homomorphism.
Then $\phi$ is either an injection or the trivial homomorphism.

e39c50ca-2d9d-4000-b3ed-371071a253e1.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is continuous on the closed interval $\closedint a b$.
Then $f$ is Darboux integrable on $\closedint a b$.

c41e36e5-9837-4d2b-bb22-466b59f15dd8.text:
Let $\floor x$ denote the floor function.
Then:
:$\floor x + \floor y \le \floor {x + y}$
The equality holds:
:$\floor x + \floor y = \floor {x + y}$
{{iff}}:
:$x \bmod 1 + y \bmod 1 < 1$
where $x \bmod 1$ denotes the modulo operation.

c6c423d5-77bf-4c0e-bd5e-84d0d7556af9.text: The following definitions of a balanced prime are equivalent:

f7902003-03d9-4703-b3d0-46f6c49a9cf1.text:
Let $X$ be a set, and let $\Sigma$ be a $\sigma$-algebra on $X$.
Then $\Sigma$ is a Dynkin system on $X$.

26178d88-724e-434d-95c1-78015b728727.text:
Let $T = \struct {\R, \tau}$ be the Sorgenfrey line.
Then $\map w T = \mathfrak c$
where
:$\map w T$ denotes the weight of $T$
:$\mathfrak c$ denotes continuum, the cardinality of real numbers.

971e9c2e-8bf7-4a5c-b89a-39abbc4b3ca0.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $a$ and $b$ be integers such that:
: $p \divides a b$
where $\divides$ means '''is a divisor of'''.
Then $p \divides a$ or $p \divides b$.
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\ds n = \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^r a_i$.
Then if $p$ divides $n$, it follows that $p$ divides $a_i$ for some $i$ such that $1 \le i \le r$.
That is:
:$p \divides a_1 a_2 \ldots a_n \implies p \divides a_1 \lor p \divides a_2 \lor \cdots \lor p \divides a_n$
Let $p, p_1, p_2, \ldots, p_n$ be primes such that:
:$p \divides \ds \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^n p_i$
Then:
:$\exists i \in \closedint 1 n: p = p_i$

0fa34c45-af68-4336-80e2-3957ae0030ec.text: A basis expansion of an irrational number never terminates and does not recur.

a6e164b1-2216-4eb2-af11-c282149487b3.text: :$\ds \int \paren {\arcsin \frac x a}^2 \rd x = x \paren {\arcsin \frac x a}^2 - 2 x + 2 \sqrt{a^2 - x^2} \arcsin \frac x a + C$

70029ffd-30c8-446f-ac0f-e9742334dca5.text:
Let $\ln: \R_{>0}$ denote the real natural logarithm.
Then:
:$\ds \forall x \in \R_{>0}: \ln x = \lim_{h \mathop \to 0} \frac {x^h - 1} h$

0912313a-0872-4006-8495-0d87b69dcded.text:
Let $G$ be a finite group.
Let $H$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Then $G$ is solvable {{iff}}:
:$(1): \quad H$ is solvable
and
:$(2): \quad G / H$ is solvable
where $G / H$ is the quotient group of $G$ by $H$.

38302fa2-ba54-45fc-bb6c-882d04ff9ea0.text:
Let a circle $C_1$ of radius $b$ roll without slipping around the inside of a circle $C_2$ of (larger) radius $a$.
Let $C_2$ be embedded in a cartesian plane with its center $O$ located at the origin.
Let $P$ be a point on the circumference of $C_1$.
Let $C_1$ be initially positioned so that $P$ is its point of tangency to $C_2$, located at point $A = \tuple {a, 0}$ on the $x$-axis.
Let $H$ be the hypocycloid traced out by the point $P$.
Let $\tuple {x, y}$ be the coordinates of $P$ as it travels over the plane.
The point $P = \tuple {x, y}$ is described by the equations:
:$x = \paren {a - b} \cos \theta + b \map \cos {\paren {\dfrac {a - b} b} \theta}$
:$y = \paren {a - b} \sin \theta - b \map \sin {\paren {\dfrac {a - b} b} \theta}$

6fde0316-20e7-473f-881e-9fe32e382527.text:
If a subset of one set is equivalent to the other, and a subset of the other is equivalent to the first, then the two sets are themselves equivalent:
:$\forall S, T: T \sim S_1 \subseteq S \land S \sim T_1 \subseteq T \implies S \sim T$

d86c6446-27c9-4de7-be8d-59a3f004fca0.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let:
:$\FF \subseteq \powerset S$ be a set of subsets of $S$
where $\powerset S$ denotes the power set of $S$.
Then:
:$\ds \bigcup_{A \mathop \in \FF} A' \subseteq \paren {\bigcup_{A \mathop \in \FF} A}'$
where $A'$ denotes the derivative of $A$.

692c28af-2f92-477b-bbe3-d13a1a951989.text: A mapping that is strictly monotone is a monotone mapping.

655a9a66-8c25-49ea-9e4e-3079c344f783.text:
An integer $N$ expressed in decimal notation is divisible by $4$ {{iff}} the $2$ least significant digits of $N$ form a $2$-digit integer divisible by $4$.
That is:
:$N = \sqbrk {a_n \ldots a_2 a_1 a_0}_{10} = a_0 + a_1 10 + a_2 10^2 + \cdots + a_n 10^n$ is divisible by $4$ 
{{iff}}:
:$10 a_1 + a_0$ is divisible by $4$.

e1e033b0-f95e-4321-b528-6910159e0da6.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $B$ be the binary representation of $n$.
Let $r$ be the number of unit digits in $B$.
Let $n!$ denote the factorial of $n$.
Then $2^{n - r}$ is a divisor of $n!$, but $2^{n - r + 1}$ is not.

252ec163-1ec7-48d7-b1d4-e2d8265d0948.text:
The following ordered quadruple of consecutive integers have divisor sums which are strictly decreasing:
:$44, 45, 46, 47$
:$104, 105, 106, 107$

f66a8b7d-ec53-415a-931e-e67278b9c17e.text:
Let $\struct {G, \cdot}$ be a group.
Then there exists a permutation group $P$ on some set $S$ such that:
:$G \cong P$
That is, such that $G$ is isomorphic to $P$.
'''Cayley's Representation Theorem''' is also known as the '''Representation Theorem for Groups'''.
Some present it as the '''Cayley's representation theorem'''.
Some sources refer to it as just '''Cayley's theorem''', but as there is more than one result so named, it is better to use the more specific form.
{{Namedfor|Arthur Cayley}}

9e56cc99-0942-4d5e-844a-699977dec2d3.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let $x, y \in G$.
Let $H x$ denote the right coset of $H$ by $x$.
Then:
:$H x = H y \iff x \in H y$

896a4b35-f6c7-4136-9100-246e2f1eab40.text:
Let $\struct {X, d}$ and $\struct {Y, d'}$ be metric spaces. 
Let $\map \CC {X, Y}$ be the set of continuous functions $X \to Y$.
Let $\FF \subset \map \CC {X, Y}$ be a set of Lipschiz continuous functions all with Lipschitz constant $M \ge 0$.
Then $\FF$ is uniformly equicontinuous.

ab514f4c-cffc-4b00-9fb7-0b4fe71a442c.text:
For $i \in \set {1, 2}$, let $\RR_i \subseteq S_i \times T_i$ be relations on $S_i \times T_i$.
Let ${\RR_i}^{-1} \subseteq T_i \times S_i$ be the inverse of $\RR_i$.
Then:
:${\RR_1}^{-1} \cup {\RR_2}^{-1} = \paren {\RR_1 \cup \RR_2}^{-1}$

6f4c9cf0-601d-4731-be76-828faa76e72c.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let $S \subseteq G$ be a right transversal for $H$ in $G$.
Let $T$ be the set defined as:
:$T := \set {x^{-1}: x \in S}$
where $x^{-1}$ is the inverse of $x$ in $G$.
Then $T$ is a left transversal for $H$ in $G$.

868bda33-ddba-4d53-880d-93fd54fd7ed8.text:
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $\R$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be convergent.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ is a Cauchy sequence.

2aa800d9-e6e6-44d4-a393-695b42b1a9fa.text: A cube number can be expressed as the difference between two squares.

b6c5b3e0-a3e9-4317-8925-49654b1d6a9b.text:
:$\map \tan {a + b} = \dfrac {\tan a + \tan b} {1 - \tan a \tan b}$
where $\tan$ is tangent.

57b801fd-cf8d-44f1-bf0a-ea4dee2d9724.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau_{_S} }$ be a topological space.
Let $\struct {R, +, *, \tau_{_R} }$ be a topological division ring.
Let $\lambda \in R$.
Let $f: \struct {S, \tau_{_S} } \to \struct {R, \tau_{_R} }$ be a continuous mapping.
Let $\lambda + f : S \to R$ be the mapping defined by:
:$\forall x \in S: \map {\paren {\lambda + f} } x = \lambda + \map f x$
Then 
:$\lambda + f: \struct {S, \tau_{_S} } \to \struct {R, \tau_{_R} }$ is continuous.

7e655d8e-a357-4f1f-8d99-f2e3c2ebd3d4.text:
Let $\EE$ be an affine space with difference space $V$ over a field $k$.
Let $\RR = \left({p_0, e_1, \ldots, e_n}\right)$ be an affine frame in $\EE$.
Define a mapping $\Theta_\RR : k^n \to \EE$ by:
:$\ds \map {\Theta_\RR} {\lambda_1, \ldots, \lambda_n} = p_0 + \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n \lambda_i e_i$
Then $\Theta_\RR$ is a bijection.

ca9b934d-ccf4-466a-a332-12fc0b361350.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a $T_1$ (Fréchet) topological space.
Let $H \subseteq S$ be connected in $T$.
If $H$ has more than one element, then $H$ is dense-in-itself.

26576a25-9312-48af-b415-3568c5724c82.text:
Let $A \subseteq \R$ be the set of all points on $\R$ defined as:
:$A := \set 0 \cup \set {\dfrac 1 n : n \in \Z_{>0} }$
Let $\struct {A, \tau_d}$ be the integer reciprocal space with zero under the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Then $A$ is not locally connected.

3d5d9ea4-09f4-4b00-a0e1-2f4981299e0f.text: There exists a set of real numbers which is not Lebesgue measurable.

49b9cd68-c869-40b1-b1da-ca8a3ebafc64.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let the cardinality of $S$ be $n$.
Let $F$ be the set of restrictions of $f$ to a subset of $S$.
Then there are $2^n$ elements of $F$.

89c656e0-6309-4fc1-8b9c-21180ccb0068.text: :$\ds \int \frac 1 {x^2} \artanh \dfrac x a \rd x = -\frac 1 x \artanh \dfrac x a + \frac 1 {2 a} \map \ln {\frac {x^2} {a^2 - x^2} } + C$

93e46504-01ca-41bb-8cdb-89d21a5cd6da.text:
Let $p, a \in \Z$.
If $p$ is a prime number then:
:$p \nmid a \implies p \perp a$
where:
:$p \nmid a$ denotes that $p$ does not divide $a$
:$p \perp a$ denotes that $p$ and $a$ are coprime.
It follows directly that if $p$ and $q$ are primes, then:
:$p \divides q \implies p = q$
:$p \ne q \implies p \perp q$
{{EuclidPropStatement|book=VII|prop=29|body=Any prime number is prime to any number which it does not measure.}}

068c18a8-25e5-4196-80ef-1931b4c637d4.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Let $T$ have a smallest element $m$.
Then $m$ is the infimum of $T$ in $S$.

149bb98d-c79e-41a0-933c-4ae3e1e21b7d.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}, M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}, \ldots, M_n = \struct {A_n, d_n}$ be metric spaces.
Let $\ds \AA = \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^n A_i$ be the cartesian product of $A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n$.
Let $d_\infty: \AA \times \AA \to \R$ be the Chebyshev distance on $\AA$:
:$\ds \map {d_\infty} {x, y} = \max_{i \mathop = 1}^n \set {\map {d_i} {x_i, y_i} }$
where $x = \tuple {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n}, y = \tuple {y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_n} \in \AA$.
For $i \in \set {1, 2, \ldots, n}$, let $U_i$ be open in $M_i$.
Then $\ds \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^n U_i$ is open in $M = \struct {\AA, d_\infty}$.

1030c91b-b003-479d-b417-b7316e8c3226.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be an additive function.
Then $f$ is an odd function.

83cf383b-d772-4b13-a4c4-a51d608eea51.text:
Let $\HH$ be a Hilbert space.
Let $A \subseteq \HH$ be a closed linear subspace of $\HH$.
Then:
:$\paren {A^\perp}^\perp = A$

1d07f32c-58b1-4176-b734-9192030ca926.text:
Let $K$ be a field.
{{TFAE|def = Irreducible Polynomial}}

5da41210-bf75-4eaf-817d-0f08ae7d61f2.text: The union of two symmetric relations is also a symmetric relation.

abda086e-c178-4a97-b4f0-4255bc2af40c.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ be a measurable space.
Let $f: X \to \overline \R$ be a bounded $\Sigma$-measurable function.
Then there exists a sequence $\sequence {f_n}_{n \mathop \in \N} \in \map \EE \Sigma$ of simple functions, such that:
:$\forall \epsilon > 0: \exists n \in \N: \forall x \in X: \size {\map f x - \map {f_n} x} < \epsilon$
That is, such that $\ds f = \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} f_n$ uniformly.
The sequence $\sequence {f_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ may furthermore be taken to satisfy:
:$\forall n \in \N: \size {f_n} \le \size f$
where $\size f$ denotes the absolute value of $f$.

e716d30e-b281-4a4a-be67-b967f96d8a22.text:
Let $S$ be a transitive set.
Then its successor set $S\,^+ = S \cup \left\{{S}\right\}$ is also transitive.

8b358dbe-bcdc-4a65-92d5-26931d84bbff.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the either-or space.
Then $T$ is a compact space.

f76a6654-edbd-4467-a5e3-99d65c69c820.text:
Let $\struct {S, \vee, \preceq}$ be a join semilattice.
Let $p, q, u \in S$ be such that:
:$p \prec q$ and $\paren {\forall s \in S: p \prec s \implies q \preceq s}$ and $u \npreceq p$
Then:
:$p \vee u = q \vee u$

17ef0baa-b7fd-4748-9f08-4ef20562d64f.text: The dihedral group $D_4$ is not an internal group product of any $2$ of its proper subgroups.

59b60a8d-f7d8-4ed5-a3f7-f5749ba89773.text:
Let $\nu: \O \to \O$ be an empty mapping.
Then $\nu$ is a bijection.

4186ff5c-d6c7-4137-9028-2fa316644126.text:
Let $A$ and $B$ be sets of real numbers.
Let $A$ and $B$ both be bounded below.
Then:
:$\map \inf {A \cup B} = \min \set {\inf A, \inf B}$
where $\inf$ denotes the infimum.

62de80c0-89f4-4e1d-b0c9-a0d0aea4388e.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $r \in R$ be a unit in $R$.
Let $r \, \mathbf I_n$ be the $n \times n$ rescaling matrix of $r$.
Then:
:$\paren {r \, \mathbf I_n}^{-1} = r^{-1} \, \mathbf I_n$

14dfaa52-9b02-40e0-9575-2de7a1724c05.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\AA$ be the Cartesian product $A \times A$.
Let $d_1$ be the taxicab metric on $\AA$:
:$\ds \map {d_1} {x, y} = \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n \map {d_{i'} } {x_{i'}, y_{i'} }$
for $x = \tuple {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n}, y = \tuple {y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_n} \in \AA$.
Then $d_1: \AA \to \AA$ is a continuous function.

cdeadb38-dbde-4db6-b767-466e031cb74e.text:
Let $r \in \R$.
Let $\mathbb P^-$ be the set of prime numbers with possibly finitely many numbers removed.
Define:
:$M = \min \set {m \in \N: \ds \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^m \frac {p_i} {p_i - 1} > r}$
where $p_i$ is the $i$th element of $\mathbb P^-$, ordered by size.
Then $M$ satisfies:
:$(1): \quad$ Every number formed with fewer than $M$ distinct prime factors in $\mathbb P^-$ has abundancy index less than $r$
:$(2): \quad$ There exists some number formed with $M$ distinct prime factors in $\mathbb P^-$ with abundancy index at least $r$
So $M$ is the minimal number of distinct prime factors in $\mathbb P^-$ a number must have for it to have abundancy index at least $r$.
For $r$ an integer greater than $1$:
If $\mathbb P^-$ is taken to be the set of all prime numbers, the values of $M$ are:
:$2, 3, 4, 6, 9, 14, 22, 35, 55, 89, 142, \cdots$
{{OEIS|A005579}}
This theorem shows that this sequence is a subsequence of the sequence A256969 in the OEIS, only differing by an offset.
If we require the numbers to be odd, we remove $2$ from $\mathbb P^-$.
The sequence of values of $M$ are:
:$3, 8, 21, 54, 141, 372, 995, 2697, 7397, 20502, \cdots$
{{OEIS|A005580}}

464d8b50-45a6-448e-885c-f0fdf483608d.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $a,b \in S$.
Then:
:$a^\prec \cap b^\prec = \left({\min \left({a, b}\right)}\right)^\prec$
where:
: $a^\prec$ denotes strict lower closure of $a$
: $\min$ denotes the min operation.

3dec9db4-05a8-4a9b-8e0c-1602228f2c5e.text:
Let $\struct {K, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Let $\mathbb K$ be the set of all ideals of $K$.
Then $\struct {\mathbb K, \subseteq}$ is a complete lattice.

e698a5fd-2d67-4b7d-a5e7-baf3df0befb6.text:
Let $\alpha$ denote the relation defined on the natural numbers $\N$ by:
:$\forall x, y \in \N: x \mathrel \alpha y \iff \exists n \in \Z: x = 2^n y$
Then $\alpha$ is an equivalence relation.

5cde0b28-acf6-4c9f-a49b-92e8fa376a26.text:
The composition of mappings is an associative binary operation:
:$\paren {f_3 \circ f_2} \circ f_1 = f_3 \circ \paren {f_2 \circ f_1}$
where $f_1, f_2, f_3$ are arbitrary mappings which fulfil the conditions for the relevant compositions to be defined.

d52e2d4f-24ba-4be0-9197-fb1d89654b1e.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $a, b \in S$, and let $T \subseteq S$.
Then the following phrases about, and concepts pertaining to $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ are dual to one another:
:{| style="text-align:center"
| $b \preceq a$
| width = "20px" |
| $a \preceq b$
|-
| $a$ succeeds $b$
|
| $a$ precedes $b$
|-
| $a$ strictly succeeds $b$
|
| $a$ strictly precedes $b$
|-
| $a$ is an upper bound for $T$
|
| $a$ is a lower bound for $T$
|-
| $a$ is a supremum for $T$
|
| $a$ is an infimum for $T$
|-
| $a$ is a maximal element of $T$
|
| $a$ is a minimal element of $T$
|-
| $a$ is the greatest element
|
| $a$ is the smallest element
|-
| the weak lower closure $a^\preceq$ of $a$
|
| the weak upper closure $a^\succeq$ of $a$
|-
| the strict lower closure $a^\prec$ of $a$
|
| the strict upper closure $a^\succ$ of $a$
|-
| the strict lower closure $T^\prec$ of $T$
|
| the strict upper closure $T^\succ$ of $T$
|-
| the join $a \vee b$ of $a$ and $b$
|
| the meet $a \wedge b$ of $a$ and $b$
|-
| $T$ is a lower set in $S$
|
| $T$ is an upper set in $S$
|}

42fe8a31-950f-4b59-9f37-9451443374f3.text:
Let $n$ be an even perfect number such that $n \ne 6$.
Then:
:$\ds n = \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^m \paren {2 k - 1}^3 = 1^3 + 3^3 + \cdots + \paren {2 m - 1}^3$
for some $m \in \Z_{>0}$.
That is, every even perfect number is the sum of the sequence of the first $r$ odd cubes, for some $r$.

6c4d2744-4f18-41bf-92bf-9e5ab739fa11.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \odot}$ be a ringoid such that $\struct {R, \odot}$ is a commutative semigroup.
Let $n \in \Z: n \ge 2$.
Then:
:$\ds \forall x, y \in R: \odot^n \paren {x + y} = \odot^n x + \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^{n - 1} \binom n k \paren {\odot^{n - k} x} \odot \paren {\odot^k y} + \odot^n y$
where $\dbinom n k = \dfrac {n!} {k! \ \paren {n - k}!}$ (see Binomial Coefficient).
If $\struct {R, \odot}$ has an identity element $e$, then:
:$\ds \forall x, y \in R: \odot^n \paren {x + y} = \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^n \binom n k \paren {\odot^{n - k} x} \odot \paren {\odot^k y}$

10caa708-7bec-4ec1-9eaf-1e19067a858a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a commutative semigroup
Let all the elements of $\struct {S, \circ}$ be cancellable.
Then an inverse completion of $\struct {S, \circ}$ is an abelian group.

a8e4a23e-6dbc-497a-9f27-b8aefcd6d3e6.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \set {\O, S} }$ be an indiscrete topological space.
Let $H \subset S$ (that is, let $H$ be a proper subset of $T$).
Then:
:$H^\circ = H^{\circ -} = H^{\circ - \circ} = \O$
where:
:$H^\circ$ denotes the interior of $H$
:$H^-$ denotes the closure of $H$.

69792e6a-751a-4383-81eb-2bbc7af4767a.text: The following axiom schemata for the definition of a finite group are logically equivalent:

49ea4157-e712-4c8d-b505-13698e8561da.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a topological space.
Let $P = \left({\tau, \subseteq}\right)$ be an inclusion ordered set of $\tau$.
Then $P$ is bounded above and $\top_P = S$
where $\top_P$ denotes the greatest element in $P$.

0d698b33-3048-4954-a2a1-ca58d50d2c4c.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \preceq}$ be a bounded below algebraic join semilattice.
Let $C = \struct {\map K L, \preceq'}$ be an ordered subset of $L$
where $\map K L$ denotes the compact subset of $L$.
Let $I = \struct {\map {\mathit {Ids} } C, \precsim}$ be an inclusion ordered set
where $\map {\mathit {Ids} } C$ denotes the set of all ideals in $C$.
Let $f: S \to \map {\mathit {Ids} } C$ be a mapping such that
:$\forall x \in S: \map f x = x^{\mathrm {compact} }$
where $x^{\mathrm {compact} }$ denotes the compact closure of $x$.
Thus $f$ is order isomorphism between $L$ and $I$.

81bc281e-883d-43e6-9277-f9ea5be11f06.text:
Let $C$ be a curve in the cartesian plane described by the equation $y = \map f x$.
Let $s$ be the length along the arc of the curve from some reference point $P$.
Then the derivative of $s$ with respect to $x$ is given by:
:$\dfrac {\d s} {\d x} = \sqrt {1 + \paren {\dfrac {\d y} {\d x} }^2}$

8f666e67-d661-4ed8-9188-92f89736354c.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $x, y \in S$ such that
:$x$ is maximal in $S \setminus y^\succeq$
Then $x^\succeq \setminus \left\{ {x}\right\} = x^\succeq \cap y^\succeq$

6bd427aa-044c-4249-98c7-fae330f0a2e3.text:
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ and $\sequence {y_n}$ be sequences in $\R$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ and $\sequence {y_n}$ be convergent to the following limits:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = l$
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} y_n = m$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \min \set {x_n, y_n} = \min \set {l, m}$

a5a44525-a331-4b3e-9b46-fe2b1cce4935.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_{\bar p} }$ be a countable excluded point space.
Then $T$ is a second-countable space.

8a84dca3-d8aa-4e6b-84e4-043495aa2a96.text:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^2 + a^2} = -\frac 1 a \arccot \frac x a + C$
where $a$ is a non-zero constant.

b518b2f4-efeb-48d1-b103-a6888811612f.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a Cauchy sequence in $R$.
Then $\sequence {\norm {x_n} }$ has a limit in $\R$.
That is,
:$\exists l \in \R: \ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \norm {x_n} = l$

5df2574c-b693-43e3-bad2-46a84d73a3db.text:
Let $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$ be a ring.
Let $\struct {G_1, +_1, \circ_1}_R, \struct {G_2, +_2, \circ_2}_R, \ldots, \struct {G_n, +_n, \circ_n}_R$ be unitary $R$-modules.
Let:
:$\ds G = \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n G_k$
be their direct product.
Then $G$ is a unitary module.

798018bf-7e6a-401c-b47e-bb8b42f4214c.text:
:$\sin x + \cos x = \sqrt 2 \, \map \cos {x - \dfrac \pi 4}$
where $\sin$ denotes sine and $\cos$ denotes cosine.

e1c71358-f72e-4b77-9733-432fe058ce4d.text:
Let $\tau_{\mathbf t}: \R^2 \to \R^2$ denote the translation of the Euclidean plane by the vector $\mathbf t = \begin {pmatrix} a \\ b \end {pmatrix}$.
Let $d_1$ denote the taxicab metric on $\R^2$.
Then $d_1$ is unchanged by application of $\tau$:
:$\forall x, y \in \R^2: \map {d_1} {\map \tau x, \map \tau y} = \map {d_1} {x, y}$

dfcab3f8-ffad-4d20-9a0a-3d68ab61964f.text:
For all $z, w \in \C$ such that it is not the case that $z$ is a negative integer and $t, w$ integers:
:$\dbinom z w = \dfrac {\map \sin {\pi \paren {w - z - 1} } } {\map \sin {\pi z} } \dbinom {w - z - 1} w$
where $\dbinom z w$ is a binomial coefficient.

efe0e979-3ed8-41ce-90ee-fe5b45c85731.text:
Composition of relations is, in general, not commutative:
That is, it is usually the case that:
:$\RR_1 \circ \RR_2 \ne \RR_2 \circ \RR_1$
for relations $\RR_1$ and $\RR_2$.

3df5c248-2cf3-4c49-8a6b-be1ea7e6f829.text:
Let $p$ and $q$ be prime numbers such that $p \ne q$.
Let $G$ be a group of order $p^2 q$.
Then $G$ is not simple.

3dabd3d9-3b8a-4b89-b4cb-6aa231fd8bf3.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\csc x$ be the cosecant of $x$.
Then, whenever $\csc x$ is defined:
:$\map \csc {-x} = -\csc x$
That is, the cosecant function is odd.

23bad16d-1054-449d-b47f-ff6e6c6f4d94.text:
Let $X$ be a topological space.
Let $Y\subset X$ be an irreducible subspace.
Then there exists an irreducible component of $X$ containing $Y$.

f439b06f-a7e4-4a2f-bbbb-189fb57132f7.text:
Let $\mathbb A$ be one of the standard number systems $\N, \Z, \Q, \R, \C$.
Let $S$ be a finite set.
Let $f: S \to \mathbb A$ be a mapping.
Let $\lambda \in \mathbb A$.
Let $g = \lambda \cdot f$ be the product of $f$ with $\lambda$.
Then we have the equality of summations on finite sets:
:$\ds \sum_{s \mathop \in S} \map g s = \lambda \cdot \sum_{s \mathop \in S} \map f s$

bc030759-129b-4828-ac7e-211e18e65255.text:
Let $R$ be a ring.
Let $\struct {G, +}$ be an abelian group..
Let $\struct {G, +, \circ}_R$ be an $R$-module.
Let $\struct {\map {\LL_R} G, +, \circ}$ be the ring of linear operators on $G$, where:
:$+$ denotes pointwise addition
:$\circ$ denotes composition of linear operators.
Then $\struct {\map {\LL_R} G, +, \circ}$ is a ring.

700cd610-2737-4204-ae30-6b1a558a305d.text:
Let $F$ be a mapping satisfying the following properties:
:$(1): \quad$ The domain of $F$ is $\On$, the ordinal class
:$(2): \quad$ For all ordinals $x$, $\map F x = \map G {F \restriction x}$
:$(3): \quad$ For all ordinals $x$, $\map G {F \restriction x} \in \paren {A \setminus \Img x}$ where $\Img x$ is the image of $x$ under $F$.
Let $\Img F$ denote the image of $F$.
Then the following properties hold:
:$(1): \quad \Img F \subseteq A$
:$(2): \quad F$ is injective
:$(3): \quad A$ is a proper class.
Note that only the third property of $F$ is the most important.
For any function $G$, a function $F$ can be constructed satisfying the first two using transfinite recursion.
{{explain|Exactly which of the above statements is the "third" is unclear. This statement needs to be made precise. It also needs to be explained. Also, it needs to be put in a separate section as it is peripheral to the statement of the theorem.}}

13d8a54a-9c06-4917-bf47-a1e7f0827d65.text:
Let $\struct {G_1, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {G_2, \circ_2}$ be groups.
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be the group direct product of $\struct {G_1, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {G_2, \circ_2}$.
Let $\pr_1$ denote the first projection of $\struct {G, \circ}$:
:$\forall \tuple {x, y} \in G: \map \phi {x, y} = x$
Then the kernel of $\pr_1$ is isomorphic to $\struct {G_2, \circ_2}$.

9b94467c-3b33-45eb-9f03-5bc7b6e71c78.text:
Let $\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}$ denote the set of quadratic integers over $2$:
:$\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2} := \set {a + b \sqrt 2: a, b \in \Z}$
that is, all numbers of the form $a + b \sqrt 2$ where $a$ and $b$ are integers.
Let $\struct {\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}, +, \times}$ be the integral domain where $+$ and $\times$ are conventional addition and multiplication on real numbers.
Then numbers of the form $a + b \sqrt 2$ such that $a^2 - 2 b^2 = \pm 1$ are all units of $\struct {\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}, +, \times}$.

beca3828-bed4-4353-abba-6315672e3508.text:
Let $\mathbb J = \set {x \in \R: a \le x \le b}$ be a closed interval of the real number line $\R$.
Let $\map \CC {\mathbb J}$ be the set of all continuous real functions on $\mathbb J$.
Then $\struct {\map \CC {\mathbb J}, +, \times}_\R$ is a subspace of the $\R$-vector space $\struct {\R^{\mathbb J}, +, \times}_\R$.

e7c26fa7-a921-4cc7-be81-1c6d1c2876dc.text:
Let $L_1 = \struct {S, \preceq_1}$ be an ordered set.
Let $L_2 = \struct {S, \preceq_2}$ be a dual ordered set of $L_1$.
Then $\map {\mathit {Ids} } {L_1} = \map {\mathit {Filt} } {L_2}$
where
:$\map {\mathit {Filt} } {L_2}$ denotes the set of all filters of $L_2$
:$\map {\mathit {Ids} } {L_1}$ denotes the set of all ideals of $L_1$.

f61ecc7f-e6f1-4e99-bebe-c34b13c46d71.text:
Let $I \subseteq \R$ be a real interval.
Let $f: I \to \R$ be an absolutely continuous real function.
Then $f$ is uniformly continuous.

8b2fe9c4-c43a-462d-ab40-fde7666e478a.text:
Let $x \in \R$ such that $-1 < x \le 1$.
Then:
:$\sqrt [3] {1 + x} = 1 + \dfrac 1 3 x - \dfrac 2 {3 \times 6} x^2 + \dfrac {2 \times 5} {3 \times 6 \times 9} x^3 - \cdots$

479d78f5-b561-4841-9029-85edb500fa96.text:
Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Then $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is $\sigma$- compact.

0e457583-9ca8-4010-8d68-c6a846884138.text:
Let $L_1 = \left({S_1, \preceq_1}\right)$, $L_2 = \left({S_2, \preceq_2}\right)$ be ordered sets.
Let $f:S_1 \to S_2$ be an order isomorphism between $L_1$ and $L_2$.
Then $\left({f, f^{-1} }\right)$ is a Galois connection.

57fb4248-2452-4052-a70d-32a38fde4b73.text:
Let $\II$ denote the set of complex numbers of the form $0 + i y$
That is, let $\II$ be the set of all wholly imaginary numbers.
Then the algebraic structure $\struct {\II, +}$ is a group.

81b2931f-fb27-472f-b3c0-3c30c8f15ea1.text:
Let $\struct {X, \tau}$ and $\struct {X', \tau'}$ be topological spaces.
Denote with $\map \BB {X, \tau}$ and $\map \BB {X', \tau'}$ their respective Borel $\sigma$-algebras.
Let $f: X \to X'$ be a continuous mapping.
Then $f$ is $\map \BB {X, \tau} \, / \, \map \BB {X', \tau'}$-measurable.

6762d070-1d50-4c98-baa9-dc48ffc9a14e.text:
Let $\struct {G, +_G}$ be an abelian group whose identity is $e$.
Let $\struct {R, +_R, \times_R}$ be a ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$ be an unitary $R$-module.
Let $x \in G$.
Then:
:$\paren {-1_R} \circ x = - x$

ad5f4fdf-bfe9-4e6d-a695-6833709265cf.text:
Let $\R^n$ be an $n$-dimensional real vector space.
Let $d_\infty: \R^n \times \R^n \to \R$ be the Chebyshev distance on $\R^n$.
Let $d_2: \R^n \times \R^n \to \R$ be the Euclidean metric on $\R^n$.
Let $M_1 = \struct {\R^n, d_\infty}$ and $M_2 = \struct {\R^n, d_2}$ be the corresponding metric spaces.
Then $M_1$ and $M_2$ are homeomorphic.

9b11a2f1-2baa-471e-885b-e65721006fc2.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets such that:
:$S \setminus T \ne \O$
:$S \cap T \ne \O$
where $S \setminus T$ denotes set difference and $S \cap T$ denotes set intersection.
Then $S \setminus T$ and $S \cap T$ form a partition of $S$.

9c653742-541a-49f8-9771-be4a644e2afa.text:
Let $a$ and $b$ be (strictly) positive real numbers such that $a^2 - b > 0$.
Then:
:$\ds \sqrt {a - \sqrt b} = \sqrt {\dfrac {a + \sqrt {a^2 - b} } 2} - \sqrt {\dfrac {a - \sqrt {a^2 - b} } 2}$

b0164ea0-7ae9-4c2b-9de6-eca443752e1a.text:
Every non-empty open set $I \subseteq \R$ can be expressed as a countable union of pairwise disjoint open intervals.
If:
:$\ds I = \bigcup_{n \mathop \in \N} J_n$
:$\ds I = \bigcup_{n \mathop \in \N} K_n$
are two such expressions, then there exists a permutation $\sigma$ of $\N$ such that:
:$\forall n \in \N: J_n = K_{\map \sigma n}$

d81951e2-a8b0-4817-a211-422b0102869f.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a meet semilattice.
Let $X$ be a non-empty subset of $S$.
Then
:$X \subseteq \map {\operatorname {fininfs} } X^\succeq$ and
:for every a filter $F$ in $L$: $\paren {X \subseteq F \implies \map {\operatorname {fininfs} } X^\succeq \subseteq F}$
where
: $\map {\operatorname {fininfs} } X$ denotes the finite infima set of $X$,
: $X^\succeq$ denotes the upper closure of $X$.

1d0b2de3-dde8-4e67-bde3-215f6b212fb8.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$ be a positive integer.
Let $x, y \in \R$ be real numbers which satisfy:
:$n \le y \le x \le y + 1$
Let $z$ be the unique real number $z$ such that:
:$\dbinom x {n + 1} = \dbinom y {n + 1} + \dbinom z n$
where $n - 1 \le z \le y$.
Its uniqueness is proved at Uniqueness of Real $z$ such that $\dbinom x {n + 1} = \dbinom y {n + 1} + \dbinom z n$.
Then:
:$\dbinom x n \le \dbinom y n + \dbinom z {n - 1}$

aef8fc8d-a293-40e6-b25c-0c48187a990a.text:
Let $z$ be a complex number.
Let $\tan z$ denote the tangent function and $i$ denote the imaginary unit: $i^2 = -1$.
Then:
:$\tan z = i \dfrac {1 - e^{2 i z} } {1 + e^{2 i z} }$

9fd22e8c-1c01-48fd-9df8-78dbdc5e8fbe.text:
Let $R$ be a ring with unity.
Let $\struct {P, \subseteq}$ be the ordered set consisting of all ideals of $R$, ordered by inclusion.
Let $\sequence {I_\alpha}_{\alpha \mathop \in A}$ be a non-empty chain of proper ideals in $P$.
Let $\ds I = \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in A} I_\alpha$ be their union.
Then $I$ is a proper ideal of $R$.

4fd34b3c-e3ff-46b6-8872-f0678082a5f4.text:
Let $\struct {R, +_R, \circ_R}$ be a ring.
Let $G$ be the trivial group.
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$ be the null module.
Then $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$ is a module.

1b625cb5-2ff7-45bd-b753-e4c2351d96a3.text:
:$\ds \sum_{i \mathop = 0}^n \binom n i^2 = \binom {2 n} n$
where $\dbinom n i$ denotes a binomial coefficient.

c6863c4c-e311-4ff6-bad3-a6560e360885.text:
Let $\R^n$ denote the real Cartesian space of $n$ dimensions.
Let $U$ be a scalar field over $\R^n$.
Let $\nabla^2 U$ denote the laplacian on $U$.
Then:
:$\nabla^2 U = \operatorname {div} \grad U$
where:
:$\operatorname {div}$ denotes the divergence operator
:$\grad$ denotes the gradient operator.

72a0fd48-98ee-4789-b9f5-d7ec2bd71ddb.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau}$ be a normal space.
Then $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also a Tychonoff (completely regular) space.

5e13e68d-8662-4c9a-87b5-439f3b4d48ad.text:
Let $E \subset \R^\ell$.
Let $\mathbb x \in \map {\operatorname{co} } E$.
{{explain|Definition of $\map {\operatorname{co} } E$}}
Then $\mathbf x$ is a convex combination of affinely independent points of $E$. 
In particular, $\mathbf x$ is a convex combination of at most $\ell + 1$ points of $E$.

0f78680d-8467-4d7d-886e-2529870d5ebf.text:
Let $\R$ be the real number line with the usual (Euclidean} metric.
The closed unit interval $\mathbf I = \closedint 0 1$ is a path-connected metric subspace of $\R$.

7e20f547-b7a7-44c4-942e-ae984bc64036.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ, \preceq}$ be a naturally ordered semigroup.
Then $\preceq$ is strongly compatible with $\circ$:
:$\forall m, n, p \in S: m \preceq n \iff m \circ p \preceq n \circ p$

144fb772-5ffb-4bce-92d9-ad288b4ff356.text:
:$\ds \int_0^{2 \pi} \frac {\d x} {\paren {a + b \cos x}^2} = \frac {2 \pi a} {\paren {a^2 - b^2}^{3/2} }$
where $a$ and $b$ are real numbers with $a > b > 0$.

368d5abc-c6fd-48cd-8759-1841ac1dbfd8.text:
Let $p$ be an odd prime.
Let $a \in \Z: a \not \equiv 0 \pmod p$.
Let $S = \left\{{a, 2 a, 3 a, \ldots, \dfrac {p - 1} 2 a}\right\}$.
Let $n$ denote the number of elements of $S$ whose least positive residue modulo $p$ is greater than $\dfrac p 2$.
Then:
:$\left({\dfrac a p}\right) = \left({-1}\right)^n$
where $\left({\dfrac a p}\right)$ is the Legendre symbol.

e76fe1ef-846f-4334-836c-f5a4aa3f1cb6.text:
Let $P$ be the quartic equation:
:$a x^4 + b x^3 + c x^2 + d x + e = 0$
such that $a \ne 0$.
Then $P$ has solutions:
:$x = \dfrac {-p \pm \sqrt {p^2 - 8 q} } 4$
where:
:$p = \dfrac b a \pm \sqrt {\dfrac {b^2} {a^2} - \dfrac {4 c} a + 4 y_1}$
:$q = y_1 \mp \sqrt {y_1^2 - \dfrac {4 e} a}$
where $y_1$ is a real solution to the cubic:
:$y^3 - \dfrac c a y^2 + \paren {\dfrac {b d} {a^2} - \dfrac {4 e} a} y + \paren {\dfrac {4 c e} {a^2} - \dfrac {b^2 e} {a^3} - \dfrac {d^2} {a^2} } = 0$
'''Ferrari's method''' is a technique for solving this quartic.

70c74aa7-6556-47f4-a5f9-79a99419c941.text:
Let $T = \struct {\set {0, 1}, \tau_0}$ be a Sierpiński space.
The sequence in $T$:
:$\sigma = \sequence {0, 1, 0, 1, \ldots}$
has $0$ as an accumulation point.

ff9d34fe-9f1e-44ee-814a-f979c7a29a37.text:
Let $A$ and $B$ be sets
Let $f$ be a bijection from $E$ to $F$.
Let $S_A$ and $S_B$ denote the set of all permutations on $A$ and $B$ respectively.
Let $\Phi: S_A \to S_B$ be the mapping defined as:
:$\forall u \in S_A: \map \Phi u = f \circ u \circ f^{-1}$
where $\circ$ denotes composition of mappings.
Then $\Phi$ is an isomorphism from $S_A$ to $S_B$.

fd75d3a3-27cf-44fc-a6c2-4b7de9ee93d9.text:
Let $a, b$ be real numbers with $a < b$.
Let $f : \closedint a b \to \R$ be a bounded function.
Then $f$ is not necessarily of bounded variation.

48c40d14-e4ca-45a7-8a6f-3b387a995f5c.text:
Let $f$ be a real function of $x$ of the form 
:$\map f x = \dfrac {\map g x} {\map h x}$
Further, let $g$ and $h$ be continuous on some open interval $\mathbb I$, where $c$ is a constant in $\mathbb I$.
If:
:$(1): \quad \map g c \ne 0$
:$(2): \quad \map h c = 0$
:$(3): \quad \forall x \in \mathbb I: x \ne c \implies \map h x \ne 0$
then the limit of $f$ as $x \to c$ will not exist, and:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c^+} \map f x = +\infty$ or $-\infty$
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to c^-} \map f x = +\infty$ or $-\infty$

f5a035db-573f-4d35-8720-ade6cba841bc.text:
Let $\Z_{>0}$ be the set of (strictly) positive integers.
Let $d: \Z_{>0} \times \Z_{>0} \to \R$ be the usual (Euclidean) metric on $\Z_{>0}$.
Let $\delta: \Z_{>0} \times \Z_{>0} \to \R$ be the metric on $\Z_{>0}$ defined as:
:$\forall x, y \in \Z_{>0}: \map \delta {x, y} = \dfrac {\size {x - y} } {x y}$
Let $\tau_d$ denote the metric topology for $d$.
Let $\tau_\delta$ denote the metric topology for $\delta$.
Then $\struct {\Z_{>0}, \tau_d}$ and $\struct {\Z_{>0}, \tau_\delta}$ are homeomorphic.

569bd688-a726-44e2-be36-af5b3eaa8615.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a strongly locally compact space.
Then $T$ is weakly locally compact.

b3bd14f3-6d9d-4c99-bf91-8be0ac494034.text:
Let $\RR$ be a congruence relation on an abelian group $\struct {G, \circ}$.
Then the quotient structure $\struct {G / \RR, \circ_\RR}$ is an abelian group.

5e2af9d5-afab-46cf-93ae-3267b22c45b7.text:
Let $\sequence {z_n}$ and $\sequence {w_n}$ be sequences in $\C$.
Let $\sequence {z_n}$ and $\sequence {w_n}$ be convergent to the following limits:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} z_n = c$
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} w_n = d$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \paren {z_n w_n} = c d$

41357691-313b-43c3-aab9-da2b539d161a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \RR}$ be a Relational Structure.
{{TFAE|def = Well-Founded Relation}}

ac6c4f77-6e01-4993-b5c0-3e72f845f16d.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Then $T$ is connected if and only if there exists no proper subset of $S$ which is clopen in $T$.

3ba37035-9ba9-450b-9094-b795c058f785.text:
$17$ is the smallest odd number $n$ greater than $3$ which cannot be expressed in the form:
:$n = 2 a^2 + p$
where:
:$p$ is prime
:$a \in \Z_{>0}$ is a (strictly) positive integer.

8fdcd10e-1366-471d-873b-a778ab90a4a6.text:
:$\map \sec {\dfrac \pi 2 - \theta} = \csc \theta$ for $\theta \ne n \pi$
where $\sec$ and $\csc$ are secant and cosecant respectively.
That is, the cosecant of an angle is the secant of its complement.
This relation is defined wherever $\sin \theta \ne 0$.

6fdde3ae-3573-4d7c-8038-129b8c9e78d6.text:
Let $\mathbf a$, $\mathbf b$ and $\mathbf c$ be cardinals.
Then:
:$\mathbf a \le \mathbf b \implies \mathbf a \mathbf c \le \mathbf b \mathbf c$
where $\mathbf a \mathbf c$ denotes the product of $\mathbf a$ and $\mathbf c$.

b39dddb0-c97b-45f3-853f-87f7e353ecbd.text:
Let $f$ and $g$ be real functions.
Let $c$ be a constant.
Let both $f$ and $g$ be bounded above on $S \subseteq \R$.
Then:
:$\ds \map {\sup_{x \mathop \in S} } {\map f x + c} = c + \map {\sup_{x \mathop \in S} } {\map f x}$
:$\ds \map {\sup_{x \mathop \in S} } {\map f x + \map g x} \le \map {\sup_{x \mathop \in S} } {\map f x} + \map {\sup_{x \mathop \in S} } {\map g x}$
where $\ds \map \sup {\map f x}$ is the supremum of $\map f x$.

6c094c52-3026-4c8f-a60b-7184b8a62112.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be an injection.
Let $g: T \to S$ be a left inverse of $f$.
Then $g$ is a surjection.

5a6e9ad2-3281-4b9c-b27c-1637428c59c0.text:
Let $A$ be a class.
Let $\ds \bigcup A$ denote the union of $A$.
Let $A$ be transitive.
Then $\ds \bigcup A$ is also transitive.

271b85af-4d5b-48e4-9970-72c3e081a258.text:
Let $S$ be a set
Let $\epsilon$ be the empty group word on $S$.
Then $\epsilon$ is reduced.

0ce7fcbd-86ad-44a1-853b-c6222ca4ca2e.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets of real numbers.
Let $S$ and $T$ admit infima.
Then:
: $\inf S \ge \inf T \iff \forall \epsilon \in \R_{>0}: \forall s \in S: \exists t \in T: s + \epsilon > t$

0a0f7286-6d98-49eb-adf2-47f6d6d178fc.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $S \subseteq A$ be bounded in $M$.
Then:
:$\map \diam S = \map \diam {S^-}$
where $\map \diam S$ denotes the diameter of $S$, and $S^-$ denotes the closure of $S$ in $M$.

f1d0c96f-5005-4c71-934b-b7240e3ff6a7.text:
Let $\mathbf a$ be a vector quantity.
Let $0 \mathbf a$ denote the scalar product of $\mathbf a$ with $0$.
Then:
:$0 \mathbf a = \bszero$
where $\bszero$ denotes the zero vector.

500a73a0-6587-40fb-b0b8-f6c2b50c9ecb.text:
Consider a circle of radius $a$ rolling without slipping along the x-axis of a cartesian plane.
Consider the point $P$ on the circumference of this circle which is at the origin when its center is on the y-axis.
Consider the cycloid traced out by the point $P$.
Let $\tuple {x, y}$ be the coordinates of $P$ as it travels over the plane.
The second derivative of the locus of $P$ is given by:
:$y'' = -\dfrac a {y^2}$

9a8b277c-2c69-4cd6-9bba-3b88eb80f56c.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an up-complete lower bounded join semillattice.
Then $\struct {S, \preceq}$ is complete.

a10bebf7-778a-4ee1-9784-e18ec7abb557.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XIII|prop=8|body=If in an equilateral and equiangular pentagon straight lines subtend two internal angles taken in order, they cut one another in extreme and mean ratio, and their greater segments are equal to the side of the pentagon.}}

370388db-add4-46f2-97b1-c3bc6d2747e5.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a semiperfect number.
Let $k \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Then $k n$ is also a semiperfect number.

806e43c4-c364-4b07-9424-f7e20020b9ab.text:
The zero cardinal $0$ is less than one:
:$0 < 1$

1209a9d5-8324-4cb2-b017-90d4394d0140.text:
Let $z_0 \in \C$ be a complex number.
Let $R \in \R_{>0}$ be a real number.
Let $\map {B'} {z_0, R}$ be the open punctured disk at $z_0$ of radius $R$.
Let $f: \map {B'} {z_0, R} \to \C$ be holomorphic.
Then there exists a sequence $\sequence {a_n}_{n \mathop \in \Z}$ such that:
:$\map f z = \displaystyle \sum_{n = -\infty}^\infty a_n \paren {z - z_0}^n$
for all $z \in B'(z_0, R)$.

cb7b0778-607b-4619-91b4-797d6bc6b7b6.text: A Euclidean domain is a principal ideal domain.

e4362a4f-e690-47f0-877c-147ddeda96a1.text:
Let $P = \struct {S, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a meet semilattice.
Let $X$ be a non-empty subset of $S$.
Then
:$\map {\operatorname {fininfs} } X^\succeq$ is filter in $P$.
where
:$\map {\operatorname {fininfs} } X$ denotes the finite infima set of $X$,
:$X^\succeq$ denotes the upper closure of $X$.

b47bec38-2d93-41de-912e-b7d8db642f3e.text:
Let $\sequence {z_n}$ be a sequence of complex numbers.
Suppose $\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty z_n$ converges to $z \in \C$.
Then $\ds \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \map \exp {z_n}$ converges to $\exp z$.

21cd44b5-54d9-411f-8512-a0f06c41707b.text:
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $\R$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be bounded.
Let $b \in \R$ be a real number.
Suppose that $\forall N: \exists n > N: x_n \ge b$.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ has a subsequence which converges to a limit $l \ge b$.

976caf3e-e94f-4643-9e30-436a2bbb38b9.text:
Let $\N_{> 0}$ be the 1-based natural numbers:
:$\N_{> 0} = \left\{{1, 2, 3, \ldots}\right\}$
Let $<$ be the ordering on $\N_{> 0}$:
:$\forall a, b \in \N_{>0}: a < b \iff \exists c \in \N_{>0}: a + c = b$
Let $a \in \N_{>0}$.
Then there exists no natural number $n$ such that $a < n < a + 1$.

d0d100e2-3ac6-44d2-bd55-aee466b65eb5.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is convex on the open interval $\openint a b$.
Then $f$ is continuous on $\openint a b$.

46c977ad-73ca-4565-96bd-dafe05ffef1d.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring.
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$ and $\struct {H, +_H, \circ}_R$ be $R$-modules.
Let $\map {\LL_R} {G, H}$ be the set of all linear transformations from $G$ to $H$.
Then $\map {\LL_R} {G, H}$ is a submodule of the $R$-module $H^G$.

f1c582ad-46a9-48ca-945e-cbbf0f6955f9.text:
The Axiom of Pairing is a consequence of:
:the Axiom of Infinity
and
:the Axiom of Replacement.

8dcc391a-7baa-49ee-a837-ef139349d95a.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $f: A_1 \to A_2$ be a mapping which is continuous at $a \in A_1$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence of points in $A_1$ such that:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = a$
where $\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n$ is the limit of $x_n$.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \map f {x_n} = \map f a$
That is:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \map f {x_n} = \map f {\lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n}$
That is, for a continuous mapping, the limit and function symbols commute.

084cb023-9f12-4b4d-a4f3-7c7de79b33da.text:
Let $F_n$ and $F_m$ be Fibonacci numbers.
By the Division Theorem, let:
:$F_n = q F_m + r$
where:
:$q \in \Z$
:$r \in \Z: 0 \le r < \size {F_m}$
Then either $r$ or $\size {F_m} - r$, or both, is a Fibonacci number.

f16c209d-c56e-4f7f-ac48-df0931c0d3e3.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $a \in A$.
Let $\sequence{x_n}$ be a real null sequence such that:
:$\forall n \in N: x_n > 0$
Let $\map {B_\epsilon} a$ denote the open $\epsilon$-ball of $a$ in $M$.
Then:
:$\mathcal B_{\sequence{x_n}} = \set{\map {B_{x_n}} a : n \in \N}$ is a local basis at $a$.

7ce032c5-b535-4300-a6b6-4e751450bc62.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $N$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Let $a \in G$.
Then:
:$\paren {a N}^n$ is the identity of the quotient group $G / N$
{{iff}}:
:$a^n \in N$

1b70271f-b16c-447f-b977-b4bafe0b4fb5.text:
Let $R$ be a ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
The determinant of the unit matrix of order $n$ over $R$ is equal to $1_R$.

4b06f9b9-da3e-49d0-86af-f8f660e7cab6.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\powerset S$ be the power set of $S$.
Let $\TT \subseteq \powerset S$ be a subset of $\powerset S$.
Then the smallest set of $\TT$, if it exists, must be unique.

f0000ed3-3af9-4976-8210-b6f561238ed7.text:
Let $T = \struct {\R, \tau}$ be the Sorgenfrey line.
Then $T$ is perfectly normal.

78bd67ab-825a-4f1f-ab79-56d6d9cb2a64.text: In the prime number race between prime numbers of the form $4 n - 1$ and $4 n + 1$, the highest known stretch of integers where $4 n + 1$ is not less than $4 n - 1$ is between $18 \, 465 \, 126 \, 293$ and $19 \, 033 \, 524 \, 538$.

b3d4a6e5-f852-461f-a9c5-fec2ba474ebd.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity.
Then:
:$\struct {\set {1_R, -1_R}, \circ} \le U_R$
That is, the set consisting of the unity and its negative forms a subgroup of the group of units.

0391282f-14bf-4f6e-998e-666dfd5a259c.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau}$ be a completely normal space.
Then $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also a normal space.

33ab2519-690a-47bd-8a8f-303cff2d7986.text:
Let $S$ be a subset of a ring $\struct {R, +, \circ}$
Then $\map {C_R} S$, the centralizer of $S$ in $R$, is a subring of $R$.

8b55149f-7c12-4ee8-bd04-0139b19c25e3.text:
Let $\struct {G \times H, \circ}$ be the group direct product of the two groups $\struct {G, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {H, \circ_2}$.
Let $g^{-1}$ be an inverse of $g \in \struct {G, \circ_1}$.
Let $h^{-1}$ be an inverse of $h \in \struct {H, \circ_2}$.
Then $\tuple {g^{-1}, h^{-1} }$ is the inverse of $\tuple {g, h} \in \struct {G \times H, \circ}$.

4696e7c9-327e-4056-a675-0ee4130caa4f.text:
Let $\left({G,\circ}\right)$ be a group.
Let $S \subseteq G$.
Let $S$ be a normal subset of $G$ by Definition 3 and Definition 4.
Then $S$ is a normal subset of $G$ by Definition 2.

7bc5c98d-ae93-4167-8439-ecad98d365d3.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $f: S \to S$ be an injection.
Let the sequence of mappings:
:$f^0, f^1, f^2, \ldots, f^n, \ldots$
be defined as:
:$\forall n \in \N: \map {f^n} x = \begin {cases}
x & : n = 0 \\
\map f x & : n = 1 \\
\map f {\map {f^{n - 1} } x} & : n > 1
\end {cases}$
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times S$ be the relation on $S$ defined as:
:$\RR = \set {\tuple {a, b} \in S \times S: \exists k \in \Z: b = \map {f^k} a \lor \exists j \in \Z: a = \map {f^j} b}$
Then $\RR$ is an equivalence relation.

63c2d976-ffbc-44c4-9e6a-63a1306a0834.text: :$\ds \int \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} \rd x = \frac {x \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } 2 + \frac {a^2} 2 \arcsin \frac x a + C$

1bb51356-b31d-4932-b572-63839a21f359.text:
Let $\struct {X_i, \Sigma_i}$ be measurable spaces, with $i \in I$ for some index set $I$.
Let $X$ be a set, and let, for $i \in I$, $f_i: X \to X_i$ be a mapping.
Then:
:$\map \sigma {f_i: i \in I} = \map \sigma {\ds \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} \map {f_i^{-1} } {\Sigma_i} }$
where:
:$\map \sigma {f_i: i \in I}$ is the $\sigma$-algebra generated by $\family {f_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$
:$\map \sigma {\ds \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} \map {f_i^{-1} } {\Sigma_i} }$ is the $\sigma$-algebra generated by $\ds \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} \map {f_i^{-1} } {\Sigma_i}$
:$\map {f_i^{-1} } {\Sigma_i}$ denotes the pre-image $\sigma$-algebra on $X$ by $f$

58a58a6c-7ac1-4078-8318-4b8c8226e597.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\tau$ be the discrete topology on $S$.
:$\tau$ is a topology on $S$.

72025463-e5db-4a15-96c8-138ada107199.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a normed division ring with zero $0$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ and $\sequence {y_n}$ be Cauchy sequences in $R$.
Suppose $\sequence {y_n}$ does not converge to $0$.
Then:
:$\exists K \in \N: \forall n > K : y_n \ne 0$
and the sequences:
:$\sequence { {x_{K + n} } \paren {y_{K + n} }^{-1} }_{n \mathop \in \N}$ and $\sequence {\paren {y_{K + n} }^{-1} {x_{K + n} } }_{n \mathop \in \N}$ are well-defined and Cauchy sequences.

e7b2fee6-fd7c-4f32-abe9-57d41dcdeb44.text:
Let $2$ be the two ring.
Then $2$ is a Boolean ring.

d330486c-66c4-4d98-b668-b37adcd991bb.text:
Let $X$ and $Y$ be topological spaces.
Let $V$ be a normed vector space over $\R$ or $\C$ with norm $\norm {\,\cdot\,}$.
Let $x_0 \in X$ and $y_0 \in Y$.
Let $f: X \to Y$ be a function with $\map f {x_0} = y_0$ that is continuous at $x_0$.
Let $g, h: Y \to V$ be functions.
Suppose $\map g y = \map O {\map h y}$ as $y \to y_0$, where $O$ denotes big-O notation.
Then $\map {\paren {g \circ f} } x = \map O {\map {\paren {h \circ f} } x}$ as $x \to x_0$.

d4aaddf8-f084-4217-8569-98f028865f6d.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Then $M$ is a fully normal space.

e25537e0-edf5-46ad-95e1-02dccbb695a2.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be an integral domain whose unity is $1_D$.
Let $\struct {U_D, \circ}$ be the group of units of $\struct {D, +, \circ}$.
Then:
:$x \in D, u \in U_D: x \divides u \implies x \in U_D$
That is, if $x$ is a divisor of a unit, $x$ must itself be a unit.

e3eb0936-d0c8-4861-a02e-a809bb8d2860.text:
Let $G$ be a group with the following properties:
:$(1): \quad G$ is non-abelian.
:$(2): \quad G$ is of order $8$.
:$(3): \quad G$ has precisely one element of order $2$.
Then $G$ is isomorphic to the quaternion group $Q$.

17242f9a-4685-4af9-b1af-58fd5b54bee4.text:
Let $\struct {F, +, \times}$ be a field whose zero is $0_F$ and whose unity is $1_F$.
Let $\struct {F, +}$ denote the additive group of $F$.
Let $\struct {F_{\ne 0_F}, \times}$ denote the multiplicative group of $F$.
Then $\struct {F, +}$ and $\struct {F_{\ne 0_F}, \times}$ are not isomorphic to each other.

6dada992-f971-4cdb-9978-f1ca4bcf7ec5.text:
Let the following conditions be fulfilled:
:Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a commutative semigroup with cancellable elements
:Let $\phi$ be an isomorphism from $\struct {S, \circ}$ into a semigroup $\struct {T, *}$
:Let $\struct {S', \circ'}$ be an inverse completion of $\struct {S, \circ}$
:Let $\struct {T', \circ'}$ be an inverse completion of $\struct {T, \circ}$.
Then there is a unique isomorphism $\phi': S' \to T'$ extending $\phi$.

d97d089b-5911-4e7b-81a8-84d4cbb15901.text: The Cartesian product $\N \times \N$ of the set of natural numbers $\N$ with itself is countable.

2268878f-07e8-40ef-8bcd-5ec4f38b4e64.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an algebraic structure with an identity element $e$.
Let $x \in S$ be invertible, and let $y$ be an inverse of $x$.
Then $x$ is also an inverse of $y$.

14f7d946-725a-46fe-a685-d79d8197d478.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a Hausdorff topological space.
Let $K \subset S$ be a compact subspace of $T$.
Then its boundary $\partial K$ is compact.

e2882c82-b16b-451b-aaf6-194c85b14669.text:
Let $\map {\mathbf{Dis} } S$ be a discrete category.
Then $\map {\mathbf{Dis} } S$ is also an order category.

ae06e2b5-caff-45a2-846b-c8ebd8261e9a.text:
Let $R, S, T$ be sets.
Then:
:$S \cap T \subseteq \paren {R \cap S} \cup \paren {\overline R \cap T}$
where $\overline R$ denotes the complement of $R$.

2fc8686c-1b0c-4bd4-8a72-c9f3bbbd6a70.text:
Let $c_0$ be the space of zero-limit sequences.
Let $\norm {\, \cdot \,}_\infty$ be the supremum norm.
Then $\struct {c_0, \norm {\, \cdot \,}_\infty}$ is a Banach space.

10fa48b5-9e29-4546-9797-35d1edfdc90d.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be the Arens-Fort space.
Then $T$ is not a locally connected space.

bfff036e-3c6a-4b71-958f-54a3291ece95.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Then:
:$\dfrac {n^n} {e^{n - 1} } \le n! \le \dfrac {n^{n + 1} } {e^{n - 1} }$

3d54085c-40f1-4392-a2a5-576a057802c9.text:
Let $I = \openint a b$ be an open real interval.
Let $\phi$ be a real function which is continuous on $I$ and also non-negative on $I$.
Let $f$ be a real function which is continuous on $I$.
Let $f$ satisfy:
:$\forall x \in I: \size {\map f x} \le \map \phi x$
If the improper integral of $\phi$ over $I$ exists, then so does that of $f$.

811217ed-5310-4c31-9302-ca587dc3c9ac.text:
Let $\left({X, \circ}\right)$ be a $B$-algebra.
Then:
:$\forall x,y,z \in X: x \circ \left({y \circ z}\right) = \left({x \circ \left({0 \circ z}\right)}\right) \circ y$

c3f68200-64dc-40df-9278-e37af0fc6d98.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a Hausdorff space.
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times S$ be an equivalence relation on $S$.
Let $T_\RR := \struct {S / \RR, \tau_\RR}$ be the quotient space of $S$ by $\RR$.
Then $T_\RR$ is not necessarily also a Hausdorff space.

79c31b52-5dc8-49a9-8120-b175a962a61b.text: The circle group $\struct {K, \times}$ is an uncountably infinite group.

904478e6-9646-4e9c-9b58-7a2161042766.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $S \subseteq G$.
Let $S^a$ denote the $G$-conjugate of $S$ by $a$ as:
:$S^a := \set {y \in G: \exists x \in S: y = a \circ x \circ a^{-1} } = a \circ S \circ a^{-1}$
Then:
:$\paren {S^a}^b = S^{b \circ a}$

d7d0d184-6a6f-4f88-83f1-3868e89ce7e2.text:
Let $G_n = \sequence {a_n}_{0 \mathop \le i \mathop \le n}$ be a geometric sequence of integers.
Let $a_0 = 1$.
Let $m \in \Z_{> 0}$.
Then:
:$\forall r \in \set {0, 1, \ldots, m}: a_k \divides a_m$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.
{{EuclidPropStatement|book = IX|prop = 11|body = If as many numbers as we please beginning from an unit be in continued proportion, the less measures the greater according to some one of the numbers which have place among the proportional numbers.}}

9d4c613c-3f8d-46b9-ad4c-bb3d512fb525.text:
Let $S_3$ denote the symmetric group on $3$ letters.
Let $G$ be the group generated by $1 / z$ and $1 - z$.
Then $S_3$ and $G$ are isomorphic algebraic structures.

0b380a0f-e714-4bef-b0aa-9fb8c9dc3184.text:
Let $S$ be a set with more than $1$ element.
Let $\struct {S, \to}$ be an algebraic structure in which the operation $\to$ is the right operation.
Then $\struct {S, \to}$ has no right identities.

5e2477b3-6957-448b-9c34-66f17a55d6ef.text:
:$\forall a, b, c \in \R: a < b \land c > 0 \implies a c < b c$
where $\R$ is the set of real numbers.

6292def0-52aa-4c75-86af-d905122ed836.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau}$ be a compact connected Hausdorff space.
Let $A$ be a closed, non-empty proper subset of $S$.
Let $C$ be a component of $A$.
Then:
:$C \cap \partial A \ne \O$
where $\partial A$ denotes the boundary of $A$.

1bcbd9e6-ba1b-46d7-b4d4-0932081c1ba9.text:
Let $\struct  {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup with a right identity $e_R$ such that:
:$\forall x \in S: \exists x_R: x \circ x_R = e_R$
That is, every element of $S$ has a right inverse with respect to the right identity.
Then $e_R$ is also a left identity, that is, is an identity.

03d9bb18-cd8d-49a6-bf95-e0929dc87f43.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\Z_p$ be the $p$-adic integers.
Let $x \in \Z_p$.
Then $x$ is the limit of a unique $p$-adic expansion of the form:
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 0}^\infty d_n p^n$

d3aca14a-853f-48d9-b00f-35d673e8857a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \set {\O, S} }$ be an indiscrete topological space.
Then $T$ is ultraconnected.

a48ca9dd-b693-4dfd-a051-b09144785525.text:
:$\forall x, y \in \R: x \ne y \implies x^2 + y^2 > 2 x y$
{{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=60|qual=Lemma|body=If a straight line be cut into unequal parts, the squares on the unequal parts are greater than twice the rectangle contained by the unequal parts.}}

5d023c84-b29d-4f2f-a40e-0e53276ca653.text:
:$\mathbb U \symdif S = \map \complement S$
where:
:$\mathbb U$ denotes the universe
:$\symdif$ denotes symmetric difference.

b1b3f887-97c1-458f-93e4-f47fcf8f660c.text:
Let $\left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a complete lattice.
Let $\left({A, \precsim}\right)$ be a non-empty directed set.
Let $Z: A \to S$ be a Moore-Smith sequence.
Let $D = \left\{ {\inf \left({Z\left[{\precsim \left({j}\right)}\right]}\right): j \in A}\right\}$ be a subset of $S$.
Then $D$ is directed.

d23efe69-f4cf-4397-87ab-8fb7143f70d4.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a strictly positive integer.
Let $f: \R_{>0} \to \R$ be the real function defined as:
:$\map f x = x^n$
where $x^n$ denotes $x$ to the power of $n$.
Then $f$ is strictly increasing.

b991c39d-4a4b-4fc4-9150-3c479840e621.text:
Let $a, b \in \Z$ be integers.
Let $S = \set {a x + b y: x, y \in \Z}$ be the set of integer combinations of $a$ and $b$.
Let $u \in S$.
Let $n \in \Z$.
Then $n u \in S$.

c1438f07-d032-4789-ba54-eb8c690b1ad4.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ and $\struct {H, *}$ be groups.
Let $\phi: G \to H$ be a homomorphism.
Then:
:$\forall g_k \in H: \map \phi {g_1 \circ g_2 \circ \cdots \circ g_n} = \map \phi {g_1} * \map \phi {g_2} * \cdots * \map \phi {g_n}$

6b61918e-ffde-4634-92e5-02356f33a58c.text:
:$\ds \int_0^1 x^m \paren {\ln x}^n \rd x = \frac {\paren {-1}^n \map \Gamma {n + 1} } {\paren {m + 1}^{n + 1} }$
where:
:$n$ is a non-negative integer
:$m$ is a real number with $m > -1$.

5f443764-c948-4500-b408-783b35480d47.text:
Let $E / F$ be a finite field extension.
Then its automorphism group is finite.

f6498eea-0e34-4c50-8827-493504180fee.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\paren {a x + b}^2 \paren {p x + q} } = \frac 1 {b p - a q} \paren {\frac 1 {a x + b} + \frac p {b p - a q} \ln \size {\frac {p x + q} {a x + b} } } + C$

70b9b984-1ba1-45ae-a228-bcc137681092.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Then there exists a completion $\tilde M = \struct {\tilde A, \tilde d}$ of $\struct {A, d}$.
Moreover, this completion is unique up to isometry.
That is, if $\struct {\hat A, \hat d}$ is another completion of $\struct {A, d}$, then there is a bijection $\tau: \tilde A \leftrightarrow \hat A$ such that:
:$(1): \quad \tau$ restricts to the identity on $x$:
::::$\forall x \in A: \map \tau x = x$
:$(2): \quad \tau$ preserves metrics:
::::$\forall x_1, x_2 \in A : \map {\hat d} {\map \tau {x_1}, \map \tau {x_2} } = \map {\tilde d} {x_1, x_2}$
:$\tilde d$ is well-defined on $\tilde A$.
We claim that $\struct {\tilde A, \tilde d}$ is a completion of $\struct {A, d}$.
Therefore we must show that:
:$\tilde d$ is a metric on $\tilde A$
:There exists an everywhere dense inclusion $\struct {A, d} \to \struct {\tilde A, \tilde d}$ preserving $d$.
In addition the theorem claims that $\struct {\tilde A, \tilde d}$ is unique up to isometry.
:$\tilde d$ is a metric on $\tilde A$.
:$\tilde M = \struct {\tilde A, \tilde d}$ is a completion of $M$.
:$\tilde M = \struct {\tilde A, \tilde d}$ is unique up to isometry.
{{qed}}
{{ACC|Completion Theorem (Metric Space)/Lemma 3}}

16602026-e066-48dc-9ee9-2a3f56ad41d8.text: :$\ds \int \csc^n a x \rd x = \frac{-\csc^{n - 2} a x \cot a x} {a \paren {n - 1} } + \frac {n - 2} {n - 1} \int \csc^{n - 2} a x \rd x$

62ce11f8-c013-44e6-a336-14236062bb91.text:
Let $\Bbb S$ be a set of sets.
Then $\Bbb S$ can be defined as an indexed family of sets.

4996be4b-57bc-4d0b-9d4b-9ccd9ee6065d.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $G$ be such that its subgroups form a nest.
Then $G$ is a cyclic $p$-group.

b0e658d1-e713-4850-92de-0850428b5ca9.text:
Let $M_1, M_2, M_3$ be metric spaces. 
Let $f: M_1 \to M_2$ and $g: M_2 \to M_3$ be homeomorphisms.
Then $g \circ f: M_1 \to M_3$ is also a homeomorphism.

18cc27ea-5be4-4ea4-9ca3-cd6a844279d1.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $U$ be an open set of $T$.
Then $U$ is a $G_\delta$ set of $T$.

8025b34c-9fd8-46b7-9102-aab6807ab426.text:
Let $R$ be a division ring.
Let $\norm {\, \cdot \,}_1: R \to \R_{\ge 0}$ and $\norm {\, \cdot \,}_2: R \to \R_{\ge 0}$ be norms on $R$.
Let $d_1$ and $d_2$ be the metrics induced by the norms $\norm {\, \cdot \,}_1$ and $\norm {\, \cdot \,}_2$ respectively.
Let $d_1$ and $d_2$ be topologically equivalent metrics.
Then:
:$d_1$ and $d_2$ are convergently equivalent metrics.

6a8c9b8f-98da-4b6a-94b3-1a3cd1f4db94.text:
Let $\mathbb A$ be one of the standard number systems $\N, \Z, \Q, \R, \C$.
Let $S$ and $T$ be finite sets.
Let $f: S \to \mathbb A$ be a mapping.
Let $g: T \to S$ be a bijection.
Then we have an equality of summations over finite sets:
:$\ds \sum_{s \mathop \in S} \map f s = \sum_{t \mathop \in T} \map f {\map g t}$

226f1a9d-1523-4171-a40a-e38763ac2143.text:
Let $\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}$ denote the set of quadratic integers over $2$:
:$\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2} := \set {a + b \sqrt 2: a, b \in \Z}$
that is, all numbers of the form $a + b \sqrt 2$ where $a$ and $b$ are integers.
Then the algebraic structure:
:$\struct {\Z \sqbrk {\sqrt 2}, +, \times}$
where $+$ and $\times$ are conventional addition and multiplication on real numbers, is an ordered integral domain.

a9a72b3d-c047-4374-9edb-3c74f41118b2.text:
Let $x \mapsto x^n$, $n \in \R$ be a real function which is continuous on the open interval $\openint 1 {+\infty}$.
Let $n > 0$.
Then $x^n \to +\infty$ as $x \to +\infty$.

a2f9e59b-7ecd-48ba-9368-d6a495e60866.text:
Let $k$ be a positive real number. 
Let $n$ be a positive integer. 
Then: 
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to 0^+} x^k \paren {\ln x}^n = 0$

66d3dae9-8483-45af-934d-f6c6ccfda9f7.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Then:
:$\ds z^{2 n + 1} - 1 = \paren {z - 1} \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n \paren {z^2 - 2 z \cos \dfrac {2 \pi k} {2 n + 1} + 1}$

2293b7b1-3a4b-4dde-95cd-7737f855c27d.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ, \leftarrow}$ be an algebraic structure where:
:$\leftarrow$ is the left operation
:$\circ$ is any arbitrary binary operation.
Then:
:$\leftarrow$ is distributive over $\circ$
{{iff}}:
:$\circ$ is idempotent.

7db7b004-742e-4142-b93f-5fdccc9db848.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $A \subseteq S, B \subseteq S$ be subsets of $S$.
Then:
:$A \subseteq B \iff \relcomp S B \subseteq \relcomp S A$
where $\complement_S$ denotes the complement relative to $S$.

2b045769-57b0-4b55-ba96-a49dea1b5c31.text:
Each element $x$ of the set of integers $\Z$ has an inverse element $-x$ under the operation of integer addition:
:$\forall x \in \Z: \exists -x \in \Z: x + \paren {-x} = 0 = \paren {-x} + x$

8cd232c9-680a-4582-a690-6b6dd7745786.text:
Let $V = \struct {X, \norm {\,\cdot\,} }$ be a normed vector space.
Every Cauchy sequence in $X$ is bounded.

a00faca0-b4b9-46e7-95f8-05d0a9b6240b.text:
Let $\chi : G := \paren {\Z / q \Z}^\times \to \C^\times$ be a Dirichlet character modulo $q$.
{{explain|$\C^\times$}}
Let $\map L {s, \chi}$ be the Dirichlet $L$-function for $\chi$.
Let $\chi$ be the trivial character.
Then $\map L {s, \chi}$ has an analytic continuation to $\C$ except for a simple pole at $s = 1$.
Let $\chi$ be non-trivial.
Then $\map L {s, \chi}$ is analytic on $\map \Re s > 0$.

bab0b160-2954-4aa1-90ae-202a69c6fb24.text:
Let $\ln$ be the natural logarithm.
Then $\ln$ is injective on $\R_{>0}$.

9c655d62-1e9a-44b9-943e-f7d7f55d428c.text:
: $\cosh 3 x = 4 \cosh^3 x - 3 \cosh x$
where $\cosh$ denotes hyperbolic cosine.

979a3b81-58ba-4cb1-b5b0-6fac65483b1b.text:
Let $a \in \R_{\ne 0}$.
Then:
:$\ds \int \frac {x^2 \rd x} {\paren ({\sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} }^3} = \frac {\paren {2 b^2 - 4 a c} x + 2 b c} {a \paren {4 a c - b^2} \sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} } + \frac 1 a \int \frac {\d x} {\sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} }$

20511ef7-802a-4ef4-ac78-04eded8accc4.text:
:$\ds \int_0^{\pi/2} \frac 1 {a + b \cos x} \rd x = \frac 1 {\sqrt {a^2 - b^2} } \map \arccos {\frac b a}$
where $a$ and $b$ are real numbers with $a > b > 0$.

b6a85fe9-50d5-44c9-bae6-598c905b5f45.text:
While every Convergent Sequence in Metric Space is Bounded, it does not follow that every bounded sequence is convergent.
That is, there exist bounded sequences which are divergent.

0312af92-9c63-47e3-8bbd-5ae99e31a5c1.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space on a set $S$.
Let $\family {A_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of subsets of $S$ indexed by the indexing set $I$:
:$\forall i \in I: A_i \subseteq S$
Let $\forall i \in I: \map T {A_i} = \struct {S, \tau_{A_i} }$ be the included set spaces on $S$ by $A_i$.
Let:
:$\forall i \in I: \map T {A_i} \ge T$
where $\map T {A_i} \ge T$ denotes that $\map T {A_i}$ is finer than $T$.
Then:
:$\ds \map T {\bigcup A_i} \ge T$
where $\ds \map T {\bigcup A_i}$ is the included set space on $S$ by $\ds \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} A_i$.

c71d07a3-647f-4345-a26a-fa5fe135817b.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $a \in G$.
Then the subgroup generated by $a$ is the set of powers:
:$\gen a  = \set {a^n : n \in \Z}$

eb2b8f9f-3ba8-4428-b41e-3888c2d02a40.text: The natural logarithm function is continuous.

d1e563a2-3811-4635-99d0-9257868c9e49.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a monoid whose identity element is $e$.
For $a \in S$, let $\circ^n a = a^n$ denote the $n$th power of $a$.
Let $a, b \in S$ such that $a$ commutes with $b$:
:$a \circ b = b \circ a$
Then:
:$\forall n \in \N: \circ^n \paren {a \circ b} = \paren {\circ^n a} \circ \paren {\circ^n b}$
That is:
:$\forall n \in \N: \paren {a \circ b}^n = a^n \circ b^n$

b6682f85-b95c-43e3-96c5-660d13370c54.text: Every finite totally ordered set is well-ordered.

20742ca3-e2db-4bf0-98d1-b4461047dafc.text:
Let $A \subseteq \R$ be any subset of the real numbers.
Let $f: A \to \R$ be a real function.
Let $x \in A$ be an isolated point of $A$.
Then $f$ is continuous at $x$.

6aa13517-267b-4ea3-b425-8014e230c95b.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau}$ be a Tychonoff space.
Then $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also an Urysohn space.

d2ecf632-2d0c-48cc-9ef0-05c499ad5f9f.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let the characteristic of $R$ be $p$.
For any $a \in R$, we define the mapping $g_a: \Z \to R$ from the integers into $R$ as:
:$\forall n \in \Z: \map {g_a} n = n \cdot a$
Then:
:$\ideal p \subseteq \map \ker {g_a}$
where:
:$\map \ker {g_a}$ is the kernel of $g_a$
:$\ideal p$ is the principal ideal of $\Z$ generated by $p$.

6a6b1faf-48bd-4630-a20a-5e7921e3b9b9.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a magma.
Then $\struct {S, \circ}$ is a submagma of itself.

1f59d643-e04b-4772-bbd0-c790c21f3300.text:
Let $f: \R \to \Z$ be an integer-valued function which satisfies both of the following:
:$(1): \quad \map f {x + 1} = \map f x + 1$
:$(2): \quad \forall n \in \Z_{> 0}: \map f x = \map f {\dfrac {\map f {n x} } n}$
Then either:
:$\forall x \in \Q: \map f x = \floor x$
or:
:$\forall x \in \Q: \map f x = \ceiling x$

fd4b6d54-b508-40ab-a33c-db4d42e3dd3a.text:
Let $\RR$ be a well-founded relation on $S$.
Let $x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n \in S$.
Then:
:$\neg \paren {\paren {x_1 \mathrel \RR x_2} \land \paren {x_3 \mathrel \RR x_4} \land \cdots \land \paren {x_n \mathrel \RR x_1} }$
That is, there are no relational loops within $S$.

44c0b91b-d43d-430e-9919-5aaa0693c9a4.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a division ring with unity $1_R$.
Let $\norm{\,\cdot\,}$ be a norm on $R$.
Then:
:$\norm{-1_R} = 1$

0b0d36fc-edd7-45ff-8437-58a9ef116491.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^3 \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } = \frac {-\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } {2 a^2 x^2} - \frac 1 {2 a^3} \map \ln {\frac {a + \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } {\size x} } + C$

26545f41-68b2-41a4-8552-f428015fdc77.text:
Let $OABC$ be a rhombus.
Then:
:$(1): \quad OB$ bisects $\angle AOC$ and $\angle ABC$
:$(2): \quad AC$ bisects $\angle OAB$ and $\angle OCB$
400px

39ad9341-ee93-449a-bf11-a84f39ea99f9.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Let $\mathbf A = \sqbrk a_{m n}$ be an $m \times n$ matrix over $\struct {R, +, \circ}$.
Then the matrix space $\map {\MM_R} {m, n}$ of all $m \times n$ matrices over $R$ is a module.

dd8f10ac-e347-4206-8eeb-b4505c4052b1.text:
Let $M = \struct {I^\omega, d_2}$ be the Hilbert cube.
Then $M$ is a separable space.

d3d54402-7a3b-46aa-8a36-5ccd15e43b4a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T$ have no two disjoint non-empty closed sets whose union is $S$.
Then the only subsets of $S$ whose boundary is empty are $S$ and $\O$.

cc3b3f76-1d49-46af-b941-e52789b0618f.text: The structure $\struct {\Z, +, \times, \le}$ is a totally ordered ring.

5763436b-e7a8-44b3-a83e-62a8ded4ceca.text:
Let Euler's number $e$ be defined as:
:$\ds e := \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \paren {1 + \frac 1 n}^n$
Then:
:$\ds e = \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^\infty \frac 1 {k!}$
That is:
:$e = \dfrac 1 {0!} + \dfrac 1 {1!} + \dfrac 1 {2!} + \dfrac 1 {3!} + \dfrac 1 {4!} \cdots$

d620a522-b562-4d7e-b715-3ca7f3283ecd.text:
Let $\ln: \C_{\ne 0} \to \C$ be the complex natural logarithm.
Let $\ln': \R_{>0} \to \R$ be the real natural logarithm.
Then:
:$\ln' = \ln \restriction_{\R_{>0} \times \R}$
That is, the real natural logarithm is the restriction of the complex natural logarithm.

bf37d428-fe45-43c0-af59-8d4a12e08d1a.text:
Let $\map \MM {m, n}$ be a metric space of order $m \times n$ over a field $K$.
Let $\mathbf A \in \map \MM {m, n}$ be a matrix. 
Let $\Gamma$ be a column operation which transforms $\mathbf A$ to a new matrix $\mathbf B \in \map \MM {m, n}$.
Then there exists a unique invertible square matrix $\mathbf K$ of order $n$ such that:
:$\mathbf A \mathbf K = \mathbf B$
where $\mathbf K$ is the product of a finite sequence of elementary column matrices.

fadb40fa-a95a-41c6-98c9-4730ba6a1353.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $A, B$ be subsets of $S$ such that
:$A \cap B \ne \O$
and
:$A$ is an upper set,
:$B$ is a directed set.
Then $A \cap B$ is a directed set.

1ae0fa19-7568-479b-808b-88ddbed42ed5.text:
The sequence $\sequence {s_n}$ defined as:
:$s_n = \paren {1 + \dfrac x n}^n$
is convergent.

37d6fc95-038d-48e1-92a8-08370c2be451.text:
Let $L / K$ be a field extension.
Let $\alpha \in L$ be algebraic over $K$.
Then the minimal polynomial in $\alpha$ over $K$ is unique and irreducible.

996ea00e-6a41-4710-95a8-992f32ef7c44.text:
Extended real addition $+_{\overline{\R}}$ is commutative.
That is, for all $x, y \in \overline{\R}$:
:$x +_{\overline{\R}} y = y +_{\overline{\R}} x$
whenever at least one of the sides is defined.

a90fae1e-e125-4153-ac16-452bf2521996.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a real function defined in the open interval $\openint {-\pi} \pi$.
Let $f$ fulfil the Dirichlet conditions in $\openint {-\pi} \pi$.
Let $a_0, a_1, \dotsc; b_1, \dotsc$ be the Fourier coefficients of $f$ in $\openint {-\pi} \pi$.
Consider the real function:
:$\map F x = \ds \int_{-\pi}^x \map f t \rd t - \dfrac {a_0} 2 x$
Then:
:$\map F \pi = \map F {-\pi} = \dfrac {a_0 \pi} 2$

8d7f3b1a-8214-4b1d-8d59-f3db5dec5b56.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is increasing on the open interval $\openint a b$.
If $\xi \in \openint a b$, then:
:$\map f {\xi^-}$ and $\map f {\xi^+}$ both exist
and:
:$\map f x \le \map f {\xi^-} \le \map f \xi \le \map f {\xi^+} \le \map f y$
provided that $a < x < \xi < y < b$.

60fdef1e-1d69-49a0-98b3-d96151d205c3.text:
Let $\mathbf A$ be an $m \times n$ matrix.
Let $\mathbf B$ be an $n \times m$ matrix.
Let $1 \le j_1, j_2, \ldots, j_m \le n$.
Let $\mathbf A_{j_1 j_2 \ldots j_m}$ denote the $m \times m$ matrix consisting of columns $j_1, j_2, \ldots, j_m$ of $\mathbf A$.
Let $\mathbf B_{j_1 j_2 \ldots j_m}$ denote the $m \times m$ matrix consisting of rows $j_1, j_2, \ldots, j_m$ of $\mathbf B$.
Then:
:$\displaystyle \map \det {\mathbf A \mathbf B} = \sum_{1 \mathop \le j_1 \mathop < j_2 \mathop < \cdots \mathop < j_m \le n} \map \det {\mathbf A_{j_1 j_2 \ldots j_m} } \map \det {\mathbf B_{j_1 j_2 \ldots j_m} }$
where $\det$ denotes the determinant.

3050907b-6c22-42f0-8e6f-e7efa2621e70.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XIII|prop=1|body=If a straight line be cut in extreme and mean ratio, the square on the greater segment added to the half of the whole is five times the square on the half.}}

d63a3cad-1209-4f90-b2e6-882406d17bd5.text:
{{TFAE|def = Congruence (Number Theory)|view = Congruence|context = Number Theory}}
Let $z \in \R$.

f4447ba6-6664-499e-ba4f-54dc9bb32546.text:
$41 \, 041$ is the smallest Carmichael number with $4$ prime factors:
:$41 \, 041 = 7 \times 11 \times 13 \times 41$

9655ebe3-9902-4861-8845-101b9e7173f2.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
