Let $f$ be continuous everywhere on their domains, except possibly for some finite number of discontinuities of the first kind in every finite subinterval of $\hointr 0 \to$.
{{explain|Establish whether it is "finite subinterval" that is needed here, or what we have already defined as "Subdivision (Real Analysis)/Finite". Also get the correct instance of "continuous".}}
Let $f$ have a (finite) limit at infinity.
Then $f$ is of exponential order $0$.

ed4310bd-1906-4ebb-83ca-357a8b83f22f.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an algebraic structure.
Let $\RR$ be a congruence for $\circ$ on $S$.
Then:
:$\forall X, Y \in S / \RR: X \circ_\PP Y \subseteq X \circ_\RR Y$
where:
:$S / \RR$ is the quotient of $S$ by $\RR$
:$\circ_\PP$ is the operation induced on $\powerset S$ by $\circ$
:$\circ_\RR$ is the operation induced on $S / \RR$ by $\circ$

b12d32d3-23e5-4b22-960a-332be92101a9.text: :$\dfrac 1 {x^4 + a^4} = \dfrac {x + a \sqrt 2} {2 a^3 \sqrt 2 \paren {x^2 + a x \sqrt 2 + a^2} } - \dfrac {x - a \sqrt 2} {2 a^3 \sqrt 2 \paren {x^2 - a x \sqrt 2 + a^2} }$

066cd08e-6fdf-467f-b934-5dd76ab71e2c.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a bounded below continuous lattice.
Let $x, z \in S$ such that
:$x \ll z$
Then
:$\exists y \in S: x \ll y \land y \ll z$

2b4e9a6e-d400-44a9-aca1-27472ffa1c28.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $a \in A$.
Let $\epsilon, \delta \in \R_{>0}$ such that $\epsilon < \delta$.
Let $\map {B^-_\epsilon} a$ be the closed $\epsilon$-ball on $a$.
Let $\map {B_\delta} a$ be the open $\delta$-ball on $a$.
Then:
:$\map {B^-_\epsilon} a \subseteq \map {B_\delta} a$

a9772b9b-7e08-465a-980f-5493442191f0.text:
Let $\struct {\C, +}$ be the additive group of complex numbers.
Let $\struct {\R, +}$ be the additive group of real numbers.
Let $f: \C \to \R$ be the mapping from the complex numbers to the real numbers defined as:
:$\forall z \in \C: \map f z = \map \Im z$
where $\map \Im z$ denotes the imaginary part of $z$.
Then $f: \struct {\C, +} \to \struct {\R, +}$ is a group epimorphism.
Its kernel is the set:
:$\map \ker f = \R$
of (wholly) real numbers.

3b0c7c5f-0c21-4147-96ee-2bf282ac4797.text: A Tusi couple is a degenerate case of the hypocycloid whose form is a straight line that forms a diameter of the stator.

cc162548-00a8-499c-b4d9-514c8478c1e1.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Let $a \in R$ and let $-a$ be the ring negative of $a$.
Then:
:$-\paren {-a} = a$

c65aa954-5293-4f13-b4c5-677774d32d1b.text:
Let $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ be the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) topology.
Then $\tau_d$ can be given by a quasimetric defined as:
:$\map d {x, y} = \begin {cases}
y - x & : y \ge x \\
2 \paren {x - y} & : y < x \end {cases}$
Thus $\struct {\R, \tau_d}$ is a quasimetric space.

0afbe012-f2f8-4044-8dad-7c824a2868da.text:
Let $V$ be a basic universe.
Let $A$ and $B$ be classes of $V$:
:$A \subseteq V, B \subseteq V$
such that it is not the case that $A = B = \O$.
Let $\ds \bigcap A$ and $\ds \bigcap B$ denote the intersection of $A$ and intersection of $B$ respectively.
Let $A$ be a subclass of $B$:
:$A \subseteq B$
Then $\ds \bigcap B$ is a subset of $\ds \bigcap A$:
:$\ds \bigcap B \subseteq \bigcap A$

b5cdbb22-7859-4e18-8218-846d5f6a5e3e.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a real function which satisfies the Dirichlet conditions on $\R$.
Let $f$ be continuous at $t \in \R$.
Then:
:$\ds \map f t = \int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{2 \pi i t s} \paren {\int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-2 \pi i d t} \map f t \rd t} \rd s$

c170cf3d-55e1-4155-8c97-0c7de23c4c3b.text:
Let $a \in \R_{>0}$ be a strictly positive real constant.
Let $\size x < a$.
Then:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^2 - a^2} = \dfrac 1 {2 a} \map \ln {\dfrac {a - x} {a + x} } + C$

c781c809-3518-48d9-bb46-572bf8079174.text:
The '''empty set''' can be formed by application of the comprehension principle.
Hence the '''empty set''' can be derived as a valid object in Frege set theory.

7ffc8fee-07fd-41a8-ac94-217b77f81f72.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let $x, y \in G$.
Let $y H$ denote the left coset of $H$ by $y$.
Then:
:$x \in y H \iff x^{-1} y \in H$

3b300522-cec4-426a-8cfb-af1c2377c562.text:
Let $\left({X, d}\right)$ and $\left({Y, e}\right)$ be metric spaces.
Let $f: X \to Y$ be a mapping.
Let $x \in X$.
Then $f$ is continuous at $x$ {{iff}} $f$ is sequentially continuous at $x$.

377a1149-252e-4354-acdb-0d24c7b7ada3.text:
Let $y = \map f x$ be a real function which is continuous on the closed interval $\closedint a b$ and continuously differentiable on the open interval $\openint a b$.
The definite integral: 
:$s = \ds \int_{x \mathop = a}^{x \mathop = b} \sqrt {1 + \paren {\frac {\d y} {\d x} }^2} \rd x$
exists, and is called the '''arc length''' of $f$ between $a$ and $b$.

fc95e4c3-c6e1-4147-a283-d7f4cbb662d9.text:
:$\ds \map \ln {1 + x} = x \, {}_2 \map {F_1} {1, 1; 2; -x}$
where:
:$x$ is a real number with $\size x < 1$
:${}_2 F_1$ denotes the Gaussian hypergeometric function.

ee6e4f37-58af-402a-9808-d5fa113588e5.text:
Let $f$ be a real function defined on an interval $I$.
If $f$ is not continuous at $x_0$, $f$ is not differentiable at $x_0$.

3bdcfec7-04c6-42fc-a999-ee66cb196a55.text:
Let $\C$ denote the complex numbers.
Let $f$ and $g$ be complex functions which are continuous on an open subset $S \subseteq \C$.
Then:
:$f g$ is continuous on $S$
where $f g$ denotes the pointwise product of $f$ and $g$.

8b215f3d-cbc4-4e82-ac8e-2eb0151c2154.text:
Discounting the trivial solution:
:$1^2 = 1 = 0^3 + 1^3$
$9$ is the only square number which is the sum of $2$ consecutive positive cube numbers:
:$3^2 = 9 = 1^3 + 2^3$

3b5231dc-f486-48ad-baca-aef99b7d9cd9.text:
Let $A$ be a finite class.
Then $A$ is a set.

660b0bcd-7083-4af7-a8e2-abcc8eb3c121.text:
Let $H : \R \to \closedint 0 1$ be the Heaviside step function.
Let $T \in \map {\DD'} \R$ be a distribution corresponding to $H$.
Let $\delta \in \map {\DD'} \R$ be the Dirac delta distribution.
Then the distributional derivative of $T$ is $\delta$.

4beefb35-467e-4602-9301-6a452fe9202b.text:
Let $A_1, A_2, \dotsc, A_n$ be sets.
Let:
:$\forall k \in \set {2, 3, \dotsc, n}: A_{k - 1} \subseteq A_k$
and:
:$A_n \subseteq A_1$
Then:
:$\forall j, k \in \set {1, 2, \dotsc, n}: A_j = A_k$

d6889680-3842-4acd-8d93-d4f7590344f0.text:
Let $\Gamma$ denote the gamma function.
Then:
:$\forall z \notin \set {-\dfrac n 2: n \in \N}: \map \Gamma z \map \Gamma {z + \dfrac 1 2} = 2^{1 - 2 z} \sqrt \pi \, \map \Gamma {2 z}$
where $\N$ denotes the natural numbers.

925cfdd6-472c-4b9f-842f-9a36f43703dd.text:
Let $\struct {Y, \preceq, \tau}$ be a generalized ordered space (GO-space) by Definition 3.
That is:
:let $\struct {Y, \tau}$ be a Hausdorff space
and:
:let $\tau$ have a sub-basis consisting of upper sets and lower sets relative to $\preceq$.
Then $\struct {Y, \preceq, \tau}$ is a GO-space by Definition 2.
That is, there is a linearly ordered space $\struct {X, \preceq', \tau'}$ and a mapping from $Y$ to $X$ which is a order embedding and a topological embedding.

7b4ae963-2479-4565-8ede-140c62d01437.text:
Let $\delta \in \map {\DD'} \R$ be the Dirac delta distribution.
Then for any $n \in \N$ the set of distributional derivatives $\set {\delta, \delta' \ldots, \delta^{\paren n} }$ is linearly independent in $\map {\DD'} \R$.

c59e7853-a143-480b-91b3-efc1b7fd1c6d.text:
Let $A$ be a class, which may be either a set or a proper class.
Then:
:$\forall A: \paren {A \in U \iff \exists x: x = A}$
where $U$ is the universal class.

6d60f57c-b04b-4fc3-8169-f8e4f598a0d1.text:
Let $S$ be a system of $n$ homogeneous simultaneous linear equations in $n$ variables:
:$\displaystyle \forall i \in \set {1, 2, \ldots, n}: \sum_{j \mathop = 1}^n \alpha_{i j} x_j = 0$
$S$ has a non-trivial solution {{iff}} its reduced echelon matrix $R$ is not equal to the unit matrix $\mathbf I_n$.

b882055e-0a50-41ef-867f-bf43cee247df.text:
Let $\mathbf C$ be a metacategory.
Let $f: C \to D$ be an isomorphism of $\mathbf C$.
Then $f$ admits a unique inverse morphism $g: D \to C$.

92d23aba-0f72-4af5-9456-75fa2b5d221c.text:
Let $\C$ denote the complex numbers.
Let $f$ and $g$ be complex functions which are continuous on an open subset $S \subseteq \C$.
Then:
:$f + g$ is ‎continuous on $S$.

9024cd82-0ffc-4e07-8944-4c35696c0a90.text:
Let $T$ be a $T_{3 \frac 1 2}$ space.
Then $T$ is also a $T_3$ space.

90762495-5501-45be-a81b-451e622cf128.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring whose zero is $0_R$.
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$ be an $R$-module.
Let $H \subseteq G$ such that $e \in H$.
Then $H$ is a linearly dependent set.

9ae45382-9d95-4660-9aa7-20809fc83cea.text:
Let $\CC$ be a circle whose radius is $r$ and whose center is at the origin of a Cartesian plane.
Let $P = \tuple {x_1, y_1}$ be a point on $\CC$.
Let $\NN$ be a normal to $\CC$ passing through $P$.
Then $\NN$ can be defined by the equation:
:$y_1 x - x_1 y = 0$

52ed0b09-da99-491a-a0b4-34352cfde5bf.text:
Let $S \subseteq \C$ be an open subset of the complex plane $\C$.
Then the complement of $S$ in $\C$ is closed.

dd1b2e95-7b7a-442c-9f69-739aed871fc1.text:
The universal cover of a Riemann surface is conformally isomorphic to either:
:the Riemann sphere
:the complex plane
or
:the unit disk.

f4111609-e66b-4a35-b867-4c44be857895.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a strictly positive integer.
Let $\map w n$ denote the number of primes strictly less than $n$ which are not divisors of $n$.
Let $\map \phi n$ denote the Euler $\phi$ function of $n$.
Then $30$ is the largest integer $n$ such that:
:$\map w n = \map \phi n - 1$

99052c55-776d-4fe4-8dfc-3f400e43c145.text: A coreflexive relation is a subset of the diagonal relation.

d140da61-53b7-417e-bcd0-e8788a966c3d.text:
Let $\R$ be the set of real numbers.
Let $\BB$ be the set of subsets of $\R$ defined as:
:$\BB = \set {\openint a b: a, b \in \R}$
That is, $\BB$ is the set of all open real intervals of $\R$:
:$\openint a b := \set {x \in \R: a < x < b}$
Then $\BB$ forms a basis for the Euclidean topology on $\R$.

ded2fa22-9944-492c-80ad-917177a2ee21.text:
Let $A$ and $B$ be non-empty sets of real numbers.
Let $A + B$ be $\set {x + y: x \in A, y \in B}$.
Let either $A$ and $B$ have suprema or $A + B$ have a supremum.
Then all $\sup A$, $\sup B$, and $\sup \paren {A + B}$ exist and:
:$\sup \paren {A + B} = \sup A + \sup B$

4ece345e-53ba-48d0-9c20-9c7544432f7a.text: The $n$th prime number is approximately $n \ln n$.

d2f75811-3212-42df-bc1d-52811559bfd8.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an algebraic structure with identity $e$.
Let $\struct {T, \circ}$ be a algebraic substructure of $\struct {S, \circ}$.
That is, let $T \subseteq S$.
Let $e \in T$.
Then $e$ is an identity of $\struct {T, \circ}$.

8bd378d9-141f-43b0-b958-febdab8a9f48.text: The power set of a set is a sigma-algebra.

9a2fe33a-c943-433d-9e15-5f0ae50c4d4b.text:
:$\ds \int \map \sin {a x + b} \rd x = -\frac {\map \cos {a x + b} } a + C$
where $a$ is a non-zero constant.

bc0ee82c-e965-4c9c-bd7e-33ba8444d8e2.text:
Let $a, b$ be real numbers with $a < b$.
Let $f, g : \closedint a b \to \R$ be functions of bounded variation.
Let $V_f$ and $V_g$ be the total variations of $f$ and $g$ respectively. 
Then $f - g$ is of bounded variation with:
:$V_{f - g} \le V_f + V_g$
where $V_{f - g}$ denotes the total variation of $f - g$.

04e2dc6c-78d8-4916-9cd5-c0312c5b9369.text:
The function:
:$\dfrac {\sinh x} x$ 
is increasing for positive real $x$.

b4d9bebc-dcc0-49e4-b2dd-3c01448ed583.text:
The sum of any finite number of even integers is itself even.
{{EuclidPropStatement|book=IX|prop=21|body=If as many even numbers as we please be added together, the whole is even.}}

5d3c47f9-e475-4567-ba28-b7fd3df207b8.text:
Let $p$ be an odd prime.
Let $a \in \Z$ be an integer such that $a \not \equiv 0 \pmod p$.
Let $a \equiv b \pmod p$.
Then $a$ and $b$ have the same quadratic character.

1a9aa0b0-2992-4198-b096-4670f4e6a2b0.text:
Let $p$ be prime and $n \in \Z: n \ge 1$.
Then:
:$\map \phi {p n} = \begin{cases}
\paren {p - 1} \map \phi n & : p \nmid n \\
p \map \phi n & : p \divides n 
\end{cases}$
where:
:$\map \phi n$ denotes the Euler $\phi$ function of $n$
:$\divides$ denotes divisibility.
Thus for all $n \ge 1$ and for any prime $p$, we have that $\map \phi n$ divides $\map \phi {p n}$.

77378371-9a8b-47b6-9640-2b7458a2b3ef.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ and $K$ be subgroups of $G$.
Let $K$ act on the left coset space $G / H^l$ by:
:$\forall \tuple {k, g H} \in K \times G / H^l: k * g H := \paren {k g} H$
The length of the orbit of $g H$ is $\index K {K \cap H^g}$.

1c09b8f7-8561-49cc-80a0-cf29f0014e32.text:
Let $x \in \R_{\ge 0}$ have a representation $S$ in the golden mean number system.
Then $S$ can be converted to its simplest form as follows:
:$(1): \quad$ Replace any infinite string on the right hand end of $S$ of the form $010101 \ldots$ with $100$
:$(2): \quad$ Repeatedly replace the leftmost instance of $011$ with $100$.

fd377e3a-7e09-402f-9f09-9f62666a6ab7.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer such that $n > 3$.
Then $n! > n^2$.

9beb4c83-4ce2-403d-bbb5-aa96e355d98f.text:
$\struct {\On, \times, \le}$ forms an ordered semigroup, where:
: $\On$ denotes the ordinal class, and
: $\times$ denotes ordinal multiplication.

11d83768-bdb0-4140-89e2-0c129a28f0f3.text:
Let $G$ be a topological group.
Let $H\leq G$ be a subgroup.
Let $\overline H$ denote its closure.
Then $\overline H$ is a subgroup of $G$.

be0856a2-5242-43c4-aa39-ba2cda88540b.text:
Let $U \subset \C$ be a domain.
Let $z_0 \in U$.
Let $f: U \setminus \set {z_0} \to \C$ be holomorphic.
Then the following are equivalent:
:$(1): \quad f$ extends to a holomorphic function $f: U \to \C$.
:$(2): \quad f$ extends to a continuous function $f: U \to \C$.
:$(3): \quad f$ is bounded in a neighborhood of $z_0$.
:$(4): \quad \map f z = \map o {\dfrac 1 {\cmod {z - z_0} } }$ as $z \to z_0$.

feca23a7-1534-4a2b-9d19-e0c92e7c77af.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Let $T^*$ be the set of all upper bounds of $T$ in $S$.
Then $T^* \cap T \ne \O$ {{iff}}:
:$T$ has a greatest element $M$
and
:$T^* \cap T$ is a singleton such that $T^* \cap T = \set M$

6f57a982-e8b4-4d19-9388-22192babbfa0.text:
Let $G \left({z}\right)$ be the generating function for the sequence $\left\langle{a_n}\right\rangle$.
Let $m \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $\omega = e^{2 i \pi / m} = \cos \dfrac {2 \pi} m + i \sin \dfrac {2 \pi} m$.
Then for $r \in \Z$ such that $0 \le r < m$:
:$\displaystyle \sum_{n \bmod m \mathop = r} a_n z^n = \dfrac 1 m \sum_{0 \mathop \le k \mathop < m} \omega^{-k r} G \left({\omega^k z}\right)$

b7d88cab-a61f-4b18-abf8-7c7786b0763e.text: The intersection of two symmetric relations is also a symmetric relation.

c1e5b572-b282-4aa6-9bb5-d87eba80bbd3.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma, \mu}$ be a measure space.
Let $f: X \to \R, f \in \EE^+$ be a positive simple function.
Let $\lambda \in \R_{\ge 0}$ be a positive real number.
Then:
:$\map {I_\mu} {\lambda \cdot f} = \map {\lambda \cdot I_\mu} f$
where:
:$\lambda \cdot f$ is the pointwise $\lambda$-multiple of $f$
:$I_\mu$ denotes $\mu$-integration.
This can be summarized by saying that $I_\mu$ is positive homogeneous.

63887690-5864-405f-a6ee-5e04104f9cf9.text:
Let $m \in \Z$ be an integer.
Then addition modulo $m$ has inverses:
For each element $\eqclass x m \in \Z_m$, there exists the element $\eqclass {-x} m \in \Z_m$ with the property:
:$\eqclass x m +_m \eqclass {-x} m = \eqclass 0 m = \eqclass {-x} m +_m \eqclass x m$
where $\Z_m$ is the set of integers modulo $m$.
That is:
:$\forall a \in \Z: a + \paren {-a} \equiv 0 \equiv \paren {-a} + a \pmod m$

1f5d6fba-7940-446d-8c35-eb59c89f25db.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $x \in S$.
Let every open neighborhood $U$ of $x$ contain an open neighborhood $V$ of $x$ such that every two points of $V$ lie in some connected subset of $U$.
Then:
:$x$ has a neighborhood basis consisting of connected sets.

81abdf2f-2b3e-4889-9de3-cf898ee71507.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $H_1$ and $H_2$ be subsets of $S$.
Let ${H_1}^-$ and ${H_2}^-$ denote the closures of $H_1$ and $H_2$ respectively.
Then it is not necessarily the case that:
:$\paren {H_1 \cap H_2}^- = {H_1}^- \cap {H_2}^-$

158064e6-2650-4368-a540-7703b7716452.text:
The equation:
:$x^p = y^2 + 1$
has no solution in the integers for $x, y, p > 1$.

7f8741e1-5c06-4227-9407-52c2f95e9433.text:
:$x \le \ceiling x < x + 1$
where $\ceiling x$ is the ceiling of $x$.

79eb4c33-4091-4572-a67f-e270d5eba753.text:
Let $\RR$ be a relation on a set $S$.
If $\RR$ is reflexive, then so is $\RR^{-1}$.

c2631add-6afb-4b33-802f-751915c280a1.text:
Let $\sequence {a_k}$ be a sequence of non-zero complex numbers such that:
:$\cmod {a_n} \to \infty$ as $n \to \infty$
Let $\sequence {p_n}$ be a sequence of non-negative integers for which the series:
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \size {\dfrac r {a_n} }^{1 + p_n}$
converges for every $r \in \R_{> 0}$.
Let:
:$\ds \map f z = \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \map {E_{p_n} } {\frac z {a_n} }$
where $E_{p_n}$ are Weierstrass elementary factors.
Then $f$ is entire and its zeroes are the points $a_n$, counted with multiplicity.

416bb0dc-2e59-4f7c-8f39-213e9561eebe.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a semigroup with a left identity $e_L$ such that:
:$\forall x \in S: \exists x_L: x_L \circ x = e_L$
That is, every element of $S$ has a left inverse with respect to the left identity.
Then $e_L$ is also a right identity, that is, is an identity.

70aa0c0f-91dd-4361-98ba-a83672b6ecae.text:
Let $\tuple {X, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\tuple {Y, d'}$ be a complete metric space.
Let $A \subseteq X$ be a set that is not closed.
Let $f : A \to Y$ be a uniformly continuous function.
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be a sequence in $A$ convergent to $a \in A^-$. 
Then $\sequence {\map f {a_n} }$ converges.

07669e2f-5e64-4d31-a746-d222bdb86dab.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Then:
:$2 \le k \le p - 1 \implies \dbinom {p + 1} k \equiv 0 \pmod p$
where $\dbinom {p + 1} k$ denotes a binomial coefficient.

9c2d1016-4b79-485f-99c0-a79c5ddbfbb8.text:
{{Cross-Relation Quotient Structure Inverse Completion Context Definition}}
Let the mapping $\psi: S \to T'$ be defined as:
:$\forall x \in S: \map \psi x = \eqclass {\tuple {x \circ a, a} } \boxtimes$
Then $\psi: S \to T'$ is an injection, and does not depend on the particular element $a$ chosen.

b861e13d-550b-4bb4-9ef3-104ae414faf7.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a Hausdorff space.
Let $X \subseteq S$ such that $X$ is finite.
Let $x \in X$.
Then $x$ is isolated in $X$.

364bccea-da9f-428b-bbff-d9dda368fbd3.text:
Let $S = \set {a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_r} \subseteq \Z$ be a finite subset of the integers.
Let $S$ be pairwise coprime.
Let:
:$\forall j \in \set {1, 2, \ldots, r}: a_r \divides b$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.
Then:
:$\ds \prod_{j \mathop = 1}^r a_j \divides b$

29bc36e0-d9cb-46c3-bd10-2cbcf1a90fad.text:
Let $\tuple {L, R}$ be a Dedekind cut of the set of real numbers $\R$.
Then either $L$ contains a largest number or $R$ contains a smallest number.

654d66f7-8f66-4177-97f5-709b5ec92ccb.text:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to \infty} \map \erfc x = 0$
where $\erfc$ denotes the complementary error function.

094e5e68-5433-4917-a25a-c3ba183c3cc7.text: The axiom of dependent choice implies the axiom of countable choice.

792360de-3dae-441f-894b-6f30536785d4.text:
Let $G$ be an $n$-dimensional vector space over a field.
Let $G^*$ be the algebraic dual of $G$.
Let $M$ be an $m$-dimensional subspace of $G$.
Let $M^\circ$ be the annihilator of $M$.
Then:
:$M^\circ$ is an $\paren {n - m}$-dimensional subspace of $G^*$.

bc3af590-3652-484e-acb1-e268f62be720.text:
Let $a \in \R$ be a real number such that $a > 1$.
Let $f: \Z \to \R$ be the real-valued function defined as:
:$\map f k = a^k$
where $a^k$ denotes $a$ to the power of $k$.
Then $f$ is strictly decreasing.

45a50917-2ada-440f-9674-24670d277999.text:
Let $\map a n$ be any finite periodic function on $\Z$ with period $b$.
Let $\xi = e^{2 \pi i/ b}$ be the first $b$th root of unity.
Then:
:$\ds \map a n = \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{b - 1} \map {a_*} k \xi^{n k}$
where:
:$\ds \map {a_*} n = \frac 1 b \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^{b - 1} \map a k \xi^{-n k}$

69d807da-ee32-4420-a1d4-74ea392758cc.text:
Let $S = \sequence {s_n}$ be the sequence of fractions defined as follows:
Let the numerator of $s_n$ be:
:$\floor {n \sqrt 2}$
where $\floor x$ denotes the floor of $x$.
Let the denominators of the terms of $S$ be the (strictly) positive integers missing from the numerators of $S$:
:$S := \dfrac 1 3, \dfrac 2 6, \dfrac 4 {10}, \dfrac 5 {13}, \dfrac 7 {17}, \dfrac 8 {20}, \ldots$
Then the difference between the numerator and denominator of $s_n$ is equal to $2 n$.

128d953d-41ec-42f1-8ebc-cb1633eed5c8.text:
Let $Q_n = \sequence {a_j}_{0 \mathop \le j \mathop \le n}$ be a geometric sequence of integers.
Let $j \ne k$.
Then:
:$\paren {\exists j \in \set {0, 1, \ldots, n - 1}: a_j \divides a_{j + 1} } \iff \paren {\forall j, k \in \set {0, 1, \ldots, n}, j < k: a_j \divides a_k}$
where $\divides$ denotes integer divisibility.
That is:
:One term of a geometric sequence of integers is the divisor of the next term
{{iff}}
:All terms are divisors of all later terms.

e1dbaac3-09e1-4c35-8740-52dc49495395.text:
:$\ds \int \cot^2 x \rd x = -\cot x - x + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

6ccc9c47-82d7-4b2f-9ebd-37f2588e33c8.text: The number of Sylow $p$-subgroups of a finite group is congruent to $1 \pmod p$.

cd49d447-306a-4961-beb7-739e23f40d1e.text:
Let $\struct {S, \tau}$ be a $T_5$ space.
Then $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also a $T_4$ space.

285eb8f6-4ad5-4bca-a2ec-1ed19e20a100.text:
Let $p \in \R$ be a real number.
Then the $p$-series:
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty n^{-p}$
is convergent {{iff}} $p > 1$.

9e84eb70-45bc-4269-abc2-f57ad520a7d0.text:
Let $\ln$ be the natural logarithm function on the real numbers.
Then the image of $\ln$ is the set of real numbers:
:$\Img \ln = \R$

81e007f9-5fcd-43b1-8b06-2afa7245cadd.text:
Let $a, b, c \in R$ where $a < b < c$.
Let $A$ be the union of the two adjacent open intervals:
:$A := \openint a b \cup \openint b c$
Then:
:$A^- = \closedint a c$
where:
:$A^-$ is the closure of $A$.

7b2ce615-46c8-477e-891f-ab0dc999ac9a.text: For all $z \in \Z$, congruence modulo $z$ is an equivalence relation.

a4d218d3-d658-40c2-8d72-14091b0a3220.text:
Let $\family {\struct {S_i, \tau_i} }_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an $I$-indexed family of topological spaces.
Let $S$ be the cartesian product of $\family {S_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$.
That is:
:$\ds S := \prod_{i \mathop \in I} S_i$
Define:
:$\ds \BB := \set {\prod_{i \mathop \in I} U_i: \forall i \in I: U_i \in \tau_i}$
Then $\BB$ is a synthetic basis on $S$.

b168aa84-d857-4963-99c7-5518a1df2745.text:
Let $r \in \R_{> 0}$ be a positive real number.
Let $n, m \in \Z_{\ge 0}$ be positive integers.
Let $r^n$ be defined as $r$ to the power of $n$.
Then:
:$\paren {r^n}^m = r^{n m}$

eb1c61b2-8be0-4cbc-9ef7-451b8d3468a3.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
:$x^{\overline 0} = 1$
where $x^{\overline 0}$ denotes the rising factorial.

a2445486-29ca-42b3-a91c-b02831af0781.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}, k \in \Z$.
Then:
:$\dbinom n k = \dbinom n {n - k}$
where $\dbinom n k$ is a binomial coefficient.

c5547c90-746f-4406-83fa-73a604258f9e.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T^*_p = \struct {S^*_p, \tau^*_p}$ be the closed extension space of $T$.
Then the closed sets of $T^*_p$ (apart from $S^*_p$) are the closed sets of $T$.
This explains why $\tau^*_p$ is called the closed extension topology of $\tau$.

af5274a2-e51a-4ca6-b916-e9f699c8e178.text: The square root of $2$ is an algebraic number of degree $2$.

d5e005f6-89ec-42b1-8e31-ed91ff1e6a78.text:
Let $x \ge 2$ be a real number.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{p \mathop \le x} \frac {\ln p} p \paren {\int_p^x \frac 1 {t \ln^2 t} \rd t} = \int_2^x \frac 1 {t \ln^2 t} \paren {\sum_{p \mathop \le t} \frac {\ln p} p} \rd t$
where: 
:$\ds \sum_{p \mathop \le x}$ sums over the primes less than or equal to $x$.

1fc954c4-19b9-4d6b-ae10-82550fd1f81f.text:
Let $n$ be a natural number.
Then $n$ is a transitive set.

35856a55-77b5-4640-bafd-85446a7921ea.text:
Let $\mathbf a$ be a vector quantity.
Let $m$ be a scalar quantity.
Then:
:$m \mathbf a = m \paren {\size {\mathbf a} \hat {\mathbf a} } = \paren {m \size {\mathbf a} } \hat {\mathbf a}$
where:
:$\size {\mathbf a}$ denotes the magnitude of $\mathbf a$
:$\hat {\mathbf a}$ denotes the unit vector in the direction $\mathbf a$.

f1f0ac3e-a34f-4518-8239-bcae72a438b8.text: The set of integers $\Z$ is not well-ordered under the usual ordering $\le$.

1a02d3bb-468c-49c8-ba3b-2c9f052785dd.text:
Let $A$ and $B$ be subsets of a universal set $\Bbb U$.
Let $\uparrow$ denote the operation on $A$ and $B$ defined as:
:$\paren {A \uparrow B} \iff \paren {\relcomp {\Bbb U} {A \cap B} }$
where $\relcomp {\Bbb U} A$ denotes the complement of $A$ in $\Bbb U$.
Then:
:$A \cap B = \paren {A \uparrow B} \uparrow \paren {A \uparrow B}$

cba1214e-4ed2-499a-9f18-9a02ad6f238a.text:
Let $\alpha \in \R$ be a real number which is specifically not an integer.
Then:
:$\pi \cosec \pi \alpha = \dfrac 1 \alpha + \ds 2 \sum_{n \mathop \ge 1} \paren {-1}^n \dfrac {\alpha} {\alpha^2 - n^2}$

12608204-b36b-44c9-bff0-cc49762d50fc.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $x \notin \Z$.
Then:
:$\left\lfloor{x}\right\rfloor < x$
where $\left\lfloor{x}\right\rfloor$ denotes the floor of $x$.

bf1d5a7e-2ac1-43d0-89ce-55b24ac9d7f6.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=67|body=A straight line commensurable in length with a bimedial straight line is itself also bimedial and the same in order.}}

37d34fd4-4a7b-4fe6-921d-c6a749eb6846.text:
Let $C_n$ be a (finite) cyclic group of order $n$.
Then $C_n$ has $\map \phi n$ generators, where $\map \phi n$ denotes the Euler $\phi$ function.

dd70ea06-1c6f-4659-8654-7bb7fe0e94fd.text:
Let $f, g$ are permutations of a set $S$.
Then their composite $g \circ f$ is also a permutation of $S$.

ab40fa63-56ee-46de-b5e4-77064b60f32a.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is strictly concave on the open interval $I$.
Let $J = f \sqbrk I$.
If $f$ be strictly increasing on $I$, then $f^{-1}$ is strictly convex on $J$.

b0defc00-ceda-4b02-a07b-c6c6c2bce373.text:
Let $m$ and $n$ be ordinals.
Then it is not the case that $m \in n$ and $n \in m$.

9c59bab6-9669-40fb-a697-e5b52b71329b.text: The set $\N$ of natural numbers is infinite.

e7f83dd2-1217-42d4-9747-333d83c136c8.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be an irreducible topological space.
Let $U$ be a non-empty open set of $T$.
Then $U$ is irreducible in its induced subspace topology.

8746f9bc-ed28-4467-bcd4-5856808e0a92.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, *, \norm {\,\cdot\,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $d$ be the metric induced by the norm $\norm {\,\cdot\,}$.
Let $R^* = R \setminus \set 0$
Let $d^*$ be the subspace metric on $R^*$.
Then the mapping:
:$\iota : \struct {R^* ,d^*} \to \struct {R, d} : \map \iota x = x^{-1}$ 
is continuous.

f9e41ea1-01bf-40dd-b80d-22d661311da6.text:
thumb
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to \infty} \paren {x - \map \Gamma {\dfrac 1 x} } = \gamma$
where:
:$\Gamma$ denotes the $\Gamma$ (Gamma) function
:$\gamma$ denotes the Euler-Mascheroni constant.

89f2cd32-ee0e-405c-9bb9-775d49865ba3.text:
Let $S$ be the set of all complex functions $f: \C \to \C$ which preserve distance when embedded in the complex plane.
That is:
:$\size {\map f a - \map f b} = \size {a - b}$
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be the algebraic structure formed from $S$ and the composition operation $\circ$.
Then $\struct {S, \circ}$ is a group.

28016647-8368-4eb8-8089-f018a4f5f49b.text:
Let $\struct {\Z, +}$ denote the additive group of integers.
Let $m, n \in \Z_{> 0}$ be (strictly) positive integers.
Let $\struct {\Z \times \Z, +}$ denote the Cartesian product of $\struct {\Z, +}$ with itself.
The subgroups of $\struct {\Z \times \Z, +}$ are not all of the form:
:$\struct {m \Z, +} \times \struct {n \Z, +}$
where $\struct {m \Z, +}$ denotes the additive group of integer multiples of $m$.

b326c071-dbf5-4050-9e99-8d09501d247e.text: The Riemann zeta function $\zeta$ has a unique analytic continuation to $\C\setminus\{1\}$.

3bbe2dfe-b83d-4f76-9c1d-c249ea1942fe.text:
Let $x$ be an ordinal.
Then $x \notin x$.

23d04db1-0871-43f4-acbf-1587fd542094.text:
Let $z \in \C$ be a complex number.
Then:
:$e^{i z} = \cos z + i \sin z$
where:
:$e^{i z}$ denotes the complex exponential function
:$\cos z$ denotes the complex cosine function
:$\sin z$ denotes complex sine function
:$i$ denotes the imaginary unit.

dbd2e7a4-5309-463e-8087-31ed82f25997.text:
:$\cos^5 x = \dfrac {10 \cos x + 5 \cos 3 x + \cos 5 x} {16}$
where $\cos$ denotes cosine.

bedceeb5-0bed-4b0b-82ff-7d486a7f19ed.text: The divisor counting function is primitive recursive.

2addb960-1669-421b-897c-bf21a6165104.text:
Let $\family {a_i}_{i \mathop \in I}, \family {b_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be $I$-indexed families of positive real numbers.
That is, let $a_i, b_i \in \R_{\ge 0}$ for all $i \in I$.
Suppose that for all $i \in I$, $a_i \le b_i$.
Furthermore, suppose that $\ds \sum \set {b_i: i \in I}$ converges.
Then:
:$\ds \sum \set {a_i: i \in I} \le \sum \set {b_i: i \in I}$
In particular, $\ds \sum \set {a_i: i \in I}$ converges.

d3357cd4-9cb7-40f3-b133-69f49010ef21.text:
Let $F_k$ be the $k$th Fibonacci number.
Then:
:${F_n}^2 - F_{n - r} F_{n + r} = \left({-1}\right)^{n - r} {F_r}^2$

480d43a4-afc0-4109-a896-ba64e38bdb2c.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\BB$ be the set of all open balls of $M$.
Then $\BB$ is a basis for the open sets of $M$.

0803b4c2-adb7-4891-81c6-6db4b1a53e7c.text:
Let $\struct {\Z, +}$ be the additive group of integers.
Let $\struct {\Q, +}$ be the additive group of rational numbers.
Then $\struct {\Z, +}$ is a normal subgroup of $\struct {\Q, +}$.

ad9fae0d-8e07-47f9-a831-8372fb7bd6a7.text:
Let $\R^n$ be a real vector space.
Let $\mathbb W \subseteq \R^n$.
Then $\mathbb W$ is a linear subspace of $\R^n$ {{iff}}:
:$(1): \quad \mathbf 0 \in \mathbb W$, where $\mathbf 0$ is the zero vector with $n$ entries
:$(2): \quad \mathbb W$ is closed under vector addition
:$(3): \quad \mathbb W$ is closed under scalar multiplication.

0e16f16b-1bea-4f39-93d0-154604971fec.text:
Let:
:$\struct {X_1, d_1}$
:$\struct {X_2, d_2}$
:$\struct {X_3, d_3}$
be metric spaces.
Let:
:$\phi: \struct {X_1, d_1} \to \struct {X_2, d_2}$
:$\psi: \struct {X_2, d_2} \to \struct {X_3, d_3}$
be isometries.
Then the composite of $\phi$ and $\psi$ is also an isometry.

0e291988-1678-4f3e-b357-652ce96f8e49.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a complete lattice.
Let $x, z \in S$.
Let $\mathcal R$ be an auxiliary approximating relation on $S$ such that
:$\left({x, z}\right) \in \mathcal R \land x \ne z$
Then
:$\exists y \in S: x \preceq y \land \left({y, z}\right) \in \mathcal R \land x \ne y$

51feba76-3bdc-4dee-8049-57aaa47acd1a.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\floor x$ denote the floor of $x$.
Then:
:$\ds \floor {\sqrt {\floor x} } = \floor {\sqrt x}$

8091d31e-00a5-48a7-a1f4-42fff2cabdb8.text:
Let $m, n \in \Z_{>0}$ be strictly positive integers.
Let $\struct {\Z, +}$ denote the additive group of integers.
Let $\struct {\Z_m, +_m}$ and $\struct {\Z_n, +_n}$ denote the additive groups of integers modulo $m$ and $n$ respectively.
Let $f: \Z \to \Z_n$ be the quotient epimorphism from $\struct {\Z, +}$ to $\struct {\Z_n, +_n}$.
Let $q: \Z \to \Z_m$ be the quotient epimorphism from $\struct {\Z, +}$ to $\struct {\Z_m, +_m}$.
Then:
:there exists a group homomorphism $\psi: \struct {\Z_m, +_m} \to \struct {\Z_n, +_n}$
{{iff}} 
:$m \divides n$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.

5ce6f534-6169-49e2-aae5-ee432afde83a.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $a \in \C$ be a complex number.
Then:
:$z^n - a = \ds \prod_{k \mathop = 0}^{n - 1} \paren {z - \alpha^k b}$
where:
:$\alpha$ is a primitive complex $n$th root of unity
:$b$ is any complex number such that $b^n = a$.

d64b34ff-4eae-450f-ae7f-90ec468e29f1.text:
Let $\mathbb F \in \set {\R, \C}$.
Let $\HH$ be a Hilbert space over $\mathbb F$ with inner product ${\innerprod \cdot \cdot}_\HH$.
Let $\KK$ be a Hilbert space over $\mathbb F$ with inner product ${\innerprod \cdot \cdot}_\KK$.
Let $A : \HH \to \KK$ be a bounded linear transformation.
Let $B : \KK \to \HH$ be the unique mapping satisfying: 
:$\innerprod {A x} y_\KK = \innerprod x {B y}_\HH$
for each $x \in \HH$ and $y \in \KK$. 
Then <includeonly>W</includeonly><noinclude>w</noinclude>e have: 
:$\map B {\alpha x + \beta y} = \alpha B x + \beta B y$
for all $\alpha, \beta \in \mathbb F$ and $x, y \in \KK$.
That is, $B$ is a linear transformation.

a00e1d48-f240-4199-96a4-ab7d47d72f17.text:
Let $\mathbb F \in \set {\R, \C}$.
Let $\HH$ be a Hilbert space over $\mathbb F$. 
Let $A : \HH \to \HH$ be a bounded Hermitian operator.
Let $\innerprod \cdot \cdot_\HH$ denote the inner product on $\HH$.
Let $\norm \cdot_\HH$ be the inner product norm on $\HH$. 
Then the norm of $A$ satisfies:
:$\norm A = \sup \set {\size {\innerprod {A h} h_\HH}: h \in \HH, \norm h_\HH = 1}$

9f7d133c-9c61-499a-a2fb-bb6c1b8ee9f4.text:
Let $G$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $x, y \in G$ such that:
:$\order x \perp \order y$
where:
:$\order x, \order y$ denotes the orders of $x$ and $y$ in $G$ respectively
:$\perp$ denotes the coprimality relation.
Then:
:$\gen x \cap \gen y = \set e$
where $\gen x, \gen y$ denotes the subgroup of $G$ generated by $x$ and $y$ in $G$ respectively.

236df62a-06ea-4242-b979-8559070d9a93.text:
Let $\struct {\Q, \size {\, \cdot \,}}$ be the normed vector space of rational numbers.
Then $\struct {\Q, \size {\, \cdot \,}}$ is not a Banach space.

a2882886-6873-4c07-b47d-ed2196ca9cce.text:
Let $\map \MM {m, n}$ be a metric space of order $m \times n$ over a field $K$.
Let $\mathbf A \in \map \MM {m, n}$ be a matrix. 
Let $\map e {\mathbf A}$ be the elementary row operation which transforms $\mathbf A$ to a new matrix $\mathbf A' \in \map \MM {m, n}$.
{{begin-axiom}}
{{axiom | n = \text {ERO} 3
        | t = Exchange rows $k$ and $l$
        | m = r_k \leftrightarrow r_l
}}
{{end-axiom}}
Let $\map {e'} {\mathbf A'}$ be the inverse of $e$.
Then $e'$ is the elementary row operation:
:$e' := r_k \leftrightarrow r_l$
That is:
:$e' = e$

edeb0ab5-000c-4ef4-8585-be9e5ca31ea2.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $g \in G$ be an element of $g$.
Let $\order g$ denote the order of $g$ in $G$.
Then:
:$\forall m \in \Z: \order {g^m} = \order g \iff m \perp \order g$
where:
:$g^m$ denotes the $m$th power of $g$ in $G$
:$\perp$ denotes coprimality.

389547c9-2374-4cc9-b354-5df38f52e6f8.text:
Let $G$ be an abelian group whose identity element is $e$.
Let the order of $G$ be $2 n$ such that $n$ is odd.
Then there exists exactly one $g \in G$ with $g \ne e$ such that $g = g^{-1}$.

a4bae8ad-2796-4010-ab6f-016ffc8b743e.text:
Let $H$ be a Hilbert space, and let $h \in H$.
Let $K \subseteq H$ be a closed, convex, non-empty subset of $H$.
Then there is a unique point $k_0 \in K$ such that:
:$\norm {h - k_0} = \map d {h, K}$
where $d$ denotes distance to a set.
{{refactor|Own page, and prove it}}
Furthermore, if $K$ is a linear subspace, this point is characterised by:
:$\norm {h - k_0} = \map d {h, K} \iff \paren {h - k_0} \perp K$
where $\perp$ signifies orthogonality.

887e5f89-a6f2-4d39-98ef-61dea727bf37.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty e^{-a x^2} \rd x = \frac 1 2 \sqrt {\frac \pi a}$
where $a$ is a strictly positive real number.

7026d4d3-3f09-4032-a4a3-cd4cb46726a3.text:
Let $\Z$ be the set of integers.
Let $\le$ be the ordering on the integers.
Let $\O \subset S \subseteq \Z$ such that $S$ is bounded below in $\struct {\Z, \le}$.
Then $S$ has a smallest element.

92baf63f-66b4-4eb7-9c7d-0ae33ed955e5.text:
Let $B_n$ be the Bell number for $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$.
Then:
:$B_n = \ds \sum_{k \mathop = 0}^n {n \brace k}$
where $\ds {n \brace k}$ denotes a Stirling number of the second kind.

ddc3b8c6-ca39-4b1f-bc64-f01afe53e483.text:
Let $\mathbb A$ be one of the standard number systems $\N, \Z, \Q, \R, \C$.
Let $S$ and $T$ be finite sets.
Let $f: S \cup T \to \mathbb A$ be a mapping.
Then we have the equality of summations over finite sets:
:$\ds \sum_{u \mathop \in S \mathop \cup T} \map f u = \sum_{s \mathop \in S} \map f s + \sum_{t \mathop \in T} \map f t - \sum_{v \mathop \in S \mathop \cap T} \map f v$

e0924448-4548-4e61-8bc1-9dab6e82b31d.text:
Let $r \in \R_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive real number.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{x \mathop \to \infty} x^{-r} \ln x = 0$

5297275e-4a4f-46b7-a14c-963d8629585c.text:
Let $\mathbf{Set}$ be the category of sets.
Let $\mathbf C$ be a locally small category.
Let $C \in \mathbf C_0$ be an object of $\mathbf C$.
Let $\hom_\mathbf C \paren {C, \cdot}: \mathbf C \to \mathbf{Set}$ be the covariant representable functor based at $C$.
Then $\hom_\mathbf C \paren {C, \cdot}$ is a functor.

3a31d656-3a87-4364-9da0-69b8b93390f1.text:
Let $\theta$ be the angular coordinate of a point $P$ in a polar coordinate plane.
Let $QOR$ be a straight line that bisects the angle $\theta$.
If $\theta$ is in quadrant I or quadrant II, then the angular coordinates of $Q$ and $R$ are in quadrant I and quadrant III.
If $\theta$ is in quadrant III or quadrant IV, then the angular coordinates of $Q$ and $R$ are in quadrant II and quadrant IV.

718e1d28-2ec3-4453-ac03-56ef708d58f4.text:
Let $\RR \subseteq S \times T$ be a relation.
Let $X \subseteq S, Y \subseteq T$.
Then:
:$X \subseteq \RR^{-1} \sqbrk Y \iff \RR \sqbrk X \subseteq Y$
In the language of direct image mappings, this can be written:
:$X \subseteq \map {\RR^\gets} Y \iff \map {\RR^\to} X \subseteq Y$

c1ae5577-7a9d-4270-830c-4930001c9ea0.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Then $S$ and $\O$ are both both open and closed in $T$.

5711737b-7bcc-4ac5-8210-ec498321eafc.text:
Let $D \subseteq \C$ be open.
Let $\sequence {f_n}$ be a sequence of analytic functions $f_n: D \to \C$.
Let none of the $f_n$ be identically zero on any open subset of $D$.
Let the product $\ds \prod_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty f_n$ converge locally uniformly to $f$.
Then:
:$\ds \dfrac {f'} f = \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty \frac {f_n'} {f_n}$
and the series converges locally uniformly in $D \setminus \set {z \in D : \map f z = 0}$.

bfedbc22-5a89-49c7-afac-ad47db6cf36f.text:
Let $a$ and $b$ be small classes.
Then their Cartesian product $a \times b$ is small:
:$\map {\mathscr M} {a \times b}$

a7722c64-42a9-4780-b353-2bf6efab28e9.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ, \le}$ be a totally ordered ring.
Let $n$ be an odd positive integer.
Let $f: R \to R$ be the mapping defined by:
:$\map f x = \map {\circ^n} x$
Then $f$ is strictly increasing on $R$.

b234476e-d3dd-4e7e-bdb4-7a6c350051f4.text:
:$\ds \int_0^1 \frac {\arctan x} x \rd x = G$
where $G$ denotes Catalan's constant.

c349c3e5-cb20-43b0-8620-b28c72400ef3.text:
Let $M = \struct {S, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $A \subseteq S$ be a dense subset.
Suppose that every Cauchy sequence in $A$ converges in $M$.
Then $M$ is complete.

1f45a0a4-2823-47f4-a183-77396374f7b0.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ be a measurable space.
Let $f, g: X \to \overline \R$ be $\Sigma$-measurable functions.
Then the following sets are measurable:
:$\set {f < g}$
:$\set {f \le g}$
:$\set {f = g}$
:$\set {f \ne g}$
where, for example, $\set {f < g}$ is short for $\set {x \in X: \map f x < \map g x}$.

80265ecd-d333-40b1-940e-7c7739e1bfca.text:
Let $s_{-1}: \R^2 \to \R^2$ be a similarity mapping on $\R^2$ whose scale factor is $-1$.
Then $s_{-1}$ is the same as the rotation $r_\pi$ of the plane about the origin one half turn.

807a9982-f22b-412b-b209-7f5d3d9857c5.text:
Let $\RR_m$ denote congruence modulo $m$ on the set of integers $\Z$.
Then:
:$\RR_m \cap \RR_n = \RR_{\lcm \set {m, n} }$
where $\lcm \set {m, n}$ is the lowest common multiple of $m$ and $n$.
In the language of modulo arithmetic, this is equivalent to:
:$a \equiv b \pmod m, a \equiv b \pmod n \implies a \equiv b \pmod {\lcm \set {m, n} }$

837dba9d-7b38-41c2-9e38-91fc3b05b7bc.text:
{{Cross-Relation Quotient Structure Inverse Completion Context Definition}}
Let $c \in C$ be arbitrary.
Then:
:$\eqclass {\tuple {c, c} } \boxtimes$
is the identity of $T'$.

3459a610-0bd4-4e1e-8632-668dee5cf278.text:
Let $\R$ be the set of real numbers considered as an Euclidean space.
Let $S \subseteq \R$ be non-closed in $\R$.
Then $S$ is not a compact subspace of $\R$.

f7aa8389-8475-447e-9af9-cac622112165.text:
Let $T$ = $\struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $F$ be a closed set of $T$.
Let $H \subseteq F$ be a subset of $F$.
Let $H^-$ denote the closure of $H$.
Then $H^- \subseteq F$.

3b386fc6-ca83-4e68-b5ec-131cff331794.text:
The smallest Cunningham chain of the first kind of length $6$ is:
:$\tuple {89, 179, 359, 719, 1439, 2879}$

22559ee8-0c8b-4e36-b217-0808238b2e9b.text: :$\ds \int \paren {\arccos \frac x a}^2 \rd x = x \paren {\arccos \frac x a}^2 - 2 x - 2 \sqrt {a^2 - x^2} \arccos \frac x a + C$

155b4244-d247-4850-9427-270057021ff5.text: The largest integer which is not the sum of $2$ abundant numbers is $20 \, 161$.

857fdd57-8862-4924-a5b8-dca902cf3923.text:
Let $\struct {G, +}$ be a group whose identity is $e$.
Let $R$ be a ring.
Let $\struct {G, +, \circ}_R$ be an $R$-module.
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $G^S$ the set of all mappings $f: S \to G$.
Let $G^{\paren S}$ be the set of all mappings $f: S \to G$ such that $\map f x = e$ for all but finitely many elements $x$ of $S$.
Then:
:$\struct {G^{\paren S}, +', \circ}_R$ is a submodule of $\struct {G^S, +, \circ}_R$
where $+'$ is the operation induced on $G^{\paren S}$ by $+$.

a2ea1898-5a86-4f6f-b9dc-0a63f1a4da42.text: The set $\R_{>0}$ of strictly positive real numbers is not closed under subtraction.

5d681775-146d-467f-8b3d-a8bbcd45a414.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be a division ring.
Let $\Char D$ be the characteristic of $D$.
Then $\Char D$ is either $0$ or a prime number.

74feb202-854e-4127-bbc6-99671eeb01dc.text:
The following sequence of $9$ consecutive prime numbers are all of the form $4 n + 1$:
:$11 \, 593, 11 \, 597, 11 \, 617, 11 \, 621, 11 \, 633, 11 \, 657, 11 \, 677, 11 \, 681, 11 \, 689$

7a54b577-81b8-4624-9ba9-112790d6ce69.text:
Let $\struct {\Z \sqbrk {i \sqrt 5}, +, \times}$ denote the $5$th cyclotomic ring.
The units of $\struct {\Z \sqbrk {i \sqrt 5}, +, \times}$ are $1$ and $-1$.

34600223-6fe2-4d94-b5a2-63dee516bb64.text:
Let $m$ be a finite ordinal.
Let $m \ne 0$, where $0$ is the zero ordinal.
Then:
: $m \times \omega = \omega$
where $\omega$ denotes the minimal infinite successor set.

85a9efca-30f0-4117-b99a-5acf0ad70c55.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a metric space.
Let $\R$ denote the real numbers.
Let $f: M \to \R$ and $g: M \to \R$ be real-valued functions from $M$ to $\R$ which are continuous on $M$.
Let $\max \set {f, g}: M \to \R$ denote the pointwise maximum of $f$ and $g$.
Then:
:$\max \set {f, g}$ is ‎continuous on $M$.

ece3c1c0-8042-4473-8c76-b192729d058e.text: {{TFAE|def = Limit Superior of Sequence of Sets}}

3589b28f-f458-4a80-942c-a7659ca251ad.text:
Let $\mathbb S$ be a set of sets or class.
Then $\subseteq$ is an ordering on $\mathbb S$.
In other words, let $\struct {\mathbb S, \subseteq}$ be the relational structure defined on $\mathbb S$ by the relation $\subseteq$.
Then $\struct {\mathbb S, \subseteq}$ is an ordered set.

ccf0b553-559a-4c38-8b14-33946704dbfe.text:
Let $f: \C \to \C$ be a bounded entire function.
Then $f$ is constant.
Let $f: \C \to \C$ be an entire function such that: 
:$\size {\map f z} \ge M$
for all $z \in \C$ for some real constant $M > 0$. 
Then $f$ is constant.

5cedc2c4-949a-4011-a868-11210e78896d.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq}$ have more than one maximal element.
Then $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq}$ has no greatest element.

aa56a7a8-da87-4988-bcb8-700247183dea.text:
Let $S$ be a finite set.
Let $f: S \to \R$ be a real-valued function on $S$.
Then $f$ is bounded.

2e5082c6-cc31-48f7-9261-79fa59fe1c5a.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $X$ be an irreducible subset of $S$ such that:
:$\relcomp S X \in \tau$
Let $L = \struct {\tau, \preceq}$ be an inclusion ordered set of topology $\tau$.
Then $\relcomp S X$ is prime element in $L$.

30a15066-c37d-471d-8c5e-1a4b3ab0eb67.text:
Let $\CC_I$ be an equivalence class of isometries on the set of metric spaces.
Then $\CC_I$ is a subset of an equivalence class of homeomorphisms on the set of metric spaces.

905982d1-c974-4823-84fd-3e7362631297.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XII|prop=14|body=Cones and cylinders which are on equal bases are to one another as their heights.}}

c690fb20-77ca-42f9-b931-8374ccec2204.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is twice differentiable on the open interval $\left({a \,.\,.\, b}\right)$.
Then $f$ is strictly concave on $\left({a \,.\,.\, b}\right)$ {{iff}} its second derivative $f'' < 0$ on $\left({a \,.\,.\, b}\right)$.

9aaf395b-19a9-4a8c-af0d-0f526c1cbe76.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a woset.
Let $a \in S$, and let $S_a$ be the initial segment of $S$ determined by $a$.
Then there is no order isomorphism between $S$ and $S_a$.

8be7a271-6e0b-4e6b-bf9a-ad3ce4fc90f4.text:
Let $T = \struct{S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $A, B \subseteq S$.
Let $U, V \in \tau$ satisfy:
:$A \subset U$ and $U \cap B = \O$
:$B \subset V$ and $V \cap A = \O$
where $\O$ denotes the empty set.
Then
:$A^- \cap B = A \cap B^- = \O$
where $A^-$ denotes the closure of $A$ in $T$.

ec5fcfaf-0185-4a36-9531-fad0de6cb274.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $x_1, x_2, \dots ,x_n \in S$ for some $n \in \N_{>0}$.
Then:
:$\min \set {x_1, x_2, \dotsc, x_n} = \inf \set {x_1, x_2, \dotsc, x_n}$
where:
:$\min$ denotes the min operation
:$\inf$ denotes the infimum.

0417cae3-9e4b-47ab-a5f2-44ed3bc4f5e9.text:
Let $G$ be a topological group.
Let $H\leq G$ be an open subgroup.
Then $H$ is closed.

8597af41-67b7-4881-bb3a-1d62279e9349.text:
Let $H$ be the astroid constructed within a circle of radius $a$.
The surface of revolution formed by rotating $H$ around the $x$-axis:
:400px
evaluates to:
:$\SS = \dfrac {12 \pi a^2} 5$

9088a9d9-e136-41f9-b7f3-73d3f0e625ce.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $S \subseteq G$ such that:
:$\forall x, y \in S: x \circ y = y \circ x$
Then the subgroup generated by $S$ is abelian.

f91017d9-108d-474c-9d93-31fc0d60f2ae.text:
Let $I$ be an indexing set with uncountable cardinality.
Let $\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be a family of topological spaces indexed by $I$.
Let $\ds \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be the product space of $\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$.
Let each of $\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be a separable space.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also a separable space.

20ed3901-d7fa-44ce-805a-944fa9fdf0ad.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \times}$ be a Euclidean domain whose zero is $0$, and unity is $1$.
Let the valuation function of $D$ be $\nu$.
Let $b, c \in D_{\ne 0}$.
Then:
:If $c$ is not a unit of $D$ then $\map \nu b < \map \nu {b c}$

ec98a6a6-554a-4a67-8b71-f21b45e9ead5.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{> 0}$ be a strictly positive integer.
Let $b \in \Z$ such that $b \ge 2$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \floor {\sqrt k} = \floor {\sqrt n} \paren {n - \dfrac {\paren {2 \floor {\sqrt n} + 5} \paren {\floor {\sqrt n} - 1} } 6}$

a2f6824b-cd16-475f-966f-9890665b2b37.text: Every positive integer can be expressed as a sum of four squares.

5346c046-352b-4710-be81-5374a72383c7.text:
Let $\closedint a b$ be a closed real interval.
Then every sequence of points of $\closedint a b$ contains a subsequence which converges to a point in $\closedint a b$.

22eaa9b0-39a3-4303-a311-a202426d1914.text:
Let $a, b$ be extended real numbers such that $a < b$.
Then the closed interval $\set {x \in \R : a \le x \le b} \subseteq \R$ is uncountable.

99438c47-16f4-4619-846a-0f626d1e3ba3.text: The set $\Q$ of rational numbers forms a subset of the real numbers $\R$.

1034cf97-58fe-4f86-aadf-422765352262.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a strictly positive integer.
Let $\map p n$ denote the number of partitions on $n$.
Then:
:$\map p n = \ds \sum_{1 \mathop \le n - GP_k \mathop < n} -\paren {-1}^{\ceiling {k / 2} } \map p {n - GP_k} + \sqbrk {\exists k \in \Z: GP_k = n}$
where:
:$\ceiling {k / 2}$ denotes the ceiling of $k / 2$
:$GP_n$ denotes the $n$th generalized pentagonal number
:$\sqbrk {\exists k \in \Z: GP_k = n}$ is Iverson's convention.
{{AuthorRef|Leonhard Paul Euler}} had noticed, but had not formally proved, the result now known as Euler's Pentagonal Numbers Theorem.
However, he was so convinced of its truth that he used it to prove this and other results.

22cfe229-6a53-4058-b444-24dd061c87b6.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $G$ be a group with identity $e$ whose order is $p$.
Then $G$ has $p - 1$ elements of order $p$.

cbb4306f-828e-4d23-8c61-af320f9d0978.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring.
Let $\EE$ be a congruence relation on $R$.
Let $J = \eqclass {0_R} \EE$ be the ideal induced by $\EE$.
Then the equivalence defined by the coset space $\struct {R, +} / \struct {J, +}$ is $\EE$ itself.

56c43c95-09e9-45a0-b0bd-ba08135f8904.text:
There exists no set which is an absolutely universal set.
That is:
:$\neg \left({\exists \mathcal U: \forall T: T \in \mathcal U}\right)$
where $T$ is any arbitrary object at all.
That is, a set that contains ''everything'' cannot exist.

70deaa61-b00f-4ce9-b893-6f95337daa93.text:
Let $A$ be a set.
$\card A$ is finite
{{iff}}
$A$ is finite
where $\card A$ denotes the cardinality of $A$.

50ea6632-03d7-4852-9fcb-267217cf161f.text:
Let $f, g: \R \to \F$ be functions, where $\F \in \set {\R, \C}$.
Let $f$ be of exponential order $a$ and $g$ be of exponential order $b$.
Then $f g: t \mapsto \map f t \, \map g t$ is of exponential order $a+b$.

764bbc52-7f34-4f46-b119-f64ea4ac7766.text:
Let $A = \polar {r_1, \theta_1}$ and $B = \polar {r_2, \theta_2}$ be two points in a polar coordinate plane
The distance $d$ between $A$ and $B$ is given by:
:$d = \sqrt {r_1^2 + r_2^2 + 2 r_1 r_2 \map \cos {\theta_1 - \theta_2} }$

cba9be32-7ddb-42f6-a8b0-32bbc7918211.text:
Consider a right circular cone $\CC$ with opening angle $2 \alpha$ whose apex is at $O$.
Consider a plane $\PP$ which intersects $\CC$, not passing through $O$, at an angle $\beta$ to the axis of $\CC$.
Then the points of intersection form one of the following:
:a circle
:an ellipse
:a hyperbola
:a parabola.

29f06b1c-429f-400d-b7d9-e93485ec3f1b.text:
Let $a, b$ be real numbers with $a < b$.
Let $f, g : \closedint a b \to \R$ be functions of bounded variation.
Let $V_f$ and $V_g$ be the total variations of $f$ and $g$ respectively. 
Then $f + g$ is of bounded variation with:
:$V_{f + g} \le V_f + V_g$
where $V_{f + g}$ denotes the total variation of $f + g$.

8a15da84-2b1f-4410-a71c-98760dcf3e1e.text:
Let $G = \struct {V, E}$ be a graph.
Let $\to$ denote the relation '''is connected to''' on the set $V$.
Then $\to$ is an equivalence relation.

87eb756e-1dac-4609-8fb7-ef70de6dc981.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be a Fort space on an infinite set $S$.
Then $\tau_p$ is the minimal topology that is generated by the excluded point topology and the finite complement topology.

a59c88c6-38db-4759-84c0-d59359298944.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $T_1$ be a subset of $T$.
Then:
:$\relcomp S {f^{-1} \sqbrk {T_1} } = f^{-1} \sqbrk {\relcomp T {T_1} }$
where:
:$\complement_S$ (in this context) denotes relative complement
:$f^{-1} \sqbrk {T_1}$ denotes preimage.
That is:
:$S \setminus f^{-1} \sqbrk {T_1} = f^{-1} \sqbrk {T \setminus T_1}$
This can be expressed in the language and notation of inverse image mappings as:
:$\forall T_1 \in \powerset T: \relcomp S {\map {f^\gets} {T_1} } = \map {f^\gets} {\relcomp T {T_1} }$

1b527d6e-486e-4ee2-8cd2-23a49c4e8ad5.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $N$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Then there exists a group homomorphism of which $N$ is the kernel.

84f16962-8607-46b8-802a-72fc633f0b3a.text: The edge of a polyhedron has zero curvature.

9642b289-1ef8-450f-9297-aaf0f2b340f2.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be a given subset of $S$.
Let $\powerset S$ denote the power set of $S$
Let $\mathscr S$ be the subset of $\powerset S$ defined as:
:$\mathscr S = \set {Y \in \powerset S: T \subseteq Y}$
Then the algebraic structure $\struct {\mathscr S, \cup}$ is closed.

8cbb6d78-5235-4d51-9b87-11f6ed1d77eb.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \preceq}$ be a bounded below join semilattice.
Let $\map {\it Aux} L$ be the set of all auxiliary relations on $S$.
Let $P = \struct {\map {\it Aux} L, \precsim}$ be an ordered set
where $\precsim \mathop = \subseteq \restriction_{\map {\it Aux} L \times \map {\it Aux} L}$
Then
:$\preceq \mathop = \top_P$
where $\top_P$ denotes the greatest element in $P$.

b4108c45-b173-41ac-8d2e-247b9ffb5cd4.text:
The complex cross product is anticommutative:
:$\forall z_1, z_2 \in \C: z_1 \times z_2 = -\paren {z_2 \times z_1}$

321f9a3d-3f41-4e74-a8ab-502f85404cef.text:
Let $(S, \wedge, \preceq)$ be a meet semilattice.
Let $a, b, c, d \in S$.
Let $a \preceq b$.
Let $c \preceq d$.
Then $(a \wedge c) \preceq (b \wedge d)$.

c87fe2c8-3853-463f-806c-ec3cc27c9f6f.text:
The operation of addition on the set of real numbers $\R$ is associative:
:$\forall x, y, z \in \R: x + \paren {y + z} = \paren {x + y} + z$

e0126713-3bb6-4206-9c77-0ff199ea6f41.text:
Let $M = \struct {A_1, d_1}, M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $f: M_1 \to M_2$ be a homeomorphism.
Then $f^{-1}: M_2 \to M_1$ is also a homeomorphism.

b7e815b3-2049-4904-ad41-562323040ef0.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $\struct {\powerset G, \circ_\mathcal P}$ be the algebraic structure consisting of the power set of $G$ and the operation induced on $\powerset G$ by $\circ$.
Then $\struct {\powerset G, \circ_\mathcal P}$ is a semigroup.

4b1cb0b1-8eeb-49c3-b510-8030809fff10.text:
Let $G$ and $H$ be groups.
Let $\theta: G \to H$ be an epimorphism.
Let $\map Z G$ denote the center of $G$.
Then:
:$\theta \sqbrk {\map Z G} \subseteq \map Z H$

a9f731b9-e943-4bd6-a4cc-0bc0bd8d95c7.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $x \in R$ be nilpotent.
Then $1_R - x$ is a unit of $R$.

12947160-2167-4d36-9fd6-a8e7b4da7625.text:
Let $\struct {\C, +, \times}$ be the field of complex numbers.
There exists no total ordering on $\struct {\C, +, \times}$ which is compatible with the structure of $\struct {\C, +, \times}$.

8891f68b-7645-4d83-a6c5-c754dee1adb5.text:
Let $\tanh: \C \to \C$ be the hyperbolic tangent function on the set of complex numbers.
Then $\tanh$ is odd:
:$\map \tanh {-x} = -\tanh x$

7c9e007e-c58c-4931-83e1-8d6f8fd2000c.text:
Let $\mathbf u$ be a vector in the real vector space $\R^n$.
Then:
:$\mathbf u \cdot \mathbf u = \norm {\mathbf u}^2$
where $\norm {\mathbf u}$ is the length of $\mathbf u$.

9e560b18-cb44-47e0-b451-3f9bd6359e5f.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\BB_1$ and $\BB_2$ be two bases on $S$.
Let $\tau_1$ and $\tau_2$ be the topologies generated by $\BB_1$ and $\BB_2$ respectively.
If $\BB_1$ and $\BB_2$ satisfy:
:$\forall U \in \BB_1 : \exists \AA \subseteq \BB_2: U = \bigcup \AA$
then $\tau_1$ is coarser than $\tau_2$.

16c6edec-e129-49cf-841f-c484f3620d68.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group whose identity element is $e_G$.
Let $\struct {H, *}$ be a group whose identity element is $e_H$.
Let $N \lhd G, K \lhd H$ be normal subgroups of $G$ and $H$ respectively.
Let:
:$G / N \cong H / K$
where:
:$G / N$ denotes the quotient of $G$ by $N$
:$\cong$ denotes group isomorphism.
Let $\theta: G / N \to H / K$ be such a group isomorphism.
Let $G \times^\theta H$ be the pullback of $G$ and $H$ via $\theta$.
Then $G \times^\theta H$ is a subgroup of $G \times H$.

ffa40f30-9e54-45c6-984f-b972dbc6000a.text:
Let $\family {T_i}_{i \mathop \in I} = \family {\struct{S_i, \tau_i}}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of topological spaces where $I$ is an arbitrary index set.
Let $\ds S = \prod_{i \mathop \in I} S_i$ be the corresponding product space.
Let $\tau$ denote the Tychonoff topology on $S$.
Let $\pr_i: S \to S_i$ be the corresponding projection from $S$ onto $S_i$.
Then $\pr_i$ is continuous for all $i \in I$.

840f800d-a481-45c4-9798-76a1f595f296.text:
Let $\phi: \struct {R_1, +_1, \circ_1} \to \struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2}$ be a ring homomorphism.
Then:
:$\forall x \in R_1: \map \phi {-x} = -\paren {\map \phi x}$

13ed27ac-6a56-44aa-93ee-a33cc9cc8cc5.text:
Let $f$ be a mapping.
Then $f$ is a bijection {{iff}} $f$ is both left cancellable and right cancellable.

0df1f881-f558-4c05-a4a3-11e4a8d3042e.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T^*_{\bar p} = \struct {S^*_p, \tau^*_{\bar p} }$ be the open extension space of $T$.
Then $T^*_{\bar p}$ is a first-countable space {{iff}} $T$ is.

7b6556dc-8783-4738-8792-cb74406c5528.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty \paren {\frac {\sin p x} x}^2 \rd x = \frac {\pi \size p} 2$
where $p$ is a real number.

a20f1429-afd6-4edc-8c56-43338686b768.text:
Let $\left({S, \circ}\right)$ be a monoid with identity $e_S$.
Let $\mathbf S$ be the associated monoid category.
Then $\mathbf S$ is a category.

8001e778-5162-4bef-bd91-3ef4269bfd38.text:
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {A_\alpha}_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be an indexed family of subsets of a set $S$.
Let $J \subseteq I$
Then:
:$\ds \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in J} A_\alpha \subseteq \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} A_\alpha$
where $\ds \bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in I} A_\alpha$ denotes the union of $\family {A_\alpha}_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$.

1dc8362b-669d-4843-9c95-8bdb386f2baa.text:
Let $F_n$ denote the $n$th Fermat number.
Let $m \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Then:
:$F_n \divides F_{n + m} - 2$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.

2a5f8522-efaa-4d8a-967e-8fe1f5d7dd82.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=107|body=A straight line commensurable with that which produces with a medial area a medial whole is itself also a straight line which produces with a medial area a medial whole.}}

5da12511-39bb-44cf-bf9d-2447a65a8d61.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma, \mu}$ be a measure space.
Let $E \in \Sigma$ be a measurable set, and let $\chi_E: X \to \R$ be its characteristic function.
Then $\map {I_\mu} {\chi_E} = \map \mu E$, where $\map {I_\mu} {\chi_E}$ is the $\mu$-integral of $\chi_E$.

bae22d9b-a311-4b1c-8c23-7cbb418fc19a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$ be a subset of $S$, and let $\preceq \restriction_T$ be the restricted ordering on $T$.
Then for all $t \in T$:
:$t^{\succ T} = T \cap t^{\succ S}$
where:
:$t^{\succ T}$ is the strict upper closure of $t$ in $\struct {T, \preceq \restriction_T}$
:$t^{\succ S}$ is the strict upper closure of $t$ in $\struct {S, \preceq}$.

31a5094b-6f05-4bc7-acc5-c2f0211ef1f2.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a commutative ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$.
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be such that the only ideals of $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ are:
:$\set {0_R}$
and:
$\struct {R, +, \circ}$ itself.
That is, such that $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ has no non-null proper ideals.
Then $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ is a field.

49d52da2-59a4-425d-bc3f-c420137c971e.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XIII|prop=6|body=If a rational straight line be cut in extreme and mean ratio, each of the segments is the irrational straight line called apotome.}}

7db6e5cb-a370-4da2-a1aa-e3f4607521a9.text:
Let $s \in \R, r \in \Z_{\ge 0}, m, n \in \Z$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_k \binom r {m + k} \binom s {n + k} = \binom {r + s} {r - m + n}$
where $\dbinom r {m + k}$ etc. are binomial coefficients.

6583086f-3cf1-44c2-b6c6-6a6d9945a6a5.text:
Let a group $G$ have only one subgroup of a given order.
Then that subgroup is normal.

53e1351d-480c-4855-9a72-fb8f8e7d0116.text:
Let $T = \struct {\R, \tau}$ be the Sorgenfrey line.
Let
:$\BB = \set {\hointr x y: x, y \in \R \land x < y}$
be the basis of $T$.
Then $\card \BB \le \mathfrak c$
where
:$\card \BB$ denotes the cardinality of $\BB$
:$\mathfrak c = \card \R$ denotes the continuum.

f0a4751d-5a24-44d3-a479-57e248e0fb82.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$ be a positive integer.
Let $\map {A_n} {x, t}$ be the polynomial of degree $n$ defined as:
:$\map {A_n} {x, t} := \dbinom {x - n t} n \dfrac x {x - n t}$
for $x \ne n t$.
Let $z = x^{t + 1} - x^t$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_k \map {A_k} {r, t} z^k = x^r$
for sufficiently small $z$.

bc6b268c-d643-48cb-9409-0548c07f41f4.text:
Let $\map \MM {m, n}$ be a metric space of order $m \times n$ over a field $K$.
Let $\mathbf A \in \map \MM {m, n}$ be a matrix. 
Let $\Gamma_1$ be a column operation which transforms $\mathbf A$ to a new matrix $\mathbf B \in \map \MM {m, n}$.
Let $\Gamma_2$ be a column operation which transforms $\mathbf B$ to another new matrix $\mathbf C \in \map \MM {m, n}$.
Then there exists another column operation $\Gamma$ which transforms $\mathbf A$ back to $\mathbf C$ such that $\Gamma$ consists of $\Gamma_1$ followed by $\Gamma_2$.

fd62daf4-9146-4708-99ea-b5ac6dec8ee5.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\tau$ be a topology on $S$, thus forming the topological space $\struct {S, \tau}$.
Let $\struct {S, \NN}$ be the neighborhood space induced by $\struct {S, \tau}$.
Then $\struct {S, \NN}$ is a neighborhood space.

c3d535b5-47bc-49c2-bd9c-5a0b7ecb2342.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \circ}$ be an integral domain.
Let $\ideal x$ denote the principal ideal of $D$ generated by $x$.
Let $x, y \in \struct {D, +, \circ}$.
Then:
:$x \divides y \iff \ideal y \subseteq \ideal x$
where $x \divides y$ denotes that $x$ is a divisor of $y$.

f86b7299-5c21-4702-a91f-ef1b9f6d7ec3.text:
Let $\C$ denote the complex numbers.
Let $f$ and $g$ be complex functions defined on an open subset $S \subseteq \C$, except possibly at the point $c \in S$.
Let $f$ and $g$ tend to the following limits:
:$\ds \lim_{z \mathop \to c} \map f z = l$
:$\ds \lim_{z \mathop \to c} \map g z = m$
Let $\lambda, \mu \in \C$ be arbitrary complex numbers.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{z \mathop \to c} \paren {\lambda \map f z + \mu \map g z} = \lambda l + \mu m$

4dece15f-9343-4c2d-82ef-2e686829ba60.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=VIII|prop=18|body=Between two similar plane numbers there is one mean proportional number, and the plane number has to the plane number the ratio duplicate of that which the corresponding side has to the corresponding side.}}

a881a25c-1da2-4cfd-a9a0-1e9903504980.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a commutative semigroup.
Let $\struct {C, \circ} \subseteq \struct {S, \circ}$ be the subsemigroup of cancellable elements of $\struct {S, \circ}$.
Let $\struct {T, \circ'}$ be an inverse completion of $\struct {S, \circ}$.
Then:
:$S \circ' C^{-1}$ is a commutative semigroup
where $S \circ' C^{-1}$ is the subset product of $S$ with $C^{-1}$ under $\circ'$ in $T$.

f77d91d3-3112-4826-b63c-bb599973e2e3.text:
Let $\struct {\Z, +}$ be the additive group of integers.
Let $\struct {\Q, +}$ be the additive group of rational numbers.
Then $\struct {\Z, +}$ is a subgroup of $\struct {\Q, +}$.

104196ed-e6d2-4e11-b6e4-f7d2ed7a29c7.text:
Let $\omega$ denote the minimal infinite successor set.
Let $F$ be a function whose domain is $\omega$.
Then:
:$\exists n \in \omega: \map F {n^+} \notin \map F n$

4e5f5e7e-2c20-4fc5-83a8-c178979aafdb.text:
Let $\struct {M, \circ}$ be a monoid whose identity is $e_M$.
Let $S \subseteq M$.
Let $\struct {H, \circ}$ be the '''submonoid of $\struct {M, \circ}$ generated by $S$'''.
Then $\struct {H, \circ}$ is the intersection of all submonoids of $\struct {M, \circ}$ containing $S \cup \set {e_M}$.

691aa8d4-7ea1-4ab8-b0a6-5ae76ff6074b.text:
Let $n, k \in \Z_{\ge 0}$
Let $k > n$.
Let $\map s {n, k}$ denote a signed Stirling number of the first kind.
Then:
:$\map s {n, k} = 0$

fb6e1f32-88c6-43bd-91ea-025cfd7b3d0c.text:
:$\ds \int x^2 \sin a x \rd x = \frac {2 x \sin a x} {a^2} + \paren {\frac 2 {a^3} - \frac {x^2} a} \cos a x + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

3f9de77c-05ec-4531-9567-24c54d7e97f2.text: The integral domain of integers $\struct {\Z, +, \times}$ forms a subdomain of the field of real numbers.

616b381c-f1fe-46cc-a06f-006049fe1754.text:
Let $E / F / K$ be a tower of field extensions.
Let $E$ be algebraic over $F$.
Let $F$ be algebraic over $K$.
Then $E$ is algebraic over $K$.

fc9c7bb8-1312-4e37-8296-e1b9b8463398.text: The union of a finite number of countable sets is countable.

efe7d500-4ba2-4779-bc7e-7f2e416403ca.text:
Let $I$ be an indexing set.
Let $\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$ be a family of topological spaces indexed by $I$.
Let $\ds \struct {S, \tau} = \prod_{\alpha \mathop \in I} \struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be the product space of $\family {\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha} }_{\alpha \mathop \in I}$.
Let each of $\struct {S_\alpha, \tau_\alpha}$ be a paracompact space.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $\struct {S, \tau}$ is also paracompact space.

e5459276-03d6-40e7-838f-8313d5edf328.text:
Let $T = \struct {\R, \tau}$ be the compact complement topology on $\R$.
Then $T$ is not a $T_2$ (Hausdorff) space, $T_{2 \frac 1 2}$ (completely Hausdorff) space, $T_3$ space, $T_4$ space or $T_5$ space.

53daf93b-f7a5-4fd7-913f-c363892ace6e.text:
:$\map \tan {\dfrac \pi 2 - \theta} = \cot \theta$ for $\theta \ne n \pi$
where $\tan$ and $\cot$ are tangent and cotangent respectively.
That is, the cotangent of an angle is the tangent of its complement.
This relation is defined wherever $\sin \theta \ne 0$.

64d5bad0-c465-4190-84ba-e4095c7ef6af.text:
Let $z \in \C$ be a complex number expressed in complex form:
:$z = r \paren {\cos x + i \sin x}$
Then:
:$\forall \omega \in \C: \paren {r \paren {\cos x + i \sin x} }^\omega = r^\omega \paren {\map \cos {\omega x} + i \, \map \sin {\omega x} }$

aca0f67d-6b63-4acb-9b5d-557bb81bd848.text:
Let $\floor x$ be the floor function.
Let $\map {\operatorname {III} } x$ be the Dirac comb.
Then the distributional derivative of $\floor x$ is $\map {\operatorname {III} } 0$.

68227bac-1624-419f-97c0-471054351c5f.text:
Let $A$ be an abelian group.
Let $k \in \Z$ and $B$ be a set of the form:
:$\left\{{x \in A : x^k = e}\right\}$
Then $B$ is a subgroup of $A$.

30b964ac-4e0f-4aac-b61f-7f6030fd80c0.text:
Let $\phi: \struct {R_1, +_1, \circ_1} \to \struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2}$ be a ring homomorphism.
Let $S$ be a subring of $R_1$.
Then $\phi \sqbrk S$ is a subring of $R_2$.

2250f464-8061-4494-b717-d9acfe991fe0.text:
Let $\omega$ denote the set of natural numbers as defined by the von Neumann construction.
$\omega$ is a minimally inductive class under the successor mapping.

8f8239c0-908b-416f-b7fe-0edb3d8093f7.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ, \preceq}$ be a naturally ordered semigroup.
Let $p \in S$.
Let $T \subseteq S$ such that:
:$x \in T \implies p \preceq x \land \paren {x \in T \implies x \circ 1 \in T}$
Then:
:$S \setminus S_p \subseteq T$
where:
:$\setminus$ denotes set difference
:$S_p$ denotes the set of all elements of $S$ preceding $p$.

1b12edef-29dd-4259-b303-e1f7f5fcf2c8.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $\floor x$ denote the floor function of $x$.
Let $\RR$ be the relation defined on $\R$ such that:
:$\forall x, y, \in \R: \tuple {x, y} \in \RR \iff \floor x = \floor y$
Then $\RR$ is an equivalence, and $\forall n \in \Z$, the $\RR$-class of $n$ is the half-open interval $\hointr n {n + 1}$.

21ab6fa3-e7fc-468c-bd72-1551d9729b6a.text:
Let $N \in \N$ be an arbitrary natural number.
Let $C_N$ be the square embedded in the complex plane $\C$ with vertices $\paren {N + \dfrac 1 2} \paren {\pm 1 \pm i}$.
Let $f$ be a meromorphic function on $\C$ with finitely many poles. 
Suppose that: 
:$\ds \int_{C_N} \paren {\pi \cot \pi z} \map f z \rd z \to 0$
as $N \to \infty$. 
Let $X$ be the set of poles of $f$.
Then: 
 
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop \in \Z \mathop \setminus X} \map f n = - \sum_{z_0 \mathop \in X} \Res {\pi \map \cot {\pi z} \map f z} {z_0}$
 
If $X \cap \Z = \O$, this becomes: 
:$\ds \sum_{n \mathop = -\infty}^\infty \map f n = -\sum_{z_0 \mathop \in X} \Res {\pi \map \cot {\pi z} \map f z} {z_0}$

6bcb57d2-fa39-443f-869c-de390e4889bf.text: The set of integers $\Z$ can be well-ordered with an appropriately chosen ordering.

8c97cfd6-3aa0-4dae-8d4e-4c425a186654.text:
Let $x$ and $y$ be ordinals.
Let $y$ be a limit ordinal.
Let $x^y$ denote ordinal exponentiation.
Then:
:If $x > 1$, then $x^y$ is a limit ordinal.
:If $x \ne \O$, then $y^x$ is a limit ordinal.

86f09284-67b6-48fa-9720-9e991b8b8ec5.text:
The $n$th derivative of $\map \ln x$ for $n \ge 1$ is:
:$\dfrac {\d^n} {\d x^n} \ln x = \dfrac {\paren {n - 1}! \paren {-1}^{n - 1} } {x^n}$

0a849c7a-7e81-4e6f-9e44-afdac2d60b21.text:
Let $\struct {\Z_m, +_m, \times_m}$ be the ring of integers modulo $m$ for $m > 1$.
Let $\Z'_m$ be the set of non-zero integers modulo $m$.
Let $\struct {\Z_m, \times_m}$ be closed under modulo multiplication.
Then $m$ is prime.

53131c8a-7998-437a-9055-08155aeedf7f.text:
Let $\left({S, \circ}\right)$ be a finite semigroup.
Then:
: $\forall x \in S: \exists m, n \in \N: m \ne n: x^m = x^n$

87c5437a-e371-4dae-85b0-482935e09c4b.text:
Let $x$ be an ordinal.
Then $x$ is cofinal to itself.
That is:
:$\operatorname{cof} \left({x, x}\right)$

ed4b08b1-27df-490b-b24d-4967e321829e.text:
:$\map \cos {\dfrac {3 \pi} 2 - \theta} = -\sin \theta$
where $\cos$ and $\sin$ are cosine and sine respectively.

51d1b5d0-d938-4acc-b8cc-cadab32c484e.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $G$ be a group of order $p$.
Let $\Aut G$ denote the automorphism group of $G$.
Then:
:$\order {\Aut G} = p - 1$
where $\order {\, \cdot \,}$ denotes the order of a group.

e2fc1321-7ee1-41f5-9bfe-1eaa4ca72801.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\sequence {x_n} $ be a sequence in $\Q_p$.
{{TFAE}}

b0b1b441-f465-4b75-bfa1-28c011b0b06b.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {\sin a x \paren {1 + \cos a x} } = \frac 1 {2 a \paren {1 + \cos a x} } + \frac 1 {2 a} \ln \size {\tan \frac {a x} 2} + C$

4c73aeeb-7dfd-47e3-a86a-135c9ac00c5b.text:
Let $R$ be a ring.
Then the null ring is a subring of $R$.

c5fa8b4c-34fb-482c-8789-ffd61adf131c.text:
Let $\N_{> 0}$ be the $1$-based natural numbers.
Let $\times$ be multiplication on $\N_{>0}$.
Then:
:$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a \times c = b \times c \implies a = b$
:$\forall a, b, c \in \N_{>0}: a \times b = a \times c \implies b = c$
That is, $\times$ is cancellable on $\N_{>0}$.

edb1aa2e-b56a-4f51-bfe4-2c3fa69742a1.text:
The sine function is:
:$(1): \quad$ strictly increasing on the interval $\closedint {-\dfrac \pi 2} {\dfrac \pi 2}$
:$(2): \quad$ strictly decreasing on the interval $\closedint {\dfrac \pi 2} {\dfrac {3 \pi} 2}$
:$(3): \quad$ concave on the interval $\closedint 0 \pi$
:$(4): \quad$ convex on the interval $\closedint \pi {2 \pi}$

904d4621-707a-43ee-b124-7acaaee5cf53.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a topological space.
Let $\mathcal F$ be the collection of all $F_\sigma$ sets of $T$.
Then $\left({\mathcal F, \subseteq}\right)$ is a lattice, where $\subseteq$ denotes the subset relation.

0c818afc-1594-4718-a149-d4fe8878c348.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\Z_p$ be the $p$-adic integers.
Let $x \in \Z_p$.
Then there exists a unique coherent sequence $\sequence {\alpha_n}$:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \alpha_n = x$

11467ca3-5544-4ec6-9dca-1d1fd4806ab9.text:
Let $T = \struct {\Z_{>0}, \tau}$ be a topological space where $\tau$ is the odd-even topology on the strictly positive integers $\Z_{>0}$.
Then $T$ is not countably compact.

8e1e89b1-f496-448b-8eb1-1d7d06ecd792.text:
Let $H, K$ be Hilbert spaces.
Let $A: H \to K$ be a linear transformation.
Then:
:$\forall \lambda > 0 : \norm{A 0_H}_K = \lambda \norm{0_H}_H$

0c004ce7-6ae0-4074-bcf8-4a1e6268b973.text: Zero is an integer multiple of zero.

dd1313e9-4b0a-4a77-852a-22ce509196f6.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let $K$ be a subgroup of $H$.
Let:
:$\index G K = p$
where:
:$p$ denotes a prime number
:$\index G K$ denotes the index of $K$ in $G$.
Then either:
:$H = K$
or:
:$H = G$

f71c3985-e5a1-4d1f-9e81-ffd17922e251.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$, and let $N$ be a normal subgroup of $G$.
Then $H \cap N$ is a normal subgroup of $H$.

f0b60cc6-322c-4f1e-b40c-59f734c36d2d.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=XI|prop=16|body=If two parallel planes be cut by any plane, their common sections are parallel.}}

2714999f-1c67-4444-81d2-f717e2cc54ce.text:
Let $\struct {\Q, d_\Q}$ be the set of rational numbers under the function $d_\Q: \Q \times \Q \to \R$ defined as:
:$\forall x, y \in \Q: \map d {x, y} = \size {x - y}$
Let $\struct {\R, d}$ denote the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) metric.
Then $\struct {\Q, d_\Q}$ is a metric subspace of $\struct {\R, d}$, where:

a4684c8f-7495-47e1-8e6b-232bafc6a811.text:
Let $\sequence {z_n}$ be a sequence in $\C$.
Let $\sequence {z_n}$ be convergent to the following limit:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} z_n = c$
Let $\lambda \in \C$.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \paren {\lambda z_n} = \lambda c$

42e9173e-e615-42fb-9775-faf5636e2990.text:
Let $g$ and $h$ be elements of a group $G$ whose identity element is $e$.
Then:
:$h g = g \implies h = e$

59019a27-8f04-4b7d-b5b2-6be5a8cb9a06.text:
Let $\struct {\HH, \innerprod \cdot \cdot_\HH}$ and $\struct {\KK, \innerprod \cdot \cdot_\KK}$ be Hilbert spaces.
Let $\map {B_0} {\HH, \KK}$ be the space of compact linear transformations $\HH \to \KK$. 
Let $\map B {\HH, \KK}$ be the space of bounded linear transformations $\HH \to \KK$. 
Let $T \in \map {B_0} {\HH, \KK}$.
Then $T \in \map B {\HH, \KK}$.
That is:
:$\map {B_0} {\HH, \KK} \subseteq \map B {\HH, \KK}$

8b3e3b89-35ea-4a69-9783-e962da612ab8.text:
Let $*$ be a group action of $G$ on $X$.
Then each $g \in G$ determines a bijection $\phi_g: X \to X$ given by:
:$\map {\phi_g} x = g * x$
Its inverse is:
:$\phi_{g^{-1} }: X \to X$.
These bijection are sometimes called '''transformations''' of $X$.

34b0a3ae-d473-4af5-9cf8-eac2fff390b5.text:
:$\ds {0 \brack n} = \delta_{0 n}$
where:
:$\ds {0 \brack n}$ denotes an unsigned Stirling number of the first kind
:$\delta_{0 n}$ denotes the Kronecker delta.

0a3a37b2-1fdf-4059-a694-1f8b4fee049f.text:
Let $S$ be a set such that $S \sim x$ for some ordinal $x$.
Let $\card S$ denote the cardinal number of $S$.
Then:
:$\card S \in \On$
where $\On$ denotes the class of ordinals.

2c072427-6d69-4e35-b535-4940f299bb2b.text:
Let $E/F$ be a field extension.
Let $\operatorname{Aut}(E/F)$ be its automorphism group.
Let $S\subset E$ be a generating set of the extension.
Let $S$ be stable under the group action of $\operatorname{Aut}(E/F)$.
Then the induced group action on $S$ is faithful.

a240f1d0-8cc5-4e67-aa09-8aca898e45a9.text:
Let $\struct {S, *, \circ}$ be a cancellable semiring with unity $1_S$.
Then the distributand $*$ is commutative.
That is to say, $\struct {S, *, \circ}$ is also an additive semiring.

d5237168-1437-4e3d-b84c-0c96247dd1b7.text:
Let $S$ be a finite set.
Let $f: S \to S$ be an injection.
Then $f$ is also a surjection.

0a21325d-c024-4354-a935-96868557304c.text:
Let $T_1 = \struct {S, \tau_S}$ be a topological space.
Let $D = \struct {A, \set {\O, A} }$ be the indiscrete topology on an arbitrary doubleton $A = \set {a, b}$.
Let $T = \struct {T_1 \times D, \tau}$ be the double pointed topological space on $T_1$.
Then $T \times D$ is a $T_3$ space {{iff}} $T$ is also a $T_3$ space.

989811ec-03db-4145-b053-e31a2257cb17.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Let $\mathbb I \subseteq \R$ be the closed unit interval $\closedint 0 1$.
Let $a, b, c$ be three distinct points of $T$.
Let $f, g: \mathbb I \to T$ be arcs in $T$ from $a$ to $b$ and from $b$ to $c$ respectively.
Let $h: \mathbb I \to T$ be the mapping given by:
:$\map h x = \begin{cases}
\map f {2 x} & : x \in \closedint 0 {\dfrac 1 2} \\
\map g {2 x - 1} & : x \in \closedint {\dfrac 1 2} 1
\end{cases}$
Then either:
:$h$ is an arc in $T$
or
:There exists some restriction of $h$ which, possibly after reparametrisation, is an arc in $T$.

0d52baa3-7499-494a-a205-00259d6119e9.text:
Let $\struct {R, *}$ be a commutative semigroup, all of whose elements are cancellable.
Let $\struct {T, *}$ be an inverse completion of $\struct {R, *}$.
Let $\circ$ be an operation on $R$ which distributes over $*$.
Then:
:There exists a unique operation $\circ'$ on $T$ which distributes over $*$ in $T$ and induces on $R$ the operation $\circ$.

9071fe48-436d-4126-b9e2-5056fdf3a28a.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be an abelian group whose identity element is $e$.
Let $*$ be the product inverse operation on $G$:
:$\forall a, b \in G: a * b = a \circ b^{-1}$
where $b^{-1}$ is the inverse element of $b$ under the operation $\circ$.
Then the algebraic structure $\struct {G, *}$ is a commutative $B$-algebra.
That is:
:$\forall a, b \in G: a * \paren {0 * b} = b * \paren {0 * a}$

7f6d73fb-8ec9-4171-8148-d5635096f4b7.text:
Let $G$ be a group which acts on a finite set $X$.
Let $x \in X$.
Let $\Orb x$ denote  the orbit of $x$.
Let $\Stab x$ denote the stabilizer of $x$ by $G$.
Let $\index G {\Stab x}$ denote the index of $\Stab x$ in $G$.
Then:
:$\order {\Orb x} = \index G {\Stab x} = \dfrac {\order G} {\order {\Stab x} }$

43797414-4f80-4ee4-8453-b6e103bccc8d.text:
Let $M = \struct {A, d}$ be a complete metric space.
Then $M = \struct {A, d}$ is also a Baire space.

9a1424b4-2bde-4df0-ae89-f6b4696840ed.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ be ordered sets.
Let $\phi: \struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1} \to \struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ be an order isomorphism.
Then $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ is a well-ordered set {{iff}} $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ is also a well-ordered set.

b30ccbd5-5a0b-4152-ac51-583ca6adf583.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number such that $x > 0$.
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer such that $n < 0$.
Then there exists a $y \in \R: y \ge 0$ such that $y^n = x$.

649eeff1-ba1d-4136-9f0f-3ddfbe7a9e77.text:
Let $p$ be a permutable prime with more than $1$ digit.
Then $p$ contains only digits from the set:
:$\left\{ {1, 3, 7, 9}\right\}$

2e541e0f-aa28-4124-a3c7-cb77db1d0e1d.text:
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $S_1$ and $S_2$ be subsets of $S$.
Let $S_1 \setminus S_2$ denote the set difference between $S_1$ and $S_2$.
Then:
:$\forall S_1, S_2 \subseteq S: f \left[{S_1}\right] \setminus f \left[{S_2}\right] = f \left[{S_1 \setminus S_2}\right]$
{{iff}} $f$ is an injection.

4768cd7b-cab4-4ce6-b7c9-2ec712051bf7.text:
Consider the sequence of Wythoff pairs arranged in sequential order:
:$\tuple {0, 0}, \tuple {1, 2}, \tuple {3, 5}, \tuple {4, 7}, \tuple {6, 10}, \tuple {8, 13}, \ldots$
Apart from the first Wythoff pair $\tuple {0, 0}$, every positive integer appears in this sequence exactly once.

f43c47ae-496e-41b0-b2f7-9556856e9f36.text:
The (ordered) field $\struct {\Q, +, \times, \le}$ of rational numbers forms a subfield of the field of real numbers $\struct {\R, +, \times, \le}$.
That is, the field of real numbers $\struct {\R, +, \times, \le}$ is an extension of the rational numbers $\struct {\Q, +, \times, \le}$.

00b8f73f-143d-4209-9769-001f20a42e07.text:
Let $M$ be a compact manifold with boundary $\partial M$.
Then there is no smooth mapping $f: M \to \partial M$ such that $\partial f: \partial M \to \partial M$ is the identity.
