:$\map K k$ is the complete elliptic integral of the first kind.

53ad3e46-2560-4d72-99db-c99d90673ccd.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=44|body=A second bimedial straight line is divided at one point only.}}

3ba83d11-7874-4bba-a5cb-acd4b7f4ceff.text:
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}$ and $M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}$ be metric spaces.
Let $\AA = A_1 \times A_2$ be the cartesian product of $A_1$ and $A_2$.
Let $d_\infty: \AA \times \AA \to \R$ be the Chebyshev distance on $\AA$:
:$\ds \map {d_\infty} {x, y} = \max \set {\map {d_1} {x_1, y_1}, \map {d_2} {x_2, y_2} }$
where $x = \tuple {x_1, x_2}, y = \tuple {y_1, y_2} \in \AA$.
Let $\Gamma_f$ be the graph of $f$.
Let $f: M_1 \to M_2$ be a mapping such that the $\Gamma_f$ is a closed set of $\struct {A_1 \times A_2, d}$.
Then it is not necessarily the case that $f$ is a continuous mapping.

abc80676-5055-450a-a606-39b6c3b50c49.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a discrete topological space.
Let $A \subseteq S$.
Then:
:$A = A^\circ = A^-$
where:
:$A^\circ$ is the interior of $A$
:$A^-$ is the closure of $A$.

a732bd45-893f-45a7-b720-62e5bdbc8564.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let:
:$\card S = n$
where $\card S$ denotes the cardinality of $S$.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a surjection.
Then $\card T \le n$.
The equality:
:$\card T = n$
occurs {{iff}} $f$ is a bijection.

282a039e-226a-4bc4-b7a5-dc3f148f897d.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let:
:$\symdif$ denote the symmetric difference operation
:$\cap$ denote the set intersection operation
:$\powerset S$ denote the power set of $S$.
Then $\struct {\powerset S, \symdif, \cap}$ is a commutative ring with unity, in which the unity is $S$.
This ring is not an integral domain.

face1377-92f5-49d6-b938-2317c5a257fe.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity whose zero is $0_R$ and whose unity is $1_R$.
Let the characteristic of $R$ be $p$.
Let $g_a: \Z \to R$ be the mapping from the integers into $R$ defined as:
:$\forall n \in \Z:\forall a \in R: \map {g_a} n = n \cdot a$
where $\cdot$ denotes the multiple operation.
Then:
:$p \divides n \implies n \cdot a = 0_R$
where $p \divides n$ denotes that $p$ is a divisor of $n$.

fa42835c-3302-43e6-9805-cc30783dd099.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\struct {S, \gets}$ be the algebraic structure formed from $S$ under the left operation.
Let $f$ be a permutation on $S$.
Then $f$ is an automorphism of $f$.

5a1d1f50-4577-4d68-a01b-2c69536e4abf.text:
Let $f: \C \to \R$ be the projection from the complex numbers to the real numbers defined as:
:$\forall z \in \C: \map f z = \map \Im z$
where $\map \Im z$ denotes the imaginary part of $z$.
Then $f$ is a surjection.

1c421f21-96dd-4d9a-84a7-c47194e032cb.text: The set of complex numbers $\C$ forms a ring under addition and multiplication: $\struct {\C, +, \times}$.

3b151820-2182-4235-80da-1a6ed24c05ed.text:
Let $A$ be a non-empty class.
Let $\RR$ be a strictly well-founded relation on $A$.
Then $A$ has a strictly minimal element under $\RR$.
$\map F n$ is a set for each $n \in \omega$.

fbaa8e3c-0671-4f2f-9e80-b1821bd46451.text:
Everywhere that the function is defined:
:$\map \arcsec {-x} = \pi - \arcsec x$

8828ecab-1753-4055-b5e0-62f3a8bf7133.text:
Let $S$ be a singleton:
:$S = \set s$
for an arbitrary object $s$.
Let $+$ be the operation on $S$ defined as:
:$\forall s \in S:  s + s = s$
Let $\le$ be the relation defined on $S$ as:
:$s \le s$
Then the algebraic structure:
:$\struct {S, +, \le}$
is an ordered semigroup which fulfils the axioms:
:{{NOSAxiom|1}}
:{{NOSAxiom|2}}
:{{NOSAxiom|3}}
but:
:does not fulfil {{NOSAxiom|4}}
:$\struct {S, +}$ is not isomorphic to $\struct {\N, +}$.

d67aeb7f-34dd-4715-ad6d-2ef3c7edaf90.text:
Let $H_n$ be the Hilbert matrix of order $n$:
:$\begin{bmatrix} a_{i j} \end{bmatrix} = \begin{bmatrix} \dfrac 1 {i + j - 1} \end{bmatrix}$
Consider its inverse $H_n^{-1}$.
All the elements of $H_n^{-1}$ are integers.

27a06b8f-7fc0-4a51-8947-589d13b40472.text:
Let $G$ be the graph of the function $y = \map \sin {\dfrac 1 x}$ for $x > 0$.
Let $J$ be the line segment joining the points $\tuple {0, -1}$ and $\tuple {0, 1}$ in $\R^2$.
Then $G \cup J$ is connected.

120e1dfb-923d-4a5d-93d4-bab78fad49e2.text:
Let $\left({S, \vee, \wedge, 
eg}ight)$ be a Boolean algebra.
Then for all $a \in S$:
:$
eg (
eg a) = a$

1d85e064-9999-4fb6-87d4-238e35f5faf7.text:
Let $\arccot: \R \to \openint 0 \pi$ be the real arccotangent.
Then $\arccot$ is of exponential order $0$.

998f7c43-735b-41c7-a580-906d99614a9b.text:
Let $A$ be the set of all real sequences $\left\langle{x_i}\right\rangle$ such that the series $\displaystyle \sum_{i \mathop \ge 0} x_i^2$ is convergent.
Let $\ell^2 = \struct {A, d_2}$ be the Hilbert sequence space on $\R$.
Then no point of $\ell^2$ has a compact neighborhood.

6ebd50bb-6dee-4aeb-b542-21c7dd6df246.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\tau_p$ be the topology induced by the non-Archimedean norm $\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p$.
Let $\Z_p$ be the $p$-adic integers.
Then:
:$\BB_p = \set {q + p^n \Z_p : q \in \Q, n \in \Z}$
is a countable basis for $\struct{\Q_p, \tau_p}$.

6d468d2c-958a-4875-986e-4aec58904a2a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \set {S, \O} }$ be an indiscrete space.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be any sequence in $S$.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ converges to any point $x$ of $S$.

05b0867c-1714-4274-a4d5-4f2759759a6c.text:
Everywhere that the function is defined:
:$\map \arccsc {\dfrac 1 x} = \arcsin x$
where $\arcsin$ and $\arccsc$ denote arcsine and arccosecant respectively.

8a683b56-02dc-4131-8ed2-aeb75dd69d69.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \preceq}\right)$ be an ordered set.
Let $R$ be an auxiliary relation on $S$.
Let $x \in S$.
Then $R\left({x}\right)$ is an upper set
where $R\left({x}\right)$ denotes the image of $x$ under $R$.

0e8ead5f-5366-4ccb-ba44-8db1c5655f8a.text:
Let $r \in \R_{> 0}$ be a (strictly) positive real number.
Let $\psi, \tau \in \C$ be complex numbers.
Let $r^\lambda$ be defined as the the principal branch of a positive real number raised to a complex number.
Then:
:$r^{\psi \mathop + \tau} = r^\psi \times r^\tau$

0ff85bdd-922d-41e1-8ee3-8ee239b68918.text:
Let $a$ and $b$ be real numbers.
Let $i$ be the imaginary unit.
Then:
:$\sinh \paren {a + b i} = \sinh a \cos b + i \cosh a \sin b$
where:
:$\sin$ denotes the real sine function
:$\cos$ denotes the real cosine function
:$\sinh$ denotes the hyperbolic sine function
:$\cosh$ denotes the hyperbolic cosine function.

b0ebabf0-d5ee-423f-9b44-1eaf783b7c6e.text:
Let $\mathbb F \in \set {\R, \C}$.
Let $\HH$, $\KK$ and $\LL$ be a Hilbert spaces over $\mathbb F$.
Let $A : \KK \to \LL$ and $B : \HH \to \KK$ be bounded linear transformations.
Then:
:$\paren {A B}^* = B^* A^*$
where $^*$ denotes adjoining.

3cb1176a-6640-4b49-a519-2d31319e691d.text:
Let $0^*$ denote the rational cut associated with the (rational) number $0$.
Let $\alpha$ and $\beta$ be cuts such that $\alpha \ge 0^*$ and $\beta \ge 0^*$, where $\ge$ denotes the ordering on cuts.
Let $\gamma$ be the set of all rational numbers $r$ such that either:
:$r < 0$
or:
:$\exists p \in \alpha, q \in \beta: r = p q$
where $p \ge 0$ and $q \ge 0$.
Then $\gamma$ is also a cut.
Thus the operation of multiplication on the set of positive cuts is closed.

5a6a7e62-228e-4073-b1f1-7c38bbefb5ae.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be an algebraic structure.
Let $\struct {T, *}$ be a group.
Let $\phi: \struct {S, \circ} \to \struct {T, *}$ be a homomorphism.
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ have an identity $e_S$.
Then:
:$\map \phi {e_S} = e_T$

ad709ed9-dff2-4cfa-999e-23dda3be5ca7.text:
:${}^{n - 1} P_n = {}^n P_n$
where ${}^k P_n$ denotes the number of ordered selections of $k$ objects from $n$.

aad06f6f-6561-4c7e-ad80-3d6027639b03.text: :$\ds \int \frac 1 {x^2} \arccot \frac x a \rd x = -\frac 1 x \arccot \frac x a + \frac 1 {2 a} \map \ln {\frac {x^2 + a^2} {x^2} } + C$

485212c1-88e7-437d-895b-842fc405c78a.text:
Let $\struct {F_1, +_1, \circ_1}$ and $\struct {F_2, +_2, \circ_2}$ be fields.
Let $\phi: F_1 \to F_2$ be a field homomorphism such that $\phi$ is not the trivial homomorphism.
If $K$ is a subfield of $F_1$, then $\phi \sqbrk K$ is a subfield of $F_2$.

2b8ec2ef-972a-4d57-b1b0-b006e0ebcfc2.text:
The set $\R_{>0}$ of strictly positive real numbers is closed under multiplication:
:$\forall a, b \in \R_{> 0}: a \times b \in \R_{> 0}$

136df8f1-933a-46bf-9aee-085ef3097f8c.text:
Let $\struct {R_1, +_1, \circ_1}, \struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2}, \ldots, \struct {R_n, +_n, \circ_n}$ be rings.
Let $\ds \struct {R, +, \circ} = \prod_{k \mathop = 1}^n \struct {R_k, +_k, \circ_k}$ be their direct product.
For each $k \in \closedint 1 n$, let:
:${R_k}' = \set {\tuple {x_1, \ldots, x_n} \in R: \forall j \ne k: x_j = 0}$
Let $\pr_k: R \to {R_k}'$ be the projection on the $k$th coordinate of $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ onto ${R_k}'$.
Then $\pr_k$ is an epimorphism.

511c8301-d618-44d3-bd87-2f31b9269fbc.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $\sequence {A_n}$ be a sequence of connected subsets of $T$ with:
:$A_i \cap A_{i + 1} \ne \O$
for each $i$.
Then: 
:$\ds \bigcup_{i \mathop = 1}^\infty A_i$
is connected.

f66b4c80-20d9-4ac8-89c5-b78887dd83fe.text: The Euclidean metric on a real vector space $\R^n$ is a metric.

dd061c92-01e2-45c1-9683-a99f36accb5a.text:
Let $G$ be a finite group.
Let $\HH_1$ and $\HH_2$ be two normal series for $G$.
Then $\HH_1$ and $\HH_2$ have refinements of equal length whose factors are isomorphic.

020abbb9-b505-4211-823f-72de266d7e4e.text:
Let $a \in \R_{>0}$ be a strictly positive real constant.
Let $\size x < a$.
Then:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {a^2 - x^2} = \dfrac 1 {2 a} \map \ln {\dfrac {a + x} {a - x} } + C$

5fafafef-5ec4-4949-a87d-c0f0df75d123.text:
A square number $n^2$ can end in a repeated digit {{iff}} either:
:$(1): \quad n^2$ is a multiple of $100$, in which case $n$ is a multiple of $10$
:$(2): \quad n^2$ ends in $44$ and $n$ ends in $12, 38, 62$ or $88$.

486d6b20-05d3-415f-8d5f-cd5fef56f41e.text:
Let $\dbinom n k$ be a binomial coefficient.
Then $\dbinom n k$ is an integer.

dcba6e4b-8283-4c9c-9c5e-d8179f216574.text:
:$\ds \int \map F {\arcsin \frac x a} \rd x = a \int \map F u \cos u \rd u$
where $u = \arcsin \dfrac x a$.

8a65dc0a-982c-47c7-9e83-12a437a6d622.text:
Let $\map f z, \map j z, \map k z$ be single-valued continuous complex functions in a domain $D \subseteq \C$, where $D$ is open.
Let $f$, $j$, and $k$ be complex-differentiable at all points in $D$.
Let $\map f z = \map j z + \map k z$.
Then:
:$\forall z \in D: \map {f'} z = \map {j'} z + \map {k'} z$

921c23fe-9a52-424e-923f-c41f8ba88df9.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \vee, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a complete lattice.
Then
:$L$ is bounded.

dfed4c11-47f0-4173-ac66-c27cc5208d52.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=97|body=The square on an apotome applied to a rational straight line produces as breadth a first apotome.}}

313f8387-dd76-4c38-b4c9-7c0adbfadf70.text:
Let $S$ be a non-empty set.
Let $f, g, h: S \to \Q$ be rational-valued functions.
Let $f \times g: S \to \Q$ denote the pointwise product of $f$ and $g$.
Then:
:$\paren {f \times g} \times h = f \times \paren {g \times h}$
That is, pointwise multiplication on rational-valued functions is associative.

3e256251-6758-4a6a-b40b-a968742d0168.text:
Let $f$ be a real function defined on a closed interval $\closedint a b$.
Let $f$ be piecewise continuous with one-sided limits on $\closedint a b$.
Then $f$ is Darboux integrable on $\closedint a b$.

2d55abc8-7553-487f-82ce-a62858cc7b6b.text:
Let $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ be the irrational number space under the Euclidean topology $\tau_d$.
Then $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ is a complete metric space.

c13c4d50-8372-4c8c-8161-db3df8975fe2.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ and $\struct {H, \circ}$ be groups.
Let $\phi: G \to H$ and $\psi: G \to H$ be homomorphisms. 
Let $\gen S = G$ be the group generated by $S$.
Let:
:$\forall x \in S: \map \phi x = \map \psi x$
Then:
:$\phi = \psi$

97da3280-dbc7-4154-a8bc-bf021e94cf5d.text:
Let $\left \langle {x_n}\right \rangle_{n \in \N}$ be a sequence in the set $\Z$ of integers considered as a subspace of the real number line $\R$ under the Euclidean metric.
Then $\left \langle {x_n}\right \rangle_{n \in \N}$ converges in $\R$ to a limit {{iff}}:
:$\exists k \in \N: \forall m \in \N: m > k: x_m = x_k$
That is, {{iff}} the sequence reaches some value of $\Z$ and "stays there".

38e8ceb2-5bb7-4992-94fd-505ae7a8ff95.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let:
:$x H$ denote the left coset of $H$ by $x$
:$H y$ denote the right coset of $H$ by $y$.
Then:
:$\order {\set {x H: x \in G} } = \order {\set {H y: y \in G} }$

690ecf7f-7f67-49ee-84f9-bdf5a440500d.text:
Let a circle $C_1$ of radius $b$ roll without slipping around the outside of a circle $C_2$ of radius $a$.
Let $C_2$ be embedded in a cartesian plane with its center $O$ located at the origin.
Let $P$ be a point on the circumference of $C_1$.
Let $C_1$ be initially positioned so that $P$ is its point of tangency to $C_2$, located at point $A = \tuple {a, 0}$ on the $x$-axis.
Let $H$ be the epicycloid traced out by the point $P$.
Let $\tuple {x, y}$ be the coordinates of $P$ as it travels over the plane.
The point $P = \tuple {x, y}$ is described by the equations:
:$x = \paren {a + b} \cos \theta - b \map \cos {\paren {\dfrac {a + b} b} \theta}$
:$y = \paren {a + b} \sin \theta - b \map \sin {\paren {\dfrac {a + b} b} \theta}$

c63ddb5c-c61c-4277-8376-539bf139038f.text:
Let $F_k$ be the $k$'th Fibonacci number.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{j \mathop = 1}^{2 n} F_j F_{j + 1} = {F_{2 n + 1} }^2 - 1$

aa1d0345-8868-4e29-885c-93843a71ae16.text:
Let $S_n$ be the symmetric group of $n$ elements.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $S_n$.
Let $X$ be any set with $n$ elements.
Then $H$ acts on $X$ as a group of transformations on $X$.

5ce44111-a03c-48bf-963b-345607ded54d.text:
Let $n$ be a quasiperfect number.
Then:
:$n = \paren {2 k + 1}^2$
for some $k \in \Z_{>0}$.
That is, a quasiperfect number is the square of an odd integer.

ff74699b-22af-4722-a9eb-a14d8e5b40c8.text:
There exists a real function $R : \hointr 2 \infty \to \R$ such that:
:$\ds \frac {\map \psi x} {\ln x} + \map R x \le \map \pi x \le \frac {2 \map \psi x} {\ln x} + \sqrt x$
for all real numbers $x \ge 2$, where:
:$\pi$ is the prime counting function
:$\psi$ is the second Chebyshev function
:$R = \map \OO {\sqrt x \ln x}$ where $\OO$ is big-O notation.

cc8bcbb7-4cfb-4e63-9d56-e7e6bd233c9a.text:
Let $n, k \in \Z_{\ge 0}$ be positive integers.
Let $S_k = \ds \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^n i^k$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{i \mathop = 1}^k \binom {k + 1} i S_i = \paren {n + 1}^{k + 1} - \paren {n + 1}$

cf481015-355b-4710-9e5f-37e1f1846de1.text:
Let $\coth: \C \to \C$ be the hyperbolic cotangent function on the set of complex numbers.
Then $\coth$ is odd:
:$\map \coth {-x} = -\coth x$

94abf031-9821-4079-b7bf-4fe827c28f98.text:
Let $\map f x$ be a Lebesgue integrable function.
Let $s_0$ be a real number.
Let $\map h x$ be a Lebesgue integrable function such that:
:$\map h x = e^{2 \pi i x s_0} \map f x$
Then:
:$\map {\hat h} s = \map {\hat f} {s - s_0}$
where $\map {\hat h} s$ and $\map {\hat f} s$ are the Fourier transforms of $\map h x$ and $\map f x$ respectively.

4db9c2bb-b9e5-4511-9ed4-52cf69d9e006.text:
Let $D$ be an open region.
Let $f : D \to \C$ be a non-constant holomorphic function.
Then $\cmod f$ does not have any maximum points in the interior of $D$.
That is, for each $z \in D$ and $\delta > 0$, there exists some $\omega \in \map {B_\delta} z \cap D$, such that
:$\cmod {\map f \omega} > \cmod {\map f z}$.

6294d98b-65f1-464c-ab16-12023f0d8eed.text:
Let $\log_b: \R_{>0} \to \R$ be the real logarithm to base $b$.
Then $\log_b$ is completely additive.

78df6630-f42a-4130-a8a4-2528a70a1253.text:
Let $k$ be an integer such that $k > 1$.
Then the cartesian product of $k$ countable sets is countable.

cbad3208-19c1-4543-b122-2c7a32b46cd4.text:
Let $\ln x$ be the natural (base $e$) logarithm of $x$.
Let $\log_{10} x$ be the common (base $10$) logarithm of $x$.
Then:
:$\ln x = \paren {\ln 10} \paren {\log_{10} x} = 2 \cdotp 30258 \, 50929 \, 94 \ldots \log_{10} x$

5da2e146-404d-4913-a0b8-80bb2be15988.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a monoid whose identity is $e_S$.
Let $a, b \in S$ be invertible elements for $\circ$ that also commute.
Then:
:$\forall m, n \in \Z: a^m \circ b^n = b^n \circ a^m$

1ae281a1-40af-486b-bd4d-917229e8eb60.text:
There are exactly two integers which are idempotent with respect to multiplication:
:$0 \times 0 = 0$
:$1 \times 1 = 1$

967e552d-ccf1-4ef2-9670-7ee68fae74ea.text:
Let $M$ and $N$ be metric spaces.
Let $M$ be complete.
Let $f : M \times N \to M$ be a Lipschitz continuous uniform contraction.
Then for all $t\in N$ there exists a unique $\map g t \in M$ such that $\map f {\map g t, t} = \map g t$, and the mapping $g : N \to M$ is Lipschitz continuous.

8f9fe1d0-0ff2-46aa-88d5-bfd2a36cd988.text:
Let $F$ be a field.
Let $\theta \in \C$ be algebraic over $F$ of degree $n$.
Let $\map F \theta$ be the simple field extension of $F$ by $\theta$.
Then any element of $\map F \theta$ can be written as $\map f \theta$, where $\map f x$ is a polynomial over $F$ of degree at most $n - 1$.

e7df8f35-a2ec-40c8-b102-74780558b9ad.text:
Let $x$ be a limit ordinal.
Then:
:$x = \paren {\omega \times y}$ for some $y \in \On$
where $\omega$ is the minimal infinite successor set.

072d95bb-c1dd-4fbc-b867-3b75e672415b.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $G$ and $H$ be free unitary $R$-modules of finite dimensions $n, m > 0$ respectively.
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be an ordered basis of $G$.
Let $\sequence {b_m}$ be an ordered basis of $H$.
Let $\mathbf A$ and $\mathbf B$ be $m \times n$ matrices over $R$.
Let there exist:
:an invertible matrix $\mathbf P$ of order $n$
:an invertible matrix $\mathbf Q$ of order $m$
such that:
:$\mathbf B = \mathbf Q^{-1} \mathbf A \mathbf P$
Then there exist:
:a linear transformation $u: G \to H$
:ordered bases $\sequence { {a_n}'}$ and $\sequence { {b_m}'}$ of $G$ and $H$ respectively
such that:
:$\mathbf A = \sqbrk {u; \sequence {b_m}, \sequence {a_n} }$
:$\mathbf B = \sqbrk {u; \sequence { {b_m}'}, \sequence { {a_n}'} }$
where $\sqbrk {u; \sequence {b_m}; \sequence {a_n} }$ denotes the matrix of $u$ relative to $\sequence {a_n}$ and $\sequence {b_m}$.

785cbb58-f7d0-4a29-9731-76911e2a2a33.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\rd x} {p \sin a x + q \paren {1 + \cos a x} } = \frac 1 {a p} \ln \size {q + p \tan \frac {a x} 2} + C$

a03e3316-a1f4-4c58-84c0-d4c3e89fb906.text:
Every positive rational number can be written either as:
: $a^{a^a}$ for some irrational number $a$
or as:
: $n^{n^n}$ for some natural number $n$.

340bb5bd-1272-4687-8f9b-b06f5d272ccc.text:
The unit of a system of sets, if it exists, is unique.
If $U$ is the unit of a system of sets $\mathcal S$, then $\forall A \in \mathcal S: A \subseteq U$.

dc13aa12-5bde-4362-9a55-0870e85825ed.text:
Let $\R$ denote the real number line with the usual (Euclidean) metric.
Let $a \in \R$ be a point in $\R$.
Let $\BB_a$ be defined as:
:$\BB_a := \set {\map {B_\epsilon} a: \epsilon \in \set {\dfrac 1 n: n \in \N} }$
that is, the set of all open $\epsilon$-balls of $a$ for $\epsilon$ which are reciprocals of integers.
Then $\BB_a$ is a basis for the neighborhood system of $a$.

5fdb694e-8ab8-43ad-83ac-2f193a811910.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$ with the property that:
:$\forall x \in G: x^2 \in H$
Then $H$ is normal in $G$.

b4467afd-c9cf-4966-9982-990e18a45567.text:
Let $R$ be a region of space.
Let $S$ be a Newtonian potential over $R$ defined as:
:$\forall \mathbf r = x \mathbf i + y \mathbf j + z \mathbf k \in R: \map S {\mathbf r} = \dfrac k r$
where:
:$\tuple {\mathbf i, \mathbf j, \mathbf k}$ is the standard ordered basis on $R$
:$\mathbf r = x \mathbf i + y \mathbf j + z \mathbf k$ is the position vector of an arbitrary point in $R$ with respect to the origin
:$r = \norm {\mathbf r}$ is the magnitude of $\mathbf r$
:$k$ is some predetermined constant.
Then $S$ satisfies Laplace's equation:
:$\nabla^2 S = 0$
where $\nabla^2$ denotes the Laplacian.

1e123535-8499-4ec3-9e51-163c3101972d.text:
Let $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ and $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ be ordered sets.
Let $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$ be isomorphic to $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$.
Then $\struct {S_2, \preccurlyeq_2}$ is isomorphic to $\struct {S_1, \preccurlyeq_1}$.

640225e5-6e78-4adb-b4d3-f6664fc83cb8.text:
Let $z \in \C$.
Let $\exp$ denote the complex exponential function.
Then:
:$\dfrac 1 {\map \exp z} = \map \exp {-z}$

976c76db-6560-4a24-b346-740b66433c8a.text:
Let $S$ be any non-empty set.
Then $\set {S, \O}$ is (trivially) an algebra of sets, where $S$ is the unit.

037b3f72-c4bd-46e5-b34a-e0a74f5953b4.text:
Let $\zeta$ be the Riemann zeta function:
:$\ds \forall s \in \C: \map \Re s > 1: \map \zeta s = \sum_{n \mathop \ge 1} n^{-s}$
Then for all $s$ with $\map \Re s > 1$:
:$\ds -\frac {\map {\zeta'} s} {\map \zeta s} = \sum_{n \mathop \ge 1} \map \Lambda n n^{-s}$
where $\Lambda$ is von Mangoldt's function.

d378e695-072a-4347-928b-137ef4bca567.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $\powerset T$ be the power set of $T$.
Let $\mathbb T \subseteq \powerset T$.
Then:
:$\ds S \setminus \bigcap \mathbb T = \bigcup_{T' \mathop \in \mathbb T} \paren {S \setminus T'}$
where:
:$\ds \bigcap \mathbb T := \set {x: \forall T' \in \mathbb T: x \in T'}$
that is, the intersection of $\mathbb T$

cff1c431-cb61-4af4-ab4f-9a3a4f19cfaa.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau_p}$ be an uncountable particular point space.
Let $H = S \setminus \set p$ where $\setminus$ denotes set difference.
Then $H$ is not separable.

b525c59b-e855-4e36-a82f-4a7364698856.text: The identity mapping $I_S: S \to S$ on the set $S$ is a permutation.

fde93d78-e279-4d36-bb98-036afe49a024.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is continuous on the closed interval $\closedint a b$ and differentiable on the open interval $\openint a b$.
Let $f$ be convex on $\openint a b$.
Then:
:$\forall \xi \in \openint a b: \map f x - \map f \xi \ge \map {f'} \xi \paren {x - \xi}$

22bfb0dc-e7f2-42ff-afd3-3a5b6aeedbce.text:
Let $\mathbf A = \sqbrk a_n$ be a square matrix of order $n$ over a commutative ring $R$.
Then $\mathbf A$ can be converted to an upper or lower triangular matrix by elementary row operations.

f77ad684-55a1-467c-8605-a14324e3a911.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $P = \struct {\tau, \subseteq}$ be an inclusion ordered set of $\tau$.
Then $P$ is bounded below and $\bot_P = \O$

09d4a3b1-1674-4b7b-a690-9391576b1c9a.text:
:$\tan x \paren {\tan x + \cot x} = \sec^2 x$
where $\tan$, $\cot$ and $\sec$ denote tangent, cotangent and secant respectively.

a5c07e05-8c97-44df-8da5-80ddb6819832.text:
Let $X$ be a set on which there is a pseudometric $d: X \times X \to \R$.
For any $x, y \in X$, let $x \sim y$ denote that $\map d {x, y} = 0$.
Let $\eqclass x \sim$ denote the equivalence class of $x$ under $\sim$.
Let $X^*$ be the quotient of $X$ by $\sim$.
Then the mapping $d^*: X^* \times X^* \to \R$ defined by:
:$\map {d^*} {\eqclass x \sim, \eqclass y \sim} = \map d {x, y}$
is a metric.
Hence $\struct {X^*, d^*}$ is a metric space.

54ed66f6-cf3d-46bb-af4f-8d2f36ba1f6f.text:
The Euler $\phi$ function is a multiplicative function:
:$m \perp n \implies \map \phi {m n} = \map \phi m \, \map \phi n$
where $m, n \in \Z_{>0}$.

bcb7ab18-aa1b-4833-a274-e8e007fd83b4.text:
Let $\O$ denote the empty set.
Then the singleton $\set \O$ is supercomplete.

db24c346-0033-41b6-9c88-354519d4c0f1.text:
Let $\laptrans f$ denote the Laplace transform of a function $f$.
Let $e^x$ be the real exponential.
Then:
:$\map {\laptrans {e^{a t} } } s = \dfrac 1 {s - a}$
where $a \in \R$ is constant, and $\map \Re s > \map \Re a$.

f01e679d-1e07-49e5-83e8-c6940266929b.text:
Let $\struct {G, \circ}$ and $\struct {H, *}$ be groups.
Let $\phi: \struct {G, \circ} \to\struct {H, *}$ be a group homomorphism.
Let:
:$e_G$ be the identity of $G$
:$e_H$ be the identity of $H$
Then:
:$\forall x \in G: \map \phi {x^{-1} } = \paren {\map \phi x}^{-1}$

e7400666-1016-41d4-9bf7-c54936eb93ed.text:
Let $\RR$ denote the set of rational cuts.
Let $\struct {\RR, +, \times, \le}$ denote the ordered structure formed from $\RR$ and:
:the operation $+$ of addition of cuts
:the operation $\times$ of multiplication of cuts
:the ordering $\le$ of cuts.
Then $\struct {\RR, + \times, \le}$ is an ordered field.

e8d32ec7-e429-4738-9409-78144e9ff63c.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Then the valuation ideal induced by norm $\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p$ is the principal ideal:
:$p \Z_p = \set {x \in \Q_p: \norm x_p < 1}$
where $\Z_p$ denotes the $p$-adic integers.

0e415ca5-45d7-4dd9-b8fe-03acd34048b1.text: {{TFAE|def = Image of Mapping|view = image of a mapping}}

e809e833-5089-40d2-ace8-ad7378a97941.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be such that $\size{x} < 1$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be the sequence in $\R$ defined as $x_n = x^n$.
Then $\sequence {x_n}$ is a null sequence.

25cc9150-da17-43fa-be43-9ed041b4ff8c.text: $\omega$, the minimal infinite successor set, is an element of the infinite cardinal class $\mathcal N’$.

8edf2142-cc23-4a57-b314-6604227246c2.text:
Let $a \in \R_{\ne 0}$.
Then:
:$\ds \int x \sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} \rd x = \frac {\paren {\sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} }^3} {3 a} - \frac b {2 a} \int \sqrt {a x^2 + b x + c} \rd x$

ee55683b-315d-44bf-bacc-7f9b860bcd2a.text:
Consider the algebraic structure $\struct {\Q, +, \times}$, where:
:$\Q$ is the set of all rational numbers
:$+$ is the operation of rational addition
:$\times$ is the operation of rational multiplication.
Then $\struct {\Q, +, \times}$ forms a field.

46eb02f9-6073-4623-a8dc-49a91ab83155.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $L \subseteq S$.
Then:
:$L$ is a lower set in $S$ with no maximal element
{{iff}}:
:$\ds L = \bigcup \set {l^\prec: l \in L}$
where $l^\prec$ is the strict lower closure of $l$.

9b8563da-328e-4403-bbd2-ec9a0e00e809.text:
For all $\theta$ such that $\theta \ne 0, \pm \pi, \pm 2 \pi \ldots$
:$\dfrac {\sin 4 \theta} {\sin \theta} = 8 \cos^3 \theta - 4 \cos \theta$
where $\sin$ denotes sine and $\cos$ denotes cosine.

3ffbf308-5aea-4946-98bf-6fe624803efe.text:
:$\dfrac {\sin 6 \theta} {\sin \theta} = 32 \cos^5 \theta - 32 \cos^3 \theta + 6 \cos \theta$
where $\cos$ denotes cosine and $\sin$ denotes sine.

10ec556c-89a5-47a3-a965-1d738a0fbf2b.text:
Let $\mathbf a$ and $\mathbf b$ be vectors in the Euclidean space $\R^3$.
Let $\mathbf a \times \mathbf b$ denote the vector cross product.
Then:
:$(1): \quad$ $\mathbf a$ and $\mathbf a \times \mathbf b$ are orthogonal.
:$(2): \quad$ $\mathbf b$ and $\mathbf a \times \mathbf b$ are orthogonal.

6003dcfc-e1b5-4365-8f16-ac5cee97f675.text:
Let the probability space of an experiment $\EE$ be $\struct {\Omega, \Sigma, \Pr}$.
Let $A \in \Sigma$ be an events of $\EE$, so that $A \subseteq \Omega$.
Then:
:$A \cup \overline A = \Omega$
where $\overline A$ is the complementary event to $A$.
That is, $A \cup \overline A$ is a certainty.

e909d7db-4f59-4107-8600-0a6d7e7542d0.text:
Let $x, b \in \R$ be strictly positive real numbers such that $b > 1$.
Then:
:$\map {\log_b} {\dfrac 1 x} = -\log_b x$
where $\log_b$ denotes the logarithm to base $b$.

e117f080-6615-4e9f-9db3-0444166946de.text:
Let $\mathbf A$ be a square matrix of order $n$ of the matrix space $\map {\MM_\R} n$.
Let $\mathbf I$ be the unit matrix of order $n$.
Suppose there exists a sequence of elementary row operations that reduces $\mathbf A$ to $\mathbf I$.
Then $\mathbf A$ is invertible.
Futhermore, the same sequence, when performed on $\mathbf I$, results in the inverse of $\mathbf A$.

fd4d52fd-4ad2-48f6-81ef-a194b13c67f1.text:
Let $\map P {k, n}$ be the $n$th $k$-gonal number.
Then:
:$\ds \map P {k, n} = \sum_{j \mathop = 1}^n \paren {\paren {k - 2} \paren {j - 1} + 1}$

44019db4-5b72-4115-827f-7fa140d4fb5c.text:
Let $T_A = \struct {S_A, \tau_A}$ and $T_B = \struct {S_B, \tau_B}$ be topological spaces.
Let $\phi: T_A \to T_B$ be a homeomorphism.
If $T_A$ is a $T_2$ (Hausdorff) space, then so is $T_B$.

8f8c011b-121e-49fc-b7fb-3a0bad9c06f3.text:
Let $\overline \BB$ be the extended real $\sigma$-algebra.
Let $\map \BB \R$ be the Borel $\sigma$-algebra on $\R$.
Then:
:$\overline \BB_\R = \map \BB \R$
where $\overline \BB_\R$ denotes a trace $\sigma$-algebra.

50599035-d93f-42b5-baaa-126eb0eaba2a.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
The integers $\Z$ are dense in the closed ball $\map {B^-_1} 0$.

46f216c0-7a19-4d2a-baa7-ee7610d4ef34.text:
Let $a, b, c, d \in \Z$ such that $b d \ne 0$.
Then:
:$\dfrac a b + \dfrac c d = \dfrac {a D + B c} {\lcm \set {b, d} }$
where:
:$B = \dfrac b {\gcd \set {b, d} }$
:$D = \dfrac d {\gcd \set {b, d} }$
:$\lcm$ denotes lowest common multiple
:$\gcd$ denotes greatest common divisor.

8c334dbb-9f4d-40dd-8543-4ea11b8c42a3.text: The set of Gaussian rationals $\Q \sqbrk i$, under the operations of complex addition and complex multiplication, forms a number field.

a96f8af9-98df-4fb7-86c3-c750baf1eb02.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $f: \powerset S \to \powerset S$ be a closure operator on $S$.
Let $\CC$ be the set of all subsets of $S$ that are closed with respect to $f$.
Let $\AA \subseteq \CC$.
Then $\bigcap \AA \in \CC$.

26fb460c-7a1c-48e2-b40e-0b474af86888.text:
Let $L_n$ denote the $n$th Lucas number.
Then:
:$L_{2 n} = {L_n}^2 + 2 \left({-1}\right)^n$

a5948e9c-f6b0-4600-89e1-454af49903a7.text:
:$\floor {0 \cdotp 99999} = 0$
where $\floor x$ denotes the floor of $x$.

ad98f659-389c-4fde-8230-01eb46ad55cc.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ}$ be a quasigroup.
Let $\sigma: S \to S$ be a permutation on $S$.
Let $\struct {S, \circ_\sigma}$ be the structure induced by $\sigma$ on $\circ$:
:$\forall x, y \in S: x \circ_\sigma y := \map \sigma {x \circ y}$
Then $\struct {S, \circ_\sigma}$ is also a quasigroup.

ec468329-a3b0-45c7-9770-23e5f58b73d8.text:
Let $\sin: \C \to \C$ be the complex sine function. 
Then $\sin$ is entire.

d595e1ca-3bea-4a00-8f4c-6e7459574637.text:
Let $\struct {K, +, \circ}$ be a division ring.
Let $n \in \N_{>0}$.
Let $\mathbf V := \struct {K^n, +, \times}_K$ be the '''$K$-vector space $K^n$'''.
Then the dimension of $\mathbf V$ is $n$.

b2177a64-b94f-4154-a526-1d9bf7e6e232.text:
Let $\map \MM {m, n}$ be a metric space of order $m \times n$ over a field $K$.
Let $\mathbf A \in \map \MM {m, n}$ be a matrix. 
Let $\Gamma_1$ be a row operation which transforms $\mathbf A$ to a new matrix $\mathbf B \in \map \MM {m, n}$.
Let $\Gamma_2$ be a row operation which transforms $\mathbf B$ to another new matrix $\mathbf C \in \map \MM {m, n}$.
Then there exists another row operation $\Gamma$ which transforms $\mathbf A$ back to $\mathbf C$ such that $\Gamma$ consists of $\Gamma_1$ followed by $\Gamma_2$.

15a103ec-4445-47d4-b9bb-6d3cb9d84e8d.text:
Let $n \in \N_{>0}$.
Let $M_1 = \struct {A_1, d_1}, M_2 = \struct {A_2, d_2}, \ldots, M_n = \struct {A_n, d_n}$ be metric spaces.
Let $N_1 = \struct {B_1, d'_1}, N_2 = \struct {B_2, d'_2}, \ldots, N_n = \struct {B_n, d'_n}$ be metric spaces.
Let $f_i: M_i \to N_i$ be continuous mappings for all $i \in \set {1, 2, \ldots, n}$.
Let $\ds \MM = \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^n M_i$ be the cartesian product of $A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n$.
Let $\ds \NN = \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^n N_i$ be the cartesian product of $B_1, B_2, \ldots, B_n$.
Let $d_\infty$ be the Chebyshev distance on $\ds \AA = \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^n A_i$, and $\ds \BB = \prod_{i \mathop = 1}^n B_i$, defined as:
:$\ds \map {d_\infty} {x, y} = \max_{i \mathop = 1}^n \set {\map {d_i} {x_i, y_i} }$
:$\ds \map {d_\infty} {x, y} = \max_{i \mathop = 1}^n \set {\map {d'_i} {x_i, y_i} }$
where $x = \tuple {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n}, y = \tuple {y_1, y_2, \ldots, y_n} \in \AA$ or $\BB$.
Let $F: M \to N$ be the mapping defined as:
:$\forall x \in \AA: \map F {x_1, x_2, \ldots, x_n} = \tuple {\map f {x_1}, \map f {x_2}, \ldots, \map f {x_n} }$
Then $F$ is continuous.

ebc06a7f-3467-4222-80a0-e4a8b4f896f8.text:
Consider the subset $S$ of the complex plane defined as:
:$S := \set {\dfrac i n : n \in \Z_{>0} }$
That is:
:$S := \set {i, \dfrac i 2, \dfrac i 3, \dfrac i 4, \ldots}$
where $i$ is the imaginary unit.
No point of $S$ is an interior point.

d2019e9d-8c34-476f-9b98-45f3ff029486.text:
Let $T = \struct {\CC, \tau_d}$ be the Cantor space.
Then $T$ is totally separated.

ce24ab05-2c7c-451a-8d21-8042e1babacf.text:
Let $z_1, z_2 \in \C$ be complex numbers.
Let $\exp z$ be the exponential of $z$.
Then:
:$\map \exp {z_1 - z_2} = \dfrac {\exp z_1} {\exp z_2}$

c9d5c066-4fb2-41a1-b0f6-c27f3b8644d6.text:
Let $\struct {F, +, \times}$ be a field whose zero is $0$ and whose unity is $1$.
Let the characteristic of $F$ be $n$ such that $n > 0$.
Then:
:$n \cdot a = 0$
where $n \cdot a$ denotes the power of $a$ in the context of the additive group $\struct {F, +}$:
:$n \cdot a = \begin {cases}
0 & : n = 0 \\
\paren {\paren {n - 1} \cdot a} + a & : n > 0
\end {cases}$

ca587345-85b8-4d0e-804c-443ee52d8812.text:
Let $\mathbb T = \set {T_i: i \mathop \in I}$, where each $T_i$ is a set and $I$ is some finite indexing set.
Then:
:$\ds S \setminus \bigcap_{i \mathop \in I} T_i = \bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} \paren {S \setminus T_i}$

51b48c67-42e5-423f-b9d4-4230c16e17b0.text:
Let $\struct {S, \RR}$ be a relational structure.
Then $\RR$ is a well-founded relation {{iff}} there exists no infinite sequence $\sequence {a_n}$ of elements of $S$ such that:
:$\forall n \in \N: \paren {a_{n + 1} \mathrel \RR a_n} \text { and } \paren {a_{n + 1} \ne a_n}$

3220e166-2311-43ff-89d2-6ccff959f821.text:
:$\ds \int \cos^2 x \rd x = \frac x 2 + \frac {\sin 2 x} 4 + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

d7d9508f-d5a1-427f-a9fb-7f1a411ff6a8.text:
For all $m, n \in \Z_{\ge 0}$:
:$\ds \sum_k {n \brace k} {k \brack m} \paren {-1}^{n - k} = \delta_{m n}$
where:
:$\ds {n \brace k}$ denotes a Stirling number of the second kind
:$\ds {k \brack m}$ denotes an unsigned Stirling number of the first kind
:$\delta_{m n}$ denotes the Kronecker delta.

4473ad53-42d3-473d-9ebf-bf6b1603f2d8.text:
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be a null sequence in $\R$, that is:
:$a_n \to 0$ as $n \to \infty$
Let $\sequence {z_n}$ be a sequence in $\C$.
Suppose $\sequence {a_n}$ dominates $\sequence {z_n}$.
That is:
: $\forall n \in \N: \cmod {z_n} \le a_n$
Then $\sequence {z_n}$ is a null sequence.
This result is also known, in the UK in particular, as the '''sandwich theorem''' or the '''sandwich rule'''.
In that culture, the word '''{{WP|Sandwich|sandwich}}''' traditionally means specifically enclosing food between two slices of bread, as opposed to the looser usage of the '''{{WP|Open_sandwich|open sandwich}}''', where the there is only one such slice.
Hence, in idiomatic British English, one can refer to the (often uncomfortable) situation of being between two entities as being '''sandwiched''' between them.
As the idiom is not universal globally, the term '''squeeze theorem''' is preferred on {{ProofWiki}}, for greatest comprehension.
Category:Limits of Sequences

b7f12bf8-39a4-4c01-a8c5-1393bc04263c.text:
The factorial function can be approximated by the formula:
:$n! \sim \sqrt {2 \pi n} \paren {\dfrac n e}^n$
where $\sim$ denotes asymptotically equal.

f3c9fa35-cc28-41b7-9004-5a4356f4e381.text:
Let $z := \polar {r, \theta}$ be a complex number expressed in polar form, such that $z \ne 0$.
Then the complex cube roots of $z$ are given by:
:$z^{1 / 3} = \set {r^{1 / 3} \paren {\map \cos {\dfrac {\theta + 2 \pi k} 3} + i \, \map \sin {\dfrac {\theta + 2 \pi k} 3} }: k \in \set {0, 1, 2} }$
There are $3$ distinct such complex cube roots.
These can also be expressed as:
:$z^{1 / 3} = \set {r^{1 / 3} e^{i \paren {\theta + 2 \pi k} / 3}: k \in \set {0, 1, 2} }$
or:
:$z^{1 / 3} = \set {r^{1 / 3} e^{i \theta / 3} \omega^k: k \in \set {0, 1, 2} }$
where $\omega = e^{2 i \pi / 3} = -\dfrac 1 2 + \dfrac {i \sqrt 3} 2$ is the first cube root of unity.

f5b8a795-1a03-4c73-be14-804fda112412.text:
The volume $V_C$ of a cylinder whose bases are circles of radius $r$ and whose height is $h$ is given by the formula:
:$V_C = \pi r^2 h$

6508da85-2a9f-4f53-a2e6-d1c035a887a1.text: The set of integers under addition $\struct {\Z, +}$ forms a monoid.

c7e12409-324d-4b1d-8ff0-f53a56042218.text:
Let a pendulum with a flexible rod be suspended from a point $P$.
Let the rod be contained by a pair of bodies shaped as the arcs of a cycloid such that $P$ is the cusp between those two arcs.
:400px
Then the bob is constrained to move such that its path traces the arc of a cycloid.

f773a79f-9c0b-4d7c-8231-326c7e0930f7.text:
Let $(a_n)$ and $(b_n)$ be sequences of real or complex numbers.
Let $a_n = O(b_n)$ where $O$ denotes big-O notation.
Let $(n_k)$ be a diverging sequence of natural numbers.
Then $a_{n_k} = O(b_{n_k})$.

c2eed3c5-7d47-478e-b72f-beb4540c05af.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $f: S \to S$ be a closure operator on $S$.
Let $x \in S$.
Then $\map f x$ is the smallest closed element that succeeds $x$.

be7ca438-65aa-464d-848b-dcf83ca9a287.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\,\cdot\,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$, $\sequence {y_n} $ be Cauchy sequences in $R$.
Then:
:$\sequence {x_n y_n}$ is a Cauchy sequence.

312e61cb-6e8d-4fc6-b63c-8c2cc7fd23c6.text: :$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {x^2 \paren {a x + b}^2} = \frac {-a} {b^2 \paren {a x + b} } - \frac 1 {b^2 x} + \frac {2 a} {b^3} \ln \size {\frac {a x + b} x} + C$

1029f769-a26e-4128-80c2-a658236a74de.text:
$\struct {\On, \cdot}$ forms an monoid, where:
:$\On$ denotes the ordinal class, and
:$\cdot$ denotes ordinal multiplication.

5e126720-913d-4853-86c0-30e6ef198a2f.text:
: $\dbinom {p^n k} {p^n} \equiv k \pmod p$
where $\dbinom {p^n k} {p^n}$ is a binomial coefficient.

5072a152-5f4b-400d-8072-6c2b02a9350f.text:
Let $\struct {F, +, \times}$ be a field whose zero is $0$ and whose unity is $1$.
Let $a, b \in F$ such that $a \ne 0$.
Then:
:$\paren {a \times b^{-1} }^{-1} = b \times a^{-1}$
This can also be expressed using the notation of division as:
:$1 / \paren {a / b} = b / a$

2731d4fe-b307-4567-838b-bc4b2510875f.text:
:$\ds \int \coth^2 x \rd x = x - \coth x + C$
where $C$ is an arbitrary constant.

e242d0fa-caab-4d0a-8493-7543d396db83.text:
Let $n \in \Z$ such that $n > 1$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^{n - 1} \cos \frac {2 k \pi} n = -1$

07c98c17-d234-416b-ab04-a406bbbb5841.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T^*_{\bar p} = \struct {S^*_p, \tau^*_{\bar p} }$ be the open extension space of $T$.
Then $T^*_{\bar p}$ is a $T_0$ (Kolmogorov) space {{iff}} $T$ is.

2595ea3e-cc72-4215-96ed-807369441bd6.text:
Let $\Q$ be the set of all rational numbers.
Let $d: \Q \times \Q \to \R$ be defined as:
:$\map d {x_1, x_2} = \size {x_1 - x_2}$
where $\size x$ is the absolute value of $x$.
Then $d$ is a metric on $\Q$ and so $\struct {\Q, d}$ is a metric space.

d6db6a13-e3ff-4555-b9ac-33da9e2ad474.text:
Let $a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_r$ be non-negative real numbers.
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $a = \max \set {a_1, a_2, \ldots, a_r}$.
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \paren {a_1^n + a_2^n + \cdots + a_r^n} = a$

b5184d23-6c1f-4fc4-b0cf-b52523db7fda.text:
Let $\mathbf {Grp}$ be the category of groups.
Let $\set e$ be the trivial group.
Then $\set e$ is a terminal object of $\mathbf {Grp}$.

1550be09-8152-483e-a6f3-5fe6d5d20092.text:
Let $S, T$ be sets.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Then:
:$\forall x, y \in S: f \sqbrk {\set {x, y} } = \set {\map f x, \map f y}$

db8008de-ed4c-41ec-983a-7c49e58b5f47.text:
Let $\tuple {x, y} \stackrel u {\longrightarrow} \map u {x, y}: \R^2 \to \R$ be the Heaviside step function.
Let $u := T_u$ be the distribution associated with $u$.
Let $\delta_{\tuple {0, 0} } \in \map {\DD'} {\R^2}$ be the Dirac delta distribution.
Then in the distributional sense:
:$\dfrac {\partial^2 u} {\partial x \partial y} = \delta_{\tuple {0, 0}}$

3f6a61c7-1589-4b45-8a5f-5d890cd89549.text:
Let $\struct {G, +}$ be an abelian group.
Then:
:$\forall x, y \in G: \forall k \in \Z: k \cdot \paren {x + y} = \paren {k \cdot x} + \paren {k \cdot y}$

2c017fa6-677e-4b01-a2dc-7025aa2609ba.text:
The logarithmic integral can be defined in terms of a non-convergent series.
That is:
:$\ds \map {\operatorname {li} } z = \sum_{i \mathop = 0}^{+\infty} \frac {i! \, z} {\ln^{i + 1} z} = \frac z {\ln z} \paren {\sum_{i \mathop = 0}^{+\infty} \frac {i!} {\ln^i z} }$

e0f7fc0c-2c9c-405d-a2d8-6df0300a9634.text:
The densest packing of identical circles in the plane obtains a density of $\dfrac \pi {2 \sqrt 3} = \dfrac \pi {\sqrt {12} }$:
:$\dfrac \pi {2 \sqrt 3} = 0 \cdotp 90689 \, 96821 \ldots$
{{OEIS|A093766}}
This happens when they are packed together in a hexagonal array, with each circle touching $6$ others.

ed9911a6-2e2a-482e-a2d6-fd9b44f25a27.text:
Let $R$ be a commutative ring with unity whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $\struct {G, +_G, \circ}_R$ and $\struct {H, +_H, \circ}_R$ be $R$-modules.
Let $\map {\LL_R} {G, H}$ be the set of all linear transformations from $G$ to $H$.
Let $\struct {H, +_H, \circ}_R$ be a unitary module.
Then $\map {\LL_R} {G, H}$ is also a unitary module.

b1c52893-1cf4-4aa7-9c7f-fb2e644ae835.text:
Let $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ be the irrational number space under the Euclidean topology $\tau_d$.
Then $\struct {\R \setminus \Q, \tau_d}$ is totally separated.

fe826c8b-81cc-47ae-a9b2-3d37dc8af3fa.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space which is ultraconnected.
Then $T$ is connected.

a70a081a-4d7e-46fa-85fd-7fc6bd0ec908.text:
:$F_n = \dfrac {\phi^n} {\sqrt 5}$ rounded to the nearest integer
where:
:$F_n$ denotes the $n$th Fibonacci number
:$\phi$ denotes the golden mean.

2ed6dc51-b14b-4394-b88d-9f347fc4aaa3.text:
Let $\struct {\Q, \tau_d}$ be the rational number space under the usual (Euclidean) topology $\tau_d$.
Let $B_\alpha$ be the singleton containing the rational number $\alpha$.
Then the closure in the set of real numbers $\R$ of the union of all $B_\alpha$ is $\R$ itself:
:$\ds \map \cl {\bigcup_{\alpha \mathop \in \Q} B_\alpha} = \R$

5813136e-ffa0-4b45-ab7f-0f27482d3f41.text:
Let $G$ be a finite group.
Then $G$ has a composition series.

57326dcd-7189-454c-bcd7-90957098c90c.text:
Let $G$ and $H$ be unitary $R$-modules.
Let $\phi: G \to H$ be a non-zero linear transformation.
Let $G$ be $n$-dimensional.
Let $\sequence {a_n}$ be any ordered basis of $G$ such that $\set {a_k: r + 1 \le k \le n}$ is the basis of the kernel of $\phi$.
Then $\sequence {\map \phi {a_r} }$ is an ordered basis of the image of $\phi$.

f10a2894-6afb-43a7-be44-c5d96794857c.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\tau_p$ be the topology induced by the non-Archimedean norm $\norm {\,\cdot\,}_p$.
Then the topological space $\struct {\Q_p, \tau_p}$ is totally disconnected.

1af94585-b9f0-433e-b5c2-13e338edd842.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ and $\struct {T, \preceq'}$ be ordered sets.
Let $\phi: S \to T$ be an order embedding of $\struct {S, \preceq}$ into $\struct {T, \preceq'}$
Let $p \in S$.
Then:
:$\map {\phi^{-1} } {\map \phi p^{\succ'} } = p^\succ$
where $\cdot^\succ$ and $\cdot^{\succ'}$ represent strict upper closure with respect to $\preceq$ and $\preceq'$, respectively.

34870f6a-752f-4c46-8a69-55130d5e9172.text:
Let $F, f: D \to \C$ be complex functions, where $D$ is a connected domain.
Let $C$ be a contour that is a concatenation of the directed smooth curves $C_1, \ldots, C_n$.
Let $C_k$ be parameterized by the smooth path $\gamma_k: \closedint {a_k} {b_k} \to D$ for all $k \in \set {1, \ldots, n}$.
Suppose that $F$ is a primitive of $f$.
If $C$ has start point $z$ and end point $w$, then:
:$\ds \int_C \map f z \rd z = \map F w - \map F z$
If $C$ is a closed contour, then:
:$\ds \oint_C \map f z \rd z = 0$

bc7db4ba-75d5-45c4-94e4-ee7063f64ece.text:
Let $n\geq1$ be a natural number.
Let $p$ be a prime number
Let $n=p^\alpha q$ where $\alpha = \nu_p(n)$ is the valuation of $p$ in $n$.
Let $a\in\Z$ with $\Phi_n(a)\equiv0\pmod p$.
Then the order of $a$ modulo $p$ is $q$:
:$\operatorname{ord}_p(a) = q$.

33fff5b2-ca70-432c-9e2f-9029dafbdd07.text:
Let $\O \subsetneqq T \subsetneqq S$.
Then:
:$\set {T, \relcomp S T}$
is a partition of $S$.

c4c6fbfb-0467-46ee-aef7-42a3ce06123f.text:
Let $\struct {S, \circ, \preceq}$ be a naturally ordered semigroup.
Then:
:$\forall n \in \struct {S, \circ, \preceq}: \paren {n \circ 1}^\prec = n^\prec \cup \set n$
where $n^\prec$ is defined as the strict lower closure of $n$, that is, the set of elements strictly preceding $n$.

125a0670-0791-4b17-a807-84ed10d4e3ab.text:
Let $f: \R \to \Z$ be an integer-valued function which satisfies both of the following:
:$(1): \quad \map f {x + 1} = \map f x + 1$
:$(2): \quad \forall n \in \Z_{> 0}: \map f x = \map f {\dfrac {\map f {n x} } n}$
Then it is not necessarily the case that either:
:$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = \floor x$
or:
:$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = \ceiling x$

e2c5a1b2-3c53-4944-b0c2-31cff90927a0.text:
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a sequence in $\R$.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be convergent to the following limit:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} x_n = l$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \frac 1 {x_n} = \frac 1 l$
provided that $l \ne 0$.

d9ed9d19-b253-438d-8c71-b4fbdad6ea1a.text: The Continuum Property of the positive real numbers $\R_{\ge 0}$ implies the Well-Ordering Principle of the natural numbers $\N$.

9c63ea20-b0a0-4932-b6bd-91a54247af87.text:
Let $\mathbb S$ be a semiring of sets.
Let $A, A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n$ all belong to $\mathbb S$.
Let $A_1, A_2, \ldots, A_n$ all be pairwise disjoint subsets of $A$.
Then there exists a finite expansion of $A$:
:$\displaystyle \exists s \ge n: A = \bigcup_{k \mathop = 1}^s A_k$
with $A_1, \ldots, A_n$ as its first $n$ elements, such that:
: $(1): \quad \forall k, 1 \le k \le s: A_k \in \mathbb S$
: $(2): \quad \forall k, l, 1 \le k \le s, 1 \le l \le s: k \ne l \implies A_k \cap A_l = \O$.
That is, the nature of a semiring is such that every collection of pairwise disjoint subsets of a given set $A$ of that semiring is part of a larger collection of pairwise disjoint subsets of $A$ which forms a complete partition of $A$.

61ed6d14-2cab-41a0-a2a9-599c72683ba4.text:
:$\ds \sum_{k \mathop = 1}^n \dfrac {H_k} {k + 1} = \dfrac { {H_{n + 1} }^2 - H_{n + 1}^{\paren 2} } 2$
where:
:$H_n$ denotes the $n$th harmonic number
:$H_n^{\paren 2}$ denotes a general harmonic number.

e9267ced-17dd-46b1-a250-678c85129b90.text:
Let $G_n = \sequence {a_n}_{0 \mathop \le i \mathop \le n}$ be a geometric sequence of integers.
Let $a_0 = 1$.
Let $k \in \Z_{> 1}$.
Let $a_1$ not be a power of $k$.
Then $a_m$ is not a power of $k$ except for:
:$\forall m, k \in \set {1, 2, \ldots, n}: k \divides m$
where $\divides$ denotes divisibility.
{{EuclidPropStatement|book = IX|prop = 10|body = If as many numbers as we please beginning from an unit be in continued proportion, and the number after the unit be not square, neither will any other be square except the third from the unit and all those that leave out one. And, if the the number after the unit be not cube, neither will any other be cube except the fourth from the unit and all those that leave out two.}}

a41451a5-a740-4e0d-a9ff-41774d62e8c9.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Then the underlying set $S$ of $T$ is everywhere dense in $T$.

78b12257-db7c-4742-ade2-7cc33e0a2ada.text: For every set $S$, there exists an injection from $S$ to its power set $\powerset S$.

f1b22ca1-4092-4d24-ac9c-839a41ef904a.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $x_1, x_2, \dotsc, x_n \in S$ for some $n \in \N_{>0}$.
Let $\set{k_1, k_2, \dotsc, k_m} \subseteq \set{1, 2, \dotsc, n}$
Then:
:$\max \set {x_{k_1}, x_{k_2}, \dotsc, x_{k_m}} \preceq \max \set {x_1, x_2, \dotsc, x_n}$
where:
:$\max$ denotes the max operation

934e38e8-15bb-4301-8e78-543a33ed23f0.text:
:$\ds \int \frac {\d x} {p \sin a x + q \cos a x + r} = \begin{cases}
\ds \frac 2 {a \sqrt {r^2 - p^2 - q^2} } \map \arctan {\frac {p + \paren {r - q} \tan \dfrac {a x} 2} {\sqrt {r^2 - p^2 - q^2} } } + C & : p^2 + q^2 < r^2 \\
\ds \frac 1 {a \sqrt {p^2 + q^2 - r^2} } \ln \size {\frac {p - \sqrt {p^2 + q^2 - r^2} + \paren {r - q} \tan \dfrac {a x} 2} {p + \sqrt {p^2 + q^2 - r^2} + \paren {r - q} \tan \dfrac {a x} 2} } + C & : p^2 + q^2 > r^2
\end{cases}$

f148c58d-0dea-4047-b10d-77f4c291558a.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $f, g, h: S \to \R$ be real-valued functions.
Let $f + g: S \to \R$ denote the pointwise sum of $f$ and $g$.
Then:
:$\paren {f + g} + h = f + \paren {g + h}$
That is, pointwise addition on real-valued functions is associative.

ef465348-5946-49bc-bbd9-1b00566a293d.text: There are infinitely many prime numbers.

47478470-e8b9-4506-ae72-e5f680885a1c.text: $2016$ has the property that its ratio to its aliquot sum is $4 : 9$.

f7b90228-dae4-43c8-8787-c61fea735d5f.text:
:$\ds \int_0^\infty \frac {\sin a x} {\sinh b x} \rd x = \frac \pi {2 b} \tanh \frac {a \pi} {2 b}$
where:
:$a$ and $b$ are positive real numbers
:$\tanh$ denotes the hyperbolic cotangent function.

bd44413b-a3d4-4972-b8b8-fd1980e06406.text:
Let $S$ be a set of infinite cardinality $\kappa$.
Let $S \left[{x}\right]$ be the set of polynomial forms over $S$ in the indeterminate $x$.
Then $S \left[{x}\right]$ has cardinality $\kappa$.

dedb24d5-e0d9-43d8-b30f-801ec18275c8.text:
:$\sinh 3 x = 3 \sinh x + 4 \sinh^3 x$
where $\sinh$ denotes hyperbolic sine.

bf0719d2-dee2-4c0c-aaf8-a84696e335a1.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring whose zero is $0_R$.
Let $\struct {R / R, +, \circ}$ be the quotient ring defined by $R$.
Then $\struct {R / R, +, \circ}$ is a null ring.

47e7a886-723f-4683-b7bb-119adfd1f0d8.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $a, b, c \in S$.
The following are dual statements:
:$c = a \vee b$, the join of $a$ and $b$
:$c = a \wedge b$ the meet of $a$ and $b$

6e5db60c-e72f-4218-b103-2e183670237e.text:
Let $\map P x$ be an integral polynomial.
Let $a \equiv b \pmod n$.
Then $\map P a \equiv \map P b \pmod n$.
In particular, $a$ is a solution to the polynomial congruence $\map P x \equiv 0 \pmod n$ {{iff}} $b$ is also.

51e4cf46-507e-4f38-aced-eefd3f4fd652.text:
Let $H$ be a Hilbert space, and let $L$ be a bounded linear functional on $H$.
{{explain|We can weaken the assumption that $H$ be a Hilbert space by saying that it is just a normed space, I think. It is not strictly necessary to consider a Hilbert space.}}
Define the following norms of $L$:
:$(1): \quad 
orm L_1 = \sup \set {\size {L h}: 
orm h \le 1}$
:$(2): \quad 
orm L_2 = \sup \set {\size {L h}: 
orm h = 1}$
:$(3): \quad 
orm L_3 = \sup \set {\dfrac {\size {L h} } {
orm h}: h \in H \setminus \set {\mathbf 0} }$
:$(4): \quad 
orm L_4 = \inf \set {c > 0:  orall h \in H: \size {L h} \le c 
orm h}$
Then:
:$
orm L_1 = 
orm L_2 = 
orm L_3 = 
orm L_4$

de23966e-0b7e-4b60-9549-4892be051ab8.text:
Let $\left({R, +, \times}\right)$ be a ring with unity.
Let $A = \operatorname{Ann} \left({R}\right)$ be the annihilator of $R$.
Let $a \in A$ such that $a \ne 0$.
Then $A$ contains at least one strictly positive integer.

2160c98a-bc8e-4b66-b9ad-5f9621b3d3a3.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=43|body=A first bimedial straight line is divided at one point only.}}

54500692-776f-4cc9-b183-2cb637d3a6cb.text:
Let $a, b \in \Z$ be integers such that $b \ge a$.
Let $U$ be a set of $n = b - a + 1$ numbers $\set {x_a, x_{a + 1}, \ldots, x_b}$.
Then:
:$\ds \sum_{a \mathop \le i \mathop < j \mathop < k \mathop \le b} x_i x_j x_k = \dfrac { {S_1}^3} 6 - \dfrac {S_1 S_2} 2 + \dfrac {S_3} 3$
where:
:$\ds S_r := \sum_{k \mathop = a}^b {x_k}^r$

96ee0f51-edff-4995-9efd-e5773423dc65.text:
Let $R$ be a region of space.
Let $U$ and $W$ be scalar fields over $R$.
Then:
:$\map {\operatorname {div} } {U \grad W} = U \nabla^2 W + \paren {\grad U} \cdot \paren {\grad W}$
where:
:$\operatorname {div}$ denotes the divergence operator
:$\grad$ denotes the gradient operator
:$\nabla^2$ denotes the Laplacian.

71376ba5-8d38-4030-80c2-3006edc6776a.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be the real function defined as:
:$\forall x \in \R: \map f x = \sqbrk {x \in \Z}$
where $\sqbrk {\cdots}$ is Iverson's convention.
Then $f$ is a replicative function.

880d722c-206d-4247-becc-f2440a94d811.text:
Let $\struct {K, +_K, \times_K}$ be a division ring.
Let $\struct {V, +_V, \circ_V}_K$ be a $K$-vector space.
Let $\struct {W, +_W, \circ_W}_K$ be a $K$-algebraic structure.
Let $\phi: V \to W$ be a homomorphism, that is, a linear transformation.
Then the homomorphic image of $\phi$ is a $K$-vector space.

6f9291ab-4125-444a-9544-13e08814e78b.text: For $n \in \set {1, 22, 23, 24}$ the number of digits in the decimal representation of $n!$ is equal to $n$.

c0c3b8b3-2cb7-4689-ba57-6df90817d25e.text:
Let $L = \struct {S, \wedge, \preceq}$ be a meet semilattice.
Let $A, B$ be subsets of $S$ such that
:$A$ is coarser than $B$.
Then $\map {\operatorname{fininfs} } A$ is coarser than $\map {\operatorname{fininfs} } B$
where $\map {\operatorname{fininfs} } B$ denotes the finite infima set of $B$.

60835726-60a7-4d7f-953b-dd81c16e89c4.text: Every subset of a countably infinite set is countable.

0cd5b64c-e43d-4b11-90a7-bfd27b25f64d.text:
Let $G$ and $H$ be $n$-dimensional vector spaces over a field.
Let $\map \LL {G, H}$ be the set of all linear transformations from $G$ to $H$.
Let $u \in \map \LL {G, H}$.
Let $u^t$ be the transpose of $u$.
Then:
:$\map \ker {u^t}$ is the annihilator of the image of $u$
where $\map \ker {u^t}$ denotes the kernel of $u^t$.

db98e45f-6a63-406c-8fbf-d648f2b35eb9.text: :$\ds \int e^{a x} \cos^n b x \rd x = \frac {e^{a x} \cos^{n - 1} b x} {a^2 + n^2 b^2} \paren {a \cos b x + n b \sin b x} + \frac {n \paren {n - 1} b^2} {a^2 + n^2 b^2} \int e^{a x} \cos^{n - 2} b x \rd x + C$

44a44a4d-9602-4057-ac03-78a6656a7022.text:
The arithmetic sequence:
:$30, 66, 102, 138$
is the smallest of $4$ terms which consists entirely of positive integers each with $3$ distinct prime factors.

3ce668e7-41fb-49a0-83cb-ccf346e6d3d1.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a division ring.
Then $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ has no proper zero divisors.

c6cc02fc-058b-4596-876f-ba9e5bfba79e.text:
Let $L$ be a distributive lattice.
{{explain|Full notational specification needed}}
Let $F$ be a filter in $L$.
Let $M$ be an ideal in $L$ which is disjoint from $F$ such that no ideal in $L$ larger than $M$ is disjoint from $F$.
Then $M$ is a prime ideal.

df23b831-8226-49eb-94f2-5a62c534d12f.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{\le 0}$.
Then:
:$\phi^n = F_n \phi + F_{n - 1}$
where:
:$F_n$ denotes the $n$th Fibonacci number as extended to negative indices
:$\phi$ denotes the golden mean.

cd00e827-222a-4776-8d68-a39f440f588a.text: There exists at least one example of a first-countable topological space which is not also a second-countable space.

b2ed7181-f71c-46cc-bbe3-243aa5b68ff4.text: The cartesian product of two countable sets is countable.

489667b5-d02e-4b53-a7f3-e6562d058150.text:
Let $\mathbf C$ and $\mathbf D$ be categories.
Let $F: \mathbf C \to \mathbf D$ be a faithful functor.
Let $x$ and $y$ be objects in $\mathbf C$.
Let $f: x \to y$ be a morphism in $\mathbf C$.
Assume, that $\map F f : \map F x \to \map F y$ is a monomorphism in $\mathbf D$.
Then $f$ is a monomorphism in $\mathbf C$.

4e42c529-206f-421b-8b0d-fc945d3c0e80.text:
:$\ds \int_0^1 \frac {x^m - x^n} {\ln x} \rd x = \map \ln {\frac {m + 1} {n + 1} }$
where $m$ and $n$ are real numbers with $m, n > -1$.

37a464c5-1242-47eb-a853-e64d1d4a47ed.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$, $\struct {T, \precsim}$ be ordered sets.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
For every filter $F$ in $\struct {S, \preceq}$, let $f$ preserve the infimum on $F$.
Then $f$ preserves filtered infima.

fbbb3fb3-81fd-4cf3-8b63-e3870b31dc44.text:
Let $\ds \map f x = \frac {\size x} 2$ where $\size x$ is the absolute value function.
Let $\delta \in \map {\DD'} \R$ be the Dirac delta distribution.
Let $T_f \in \map {\DD'} \R$ be the distribution associated with $f$.
Then $T_f$ is the fundamental solution to the $1$-dimensional Laplace's equation.
That is:
:$T''_f = \delta$
or in the distributional sense:
:$\dfrac {\d^2} {\d x^2} f = \delta$

766e52a7-17a5-4d1c-b3f5-04d4d851c38b.text:
Let $T_\R = \struct {\R, \tau_\R}$ be the (uncountable) discrete space on the set of real numbers.
Let $T_D = \struct {D, \tau_D}$ be the indiscrete topology on the doubleton $D = \set {a, b}$.
Let $T = T_\R \times T_D$ be the double pointed (uncountable) discrete space which is the product space of $T_\R$ and $T_D$.
Then $T$ is '''not''' a Lindelöf space.

9b8a3f6c-ddac-474c-a9fc-a2399ac26644.text:
Let $\sequence {z_n}$ and $\sequence {w_n}$ be sequences in $\C$.
Let $\sequence {z_n}$ and $\sequence {w_n}$ be convergent to the following limits:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} z_n = c$
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} w_n = d$
Then:
:$\ds \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \paren {z_n - w_n} = c - d$

6c4df215-7612-4eda-b708-ce3b0ec5b293.text:
Let $S$ and $T$ be sets.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a mapping.
Let $\powerset S$ be the power set of $S$.
Then:
:$\ds \forall \mathbb S \subseteq \powerset S: f \sqbrk {\bigcap \mathbb S} = \bigcap_{X \mathop \in \mathbb S} f \sqbrk X$ 
{{iff}} $f$ is an injection.

e7a7e49c-f3fd-4a4d-9161-0690db71dd60.text:
Let $M_1 = \left({A_1, d_1}\right)$ and $M_2 = \left({A_2, d_2}\right)$ be metric spaces.
Let $\phi: M_1 \to M_2$ be a surjective distance-preserving mapping.
That is:
:$\forall a, b \in M_1: d_1 \tuple {a, b} = d_2 \tuple {\map \phi a, \map \phi b}$
Then $\phi$ is an isometry.

d2a32f0a-ee13-4d3f-98ef-d9f1c6feca8e.text:
:$\ds \int \frac 1 {\sqrt {a^2 - x^2} } \rd x = -\arccos \frac x a + C$
where $a$ is a strictly positive constant and $a^2 > x^2$.

855920a9-84df-44ed-a171-97768de6efa9.text: The set of Eisenstein integers $\Z \sqbrk \omega$, under the operations of complex addition and complex multiplication, forms a subring of the set of complex numbers $\C$.

be09af3d-8dd4-4a4e-bbff-9f33441f1f0d.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $x$ be a point of $T$.
Then:
:$\set x^-$ is irreducible
where $\set x^-$ denotes the topological closure of $\set x$.

2e5bf06e-9b1c-4c8d-8822-f278f95d3c65.text:
Let $P$ be the cubic equation:
:$a x^3 + b x^2 + c x + d = 0$ with $a \ne 0$
Then $P$ has solutions:
:$x_1 = S + T - \dfrac b {3 a}$
:$x_2 = - \dfrac {S + T} 2 - \dfrac b {3 a} + \dfrac {i \sqrt 3} 2 \paren {S - T}$
:$x_3 = - \dfrac {S + T} 2 - \dfrac b {3 a} - \dfrac {i \sqrt 3} 2 \paren {S - T}$
where:
:$S = \sqrt [3] {R + \sqrt {Q^3 + R^2} }$
:$T = \sqrt [3] {R - \sqrt {Q^3 + R^2} }$
where:
:$Q = \dfrac {3 a c - b^2} {9 a^2}$
:$R = \dfrac {9 a b c - 27 a^2 d - 2 b^3} {54 a^3}$
The expression $D = Q^3 + R^2$ is called the '''discriminant''' of the equation.

a22b47f0-0054-448a-9ffe-4b2cbfa5e769.text:
Let $T = \left({S, \tau}\right)$ be a topological space.
Let $A \mid B$ be a separation of $T$.
Then both $A$ and $B$ are clopen in $T$.

56e4fa33-42f1-4e28-b1f8-45f831a81f0c.text:
Let $x \in \R$ be a real number.
Let $n \in \Z$ be an integer.
Then:
:$\left\vert{x^{2 n} }\right\vert = x^{2 n}$

e2b415d4-20f7-4513-ba07-61fac1a777ac.text:
Let $\struct {S, \precsim}$ be a preordered set.
Let $x, y \in S$ such that
:$x \precsim y$
Then $\map \precsim y \subseteq \mathord {\map \precsim x}$
where $\map \precsim y$ denotes the image of $y$ under $\precsim$.

225a0440-eff5-4c18-a92c-5ea70940db16.text:
:$\ds \int \frac {x \rd x} {x^2 - a^2} = \frac 1 2 \map \ln {x^2 - a^2} + C$
for $x^2 > a^2$.

7b56cea3-25f2-4c42-b218-c37af0cd9cf1.text:
Let $A$ be an ordinal.
Then:
:$A \in \On \lor A = \On$
where $\On$ denote the class of ordinals .

7de36520-d291-4d11-9207-35467ac5e8c6.text:
Let $z$ be a complex number.
Let $\cot z$ denote the cotangent function and $i$ denote the imaginary unit: $i^2 = -1$.
Then:
:$\cot z = i \dfrac {e^{i z} + e^{-i z} } {e^{i z} - e^{-i z} }$

305fe686-4bf3-4dd9-af3f-2012b5b081f5.text:
Let:
:$\struct {R_1, +_1, \circ_1}$
:$\struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2}$
:$\struct {R_3, +_3, \circ_3}$
be rings.
Let:
:$\phi: \struct {R_1, +_1, \circ_1} \to \struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2}$
:$\psi: \struct {R_2, +_2, \circ_2} \to \struct {R_3, +_3, \circ_3}$
be (ring) monomorphisms.
Then the composite of $\phi$ and $\psi$ is also a (ring) monomorphism.

74ba8db1-54d6-47e4-a1c9-dd3c83eb23fc.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $x \in T$.
Let $\CC_x = \left\{ {A \subseteq S : x \in A \land A }\right.$ is path-connected in $\left. {T}\right\}$.
Let $C = \bigcup \CC_x$
Let $\sim$ be the equivalence relation defined by:
:$y \sim z$ {{iff}} $y$ and $z$ are path-connected in $T$.
Let $C'$ be the equivalence class of $\sim$ containing $x$.
Then $C = C'$.

fc40c826-49af-4457-b259-7b493c894604.text:
Let $C$ be a curve defined by a real function which is twice differentiable.
Let the curvature of $C$ be non-constant.
The length of arc of the evolute $E$ of $C$ between any two points $Q_1$ and $Q_2$ of $C$ is equal to the difference between the radii of curvature at the corresponding points $P_1$ and $P_2$ of $C$.

397cdbf2-3c69-43fc-bb54-1d855e0178f0.text:
Let $\family {\struct{X_i, \tau_i}}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be an $I$-indexed family of topological spaces.
Let $X$ be the cartesian product of $\family {X_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$, that is:
:$\ds X := \prod_{i \mathop \in I} X_i$
Let $\tau$ be the box topology on $X$.
For each $i \in I$, let $\pr_i: X \to X_i$ denote the $i$th projection on $X$:
:$\forall \family {x_j}_{j \mathop \in I} \in X: \map {\pr_i} {\family {x_j}_{j \mathop \in I} } = x_i$
Then $\tau$ may not be the coarsest topology on $X$ for which the projections $\family{\pr_i} _{i \mathop \in I}$ are continuous.

2379b42a-62ae-4d97-aee7-1a38350f5f2a.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
The following are equivalent:
:$(1): \quad X$ contains an uncountable subset
:$(2): \quad X$ is uncountable
:$(3): \quad $ Every sequence of distinct points $\sequence {x_n}_{n \mathop \in \N}$ in $X$ omits at least one $x \in X$
:$(4): \quad $ There is no surjection $\N \twoheadrightarrow X$
:$(5): \quad X$ is infinite and there is no bijection $X \leftrightarrow \N$
Assuming the Continuum Hypothesis holds, we also have the equivalent uncountability condition:
:$(6): \quad $There exist extended real numbers $a < b$ and a surjection $X \to \closedint a b$

cef2e9ad-a398-453d-bb55-d933cd47b786.text:
Let $\N_{>0}$ be the set of natural numbers without zero:
: $\N_{>0} = \left\{{1, 2, 3, \ldots}\right\}$
Let $\left \langle {n_r} \right \rangle$ be strictly increasing sequence in $\N_{>0}$.
Then:
: $\forall r \in \N_{>0}: n_r \ge r$

cc4441d0-0a83-4da2-9514-8f66ce91dc01.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\family {S_i}_{i \mathop \in I}$ be a family of subsets of $S$.
Then:
:$\ds \relcomp S {\bigcup_{i \mathop \in I} \mathbb S_i} = \bigcap_{i \mathop \in I} \relcomp S {S_i}$

b06c045e-aee0-410c-b441-61258eaf24e6.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $H$ be a subgroup of $G$.
Let $x \in G$.
Let:
: $x H$ be the left coset of $x$ modulo $H$.
Then:
: $x \in x H$

35760ee6-c568-4099-b41c-b40919b45bae.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book = VII|prop = 39|body = To find the number which is the least that will have given parts.}}

d2da6a94-1dc4-49e0-a1f0-78b24d9e3eeb.text:
Let $A$ be a commutative ring with unity.
Let $\mathfrak a, \mathfrak b \subseteq A$ be ideals.
Let their radicals be coprime:
:$\map \Rad {\mathfrak a} + \map \Rad {\mathfrak b} = \ideal 1$
Then $\mathfrak a$ and $\mathfrak b$ are coprime.

5cc4fd2e-1e80-481d-b9c9-40f3fdb25eb7.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set. 
Then the semigroup $\struct {S, \max}$ is commutative.

9b82b29a-362a-4989-8d2d-73498465ed20.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \circ}$ be a ring with unity whose unity is $1_R$.
Let $S$ be a division subring of $R$, such that $1_R \in S$.
The vector space $\struct {R, +, \circ_S}_S$ over $\circ_S$ is a $S$-vector space.

2412acee-7354-4da1-a5fd-4bb92df16557.text:
Let $\N_n$ denote the set $\set {1, 2, \ldots, n}$.
Let $\struct {S_n, \circ}$ denote the symmetric group on $\N_n$.
Let $r \in \N: 0 < r \le n$.
Let $B_r$ denote the set of all subsets of $\N_n$ of cardinality $r$:
:$B_r  := \set {S \subseteq \N_n: \card S = r}$
Let $*$ be the mapping $*: S_n \times B_r \to B_r$ defined as:
:$\forall \pi \in S_n, \forall S \in B_r: \pi * B_r = \pi \sqbrk S$
where $\pi \sqbrk S$ denotes the image of $S$ under $\pi$.
Then $*$ is a group action.

fe57aad7-2198-4c03-b207-e2b04e92d347.text:
Let $\tuple {\mathbf e_1, \mathbf e_2, \mathbf e_3}$ be the standard ordered basis of Cartesian $3$-space $S$.
Let $\mathbf a = a_1 \mathbf e_1 + a_2 \mathbf e_2 + a_3 \mathbf e_3$ be a vector quantity in $S$.
Then:
:$\mathbf a \cdot \mathbf e_i = a_i$

d737e7bd-3939-46d6-a154-30f5b1d82023.text:
Let $p$ be a prime number.
Let $\struct {\Q_p, \norm {\,\cdot\,}_p}$ be the $p$-adic numbers.
Let $\sequence {x_n}$ be a Cauchy sequence such that $\sequence {x_n}$ does not converge to $0$.
Then:
:$\exists N \in \N: \forall n, m \ge N: \norm {x_n}_p = \norm {x_m}_p$

ee52cc01-bd8b-4fbd-98ea-ff2c5ca7162a.text:
Let $n \in \Z_{>0}$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Let $\struct {\map {\mathcal M_\R} n, +, \times}$ denote the ring of square matrices of order $n$ over $\R$.
Then $\struct {\map {\mathcal M_\R} n, +, \times}$ is a ring with unity, but is not a commutative ring.

82915f0a-d5ca-4aeb-9a71-4ad0f93f645b.text:
Let $r \in \R_{> 0}$ be a (strictly) positive real number.
Let $x, y \in \Q$ be rational numbers.
Let $r^x$ be defined as $r$ to the power of $x$.
Then:
:$\paren {r^x}^y = r^{x y}$

eaf90acc-39b5-4843-b966-d04665f11dc9.text:
Let $\tuple {a, b, c}$ be a Pythagorean triple such that $a^2 + b^2 = c^2$.
Then at least one of $a$, $b$, $a + b$ or $a - b$ is divisible by $7$.

72c38c49-516e-48d6-94b7-ff30e0606548.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Every filter on $S$ is contained in an ultrafilter on $S$.

2c49163b-a01e-4fb0-99a1-d0965c2f2ccc.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be an ordered set.
Let $T \subseteq S$.
Let $T$ have a smallest element $m \in T$.
Then $m$ is a lower bound of $T$.
It follows by definition that $T$ is bounded below.

50bde691-471c-49a0-ab64-22b6cf493798.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be a real function which is integrable on the interval $\closedint a b$.
Let the points be defined:
:$A = \tuple {a, \map f a}$
:$B = \tuple {b, \map f b}$
:$C = \tuple {b, 0}$
:$D = \tuple {a, 0}$
Let the figure $ABCD$ be defined as being bounded by the straight lines $y = 0$, $x = a$, $x = b$ and the curve defined by $\set {\map f x: a \le x \le b}$.
Let the solid of revolution $S$ be generated by rotating $ABCD$ around the $x$-axis (that is, $y = 0$).
Then the volume $V$ of $S$ is given by:
:$\displaystyle V = \pi \int_a^b \paren {\map f x}^2 \rd x$

898fe949-2ff8-465b-8c8e-280b91e76872.text:
A geometric sequence of integers in lowest terms has extremes which are coprime.
{{EuclidPropStatement|book = VIII|prop = 3|body = If as many numbers as we please in continued proportion be the least of those which have the same ratio with them, the extremes of them are prime to one another.}}

9575df8b-a663-402c-bfa3-211328ccd60b.text:
Let $f: \R \to \R$ be an even real function which is Lebesgue integrable.
Let $\ds \map \FF {\map f t} = \map F s = \int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-2 \pi i s t} \map f t \rd t$ be the Fourier transform of $f$.
Let $\ds \map \FF {\map F s} = \map g t = \int_{-\infty}^\infty e^{-2 \pi i t s} \map F s \rd s$ be the Fourier transform of $F$.
Then:
:$\map g t = \map f t$

97e07d47-c081-4605-836e-5a95144d2cde.text:
Let $S$ be a set.
Let $\powerset S$ be the power set of $S$.
Then there is no injection from $\powerset S$ into $S$.

2bc7343b-f33f-423f-9390-7fc856a09829.text:
Let $\struct {R, +, \times}$ be a ring.
Then $\struct {R, +, \times}$ is a left module over $\struct {R, +, \times}$.

4e54ba3a-365f-4de3-a0f6-f3e4377aa5fa.text:
An integer $N$ expressed in decimal notation is divisible by $8$ {{iff}} the $3$ least significant digits of $N$ form a $3$-digit integer divisible by $8$.
That is:
:$N = \sqbrk {a_n \ldots a_2 a_1 a_0}_{10} = a_0 + a_1 10 + a_2 10^2 + \cdots + a_n 10^n$ is divisible by $8$ 
{{iff}}:
:$100 a_2 + 10 a_1 + a_0$ is divisible by $8$.

9ba41445-6a03-4ea1-8776-aafc820d52f5.text:
:$\ds \int_0^1 \frac {1 - \cos x} x \rd x - \int_1^\infty \frac {\cos x} x \rd x = \gamma$
 
where $\gamma$ is the Euler-Mascheroni Constant.

f6b9152b-7674-4ad0-b5a6-c381c65c8aee.text:
:$\csc i = \left({\dfrac {2 e} {1 - e^2} }\right) i$
where $\csc$ denotes the complex cosecant function and $i$ is the imaginary unit.

293997a8-47cb-445a-9bc0-c86a8e17609e.text:
The set of octonions $\Bbb O$ forms an algebra over the field of real numbers.
This algebra is:
:$(1): \quad$ An alternative algebra, but '''not''' an associative algebra.
:$(2): \quad$ A normed division algebra.
:$(3): \quad$ A nicely normed $*$-algebra.

93ca4785-26db-4f20-8ecf-91dc23ea0336.text:
Let $T$ be a topological space.
Let $A \subseteq T$.
Then:
:$A$ is dense-in-itself
{{iff}}:
:$A \subseteq A'$
where
:$A'$ denotes the derivative of $A$.

104b1906-c36e-43b7-88e2-4f9727869788.text:
Let $I \subseteq \R$ be a real interval.
Let $f : I \to \R$ be an constant real function.
Then $f$ is absolutely continuous.

edc69632-0153-435c-96d3-aae9cdfff58e.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $f: S \to T$ be a bijection to an arbitrary set $T$.
Let $\RR$ be a relation on $T$ defined such that:
:$\RR: = \set {\tuple {\map f x, \map f y}: x \preccurlyeq y}$
Then $f$ is an order isomorphism between $\struct {S, \preccurlyeq}$ and $\struct {T, \RR}$.

ba295108-a132-4ddb-b41d-489d3f9fac33.text:
Let $D$ be a principal ideal domain.
Let $M$ be a $D$-module.
Then $M$ is injective {{iff}} it is divisible.

612de57e-ad7d-4386-b670-79cad243d708.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space.
Let $T^*_p = \struct {S^*_p, \tau^*_p}$ be the closed extension space of $T$.
Then $T^*_p$ is irreducible.

36addc14-7982-4734-b0c3-279ddc29b9f0.text:
Let $M$ and $N$ be distinct lines in the plane.
:420px
Let $\pr_{M, N}$ be the '''projection on $M$ along $N$''':
:$\forall x \in \R^2: \map {\pr_{M, N} } x =$ the intersection of $M$ with the line through $x$ parallel to $N$.
Then $M$ is the image of $\pr_{M, N}$.

6a81c557-9a64-4cad-90fa-924fa7837ece.text:
Let $S \subseteq \C$ be a closed subset of the complex plane $\C$.
Then the complement of $S$ in $\C$ is open.

e7540285-7151-4c15-bef7-e4f4ec6c2f87.text:
Let $T = \struct {\R, \tau}$ be the Sorgenfrey line.
Then $T$ is Hausdorff.

bc86e00e-2afb-4757-bd9a-89fee1f56655.text: A vector space has unique additive identity.

7d6b8411-c329-443e-ba51-f1c90940f95a.text:
Let $x$ be a limit ordinal.
Let $y \in x$.
Then $y^+ \in x$ where $y^+$ denotes the successor set of $y$:
:$\forall y \in x: y^+ \in x$

92aa9af5-1fab-4716-b8d0-603553f18c0b.text:
The set of complex numbers is closed under subtraction:
:$\forall a, b \in \C: a - b \in \C$

1f6c0fff-f775-4ad9-8419-4b56439eea82.text:
Let $(S, \preceq, \tau)$ be an ordered set.
Let $T$ be a subset of $S$.
Let $U$ be the upper closure of $T$.
Then $U$ is an upper set.

66c1ca9f-4202-4831-ae19-6b6e2a657434.text:
Let $\struct {X, \Sigma}$ be a measurable space.
Let $f, g : X \to \R$ be simple functions.
Then $f \cdot g: X \to \R, \map {\paren {f \cdot g} } x := \map f x \cdot \map g x$ is also a simple function.

37a581a6-f0c7-42a4-a967-7c88c63af6d2.text:
Let $\Omega$ denote the first uncountable ordinal.
Let $\hointr 0 \Omega$ denote the open ordinal space on $\Omega$.
Then $\hointr 0 \Omega$ is a sequentially compact space.

3713aec8-3cfc-4b0b-90db-eeac1bf82b78.text:
Let $x, y \in \R$ be real numbers.
Let $x \bmod y$ denote the modulo operation:
:$x \bmod y := \begin{cases}
x - y \left \lfloor {\dfrac x y}\right \rfloor & : y \ne 0 \\
x & : y = 0
\end{cases}$
where $\left \lfloor {\dfrac x y}\right \rfloor$ denotes the floor of $\dfrac x y$.
Let $y < 0$.
Then:
:$0 \ge x \bmod y > y$

d2cdbff3-69bc-4f71-9072-4a8943fb5129.text:
Let $G$ be a group.
Let $S \subseteq G$.
Let $\hat S = S \cup S^{-1}$, where $S^{-1}$ is the set of all the inverses of all the elements of $S$.
Let $\tilde S = \set {a s a^{-1}: s \in \hat S, a \in G}$.
Let $\map W {\tilde S}$ be the set of words of $\tilde S$.
Let $N$ be the smallest normal subgroup of $G$ that contains $S$.
Then $N = \gen S = \map W {\tilde S}$.

03cf2232-b21a-4255-973f-3cbfb4f798bc.text:
Let $D \subseteq \C$ be an open subset of the set of complex numbers $\C$.
Let $f: D \to \C$ be a complex function on $D$.
Let $u, v: \set {\paren {x, y} \in \R^2: x + i y = z \in D} \to \R$ be two real-valued functions defined as:
:$\map u {x, y} = \map \Re {\map f z}$
:$\map v {x, y} = \map \Im {\map f z}$
where:
:$\map \Re {\map f z}$ denotes the real part of $\map f z$
:$\map \Im {\map f z}$ denotes the imaginary part of $\map f z$.
Let:
:$u$ and $v$ be differentiable in their entire domain
and:
:The following two equations, known as the '''Cauchy-Riemann equations''', hold for the continuous partial derivatives of $u$ and $v$:
::$(1): \quad \dfrac {\partial u} {\partial x} = \dfrac {\partial v} {\partial y}$
::$(2): \quad \dfrac {\partial u} {\partial y} = -\dfrac {\partial v} {\partial x}$
Then:
:$f$ is complex-differentiable in $D$
and:
:for all $z \in D$:
::$\map {f'} z = \map {\dfrac {\partial f} {\partial x} } z = -i \map {\dfrac {\partial f} {\partial y} } z$

2275f86c-4e0b-4b03-867f-c644fe84d899.text:
Let $n > 0$ be a (strictly) positive integer.
Then:
:$\ds \prod_{d \mathop \divides n} \map {\Phi_d} x = x^n - 1$
where:
:$\map {\Phi_d} x$ denotes the $d$th cyclotomic polynomial
:the product runs over all divisors of $n$.

7764a7a6-4f51-4740-b77e-88e959a32337.text:
Let $n$ be a finite ordinal.
Let $\left|{n}\right|$ denote the cardinal number of $n$.
Then:
:$\left|{n}\right| = n$

f24ebd75-8c53-4ece-97ff-55be721e312b.text: A group can not contain exactly two elements of order $2$.

12028f4e-d189-47ca-9e57-16effb7c7c05.text:
Let $f$ be a real function which is:
:$(1): \quad$ Differentiable on $\R$
:$(2): \quad$ Bounded on $\R$
:$(3): \quad$ Concave on $\R$.
Then $f$ is constant.

525c219e-fd1c-46db-92b3-37e8cb7771f3.text: The smallest positive integer which is the sum of $2$ odd primes in $6$ different ways is $60$.

18ca0086-9045-4414-9cda-759e5ef4884c.text: The set $\Q$ of rational numbers is countably infinite.

fed80919-1121-4fb1-a308-6f5b5e637ed9.text:
Let $n \in \N$ and $n = p_1 \times p_2 \times \cdots \times p_j$, $j \ge 2$, where $p_1, \ldots, p_j \in \Bbb P$ are prime factors of $n$.
Then $\exists p_i \in \Bbb P$ such that $p_i \le \sqrt n$.
That is, if $n \in \N$ is composite, then $n$ has a prime factor $p \le \sqrt n$.

ce8ab3c6-d5ac-4403-8aad-01611b92d850.text:
Let $s = \sigma + i t$
Let $\ds \map f s = \sum_{n \mathop = 1}^\infty a_n e^{-\lambda_n s}$ be a general Dirichlet series.
Then there exists a extended real number, $\sigma_0$, such that
:$(1): \quad$ For $\sigma < \sigma_0$, $\map f s$ diverges
:$(2): \quad$ For $\sigma > \sigma_0$, $\map f s$ converges.

59eaf07a-616d-4201-8232-8b17ef46f0ea.text:
Let $T = \struct {S, \tau}$ be a topological space which is ultraconnected.
Then $T$ is path-connected.

788d693c-a2a4-4944-9c10-64146906ce5e.text:
Let $\struct {R, \norm {\, \cdot \,} }$ be a normed division ring.
Let $\CC$ be the ring of Cauchy sequences over $R$
Let $\NN$ be the set of null sequences.
For all $\sequence {x_n} \in \CC$, let $\eqclass {x_n}{}$ denote the left coset $\sequence {x_n} + \NN$
Let $\norm {\, \cdot \,}_1: \CC \, \big / \NN \to \R_{\ge 0}$ be defined by:
:$\ds \forall \eqclass {x_n} {} \in \CC \,\big / \NN: \norm {\eqclass {x_n}{} }_1 = \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \norm {x_n}$
Then:
:$\norm {\, \cdot \,}_1$ is well-defined.
That is, 
:$(1): \quad \ds \forall \eqclass {x_n}{}: \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \norm{x_n}$ exists
:$(2): \quad \ds \forall \eqclass {x_n}{}, \eqclass {y_n}{} \in \CC \,\big / \NN: \eqclass {x_n}{} = \eqclass {y_n}{} \implies \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \norm{x_n} = \lim_{n \mathop \to \infty} \norm{y_n}$

0f1a47fc-259b-4ed5-bafc-3a8faa1e56cb.text:
Let $x \in \Z$ be an odd square.
Then $x \equiv 1 \pmod 8$.

23983d39-4394-4f1d-ac44-4d7488f79045.text:
Let $\struct {S, \preceq}$ be a totally ordered set.
Let $\map \min {x, y}$ denote the min operation on $x, y \in S$.
Then $\struct {S, \min}$ is a semigroup.

53bb2767-8001-40fd-b78b-7b7ab6cee8ce.text: {{EuclidPropStatement|book=X|prop=4|body=Given three commensurable magnitudes, to find their greatest common measure.}}

95d1d91a-1415-48f9-9db6-846e4937a1cb.text: There exists at least one example of a separable topological space which is not also a second-countable space.

b3371c63-ebb0-40b3-86ae-cca75db8064d.text:
Let $\mathbf u$ be a vector in the vector space $\R^n$.
Then:
:$\mathbf u \cdot \mathbf u \ge 0$

079ce1b2-6824-4fa4-87e6-ce0add3dcf95.text:
Let $\struct {D, +, \times, \le}$ be an ordered integral domain whose zero is denoted by $0_D$.
For all $a \in D$, let $\size a$ denote the absolute value of $a$.
Then:
:$\size a \times \size b = \size {a \times b}$

fb404c0d-db66-4eb0-9490-51ddc147462a.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $\struct {F_X, \iota}$ be a free group on $X$.
Let $F_X^{\mathrm {ab} }$ be its abelianization.
Let $\pi : F_X \to F_X^{\mathrm {ab} }$ be the quotient group epimorphism.
Then $\struct {F_X^{\mathrm {ab} }, \pi \circ \iota}$ is a free abelian group on $X$.

3c299c3a-f182-4deb-8305-e22405ec80ec.text:
Let $D$ be the unit disk centred at $0$.
Let $g : D \to \C$ be a complex function such that: 
:$\map g z = \begin {cases} \dfrac {\map f z} z & z \ne 0 \\ \map {f'} 0 & z = 0\end {cases}$
Then $g$ is holomorphic on $D$.

6c13198e-f818-40d7-8afc-1822c545381c.text: The only generators of the additive group of integers $\struct {\Z, +}$ are $1$ and $-1$.

7fe37d31-6a51-46a0-bc35-f1530b52731b.text:
Let $X$ be a set.
Let $\AA$ be a non-empty set of subsets of $X$.
Let $'$ be a unary operation on $X$.
Let $\AA$ have finite character.
For all $A \in \AA$ and all $x \in X$, let either:
: $A \cup \set x \in \AA$
or:
:$A \cup \set {x'} \in \AA$
Then for each $A \in \AA$ there exists a $C \in \AA$ such that:
:$A \subseteq C$
and:
:for all $x \in X$, either $x \in C$ or $x' \in C$.

85c174d4-2a92-46f1-9829-c183ee341e33.text:
Let $H$ be a hypocycloid $H$ generated by a circle $C_1$ of radius $b$ rolling within a circle $C_2$ of (larger) radius $a$.
Let $a = n b$ where $n$ is an integer.
Then $H$ has $n$ cusps.

68d1276f-019d-4ae4-a533-60723dc529d5.text:
Let $\left({S, \preceq}\right)$ and $\left({T, \precsim}\right)$ be ordered set.
Let $f:S \to T$ be an increasing mapping.
Let $x \in S$.
Then $\inf \left({f\left[{x^\succeq}\right]}\right) = f\left({x}\right)$

444bb3c4-54a8-497e-9c04-d9b954906182.text:
Let $L = \left({S, \wedge, \preceq}\right)$ be a bounded below meet-continuous meet semilattice.
Let $\mathit{Ids}\left({L}\right)$ be the set of all ideals in $L$.
Let $I$ be an ideal in $L$.
Let $f: S \to \mathit{Ids}\left({L}\right)$ be a mapping such that
:$\forall x \in S: x \preceq \sup I \implies f\left({x}\right) = \left\{ {x \wedge i: i \in I}\right\}$
and
:$\forall x \in S: x \npreceq \sup I \implies f\left({x}\right) = x^\preceq$
where $x^\preceq$ denotes the lower closure of $x$.
Then
:there exists an auxiliary approximating relation $\mathcal R$ on $S$ such that
::$\forall s \in S: f\left({s}\right) = s^{\mathcal R}$
where $s^{\mathcal R}$ denotes the $\mathcal R$-segment of $s$.

e3842d94-6de2-498d-b6e0-915482fb59a1.text:
Let $C_n$ be the square Cauchy matrix of order $n$:
:$C_n = \begin{bmatrix}
\dfrac 1 {x_1 + y_1} & \dfrac 1 {x_1 + y_2} & \cdots & \dfrac 1 {x_1 + y_n} \\
